review_body: The hotel is very well connected from both the airport Haneda and Narita. Nearest Japan Metro Station is Hanzomon on Hanzomon Line. The staffs at the JR odesk at the airport will guide you, give you the route map and guide you in buying the ticket. The signages are excellent which will take you through. From Hanzomon station take the Exit 2 and it is 2mins walk from there.The hotel is excellent very near to National Theatre, Japan Diet, Imperial Palace, Shibuya, Ginja etc. Breakfast is good. It is set menu and not the buffet type with American and Japanese option.

Rooms were bigger than most for the price range- also great view of the park! Hotel is pretty dated but kept very clean. Staff are variable, some were pleasant, some very grumpy. Location is great- few minutes walk to the subway station, a few places to eat nearby.

The reception staff on duty showed no sincereness, as in such a well established Hotel at least should provide. We booked a non-smoking room well in advance but, when we arrived the reception said all non-smoking room has been booked out so they gave us a smoking room. We checked into the room and stayed for two hours but couldn’t bear the strong smell. Then my husband went to the reception to ask them to give us a non-smoking room, since we will stay in the hotel for another four days. At first the reception said he can’t do anything about it as all non-smoking rooms are booked out even for future dates. That was ridiculous, because we booked it three months in advance. After trying a few polite ways without results, my husband called his supervisor or manager. Like a magic spell, the reception went into a room, within five seconds and came out saying OK I’ll give you a non-smoking room for the rest of your stay, all sorted. We checked into the non-smoking room and stayed for another four days. Nothing special about the room, it’s a bit old fashioned and relatively clean room. I don’t think we will book this hotel again when we visit Tokyo regardless the location is convenient.

Unfortunately it’s hard to review this hotel directly after travelling 5 star for business then moving to personal budget!But, considering what is on offer in the similar price range in Tokyo you get a lot of bang for your buck here. I booked a double bed room which was more than enough space for me and could fit a couple ok. A little tight if you are accustomed to space.Superb palace and City views from the 9th floor.The room Was scrupulously clean and the bed was comfortable with plenty of amenities.Wifi was perfect and free and they were very accommodating with a late check out.Ground floor restaurant service was speedy and food was good.I found this to be easily accessible and good value.

comfortable, well located. two great restaurants-- one sushi, the other tempura (watch chef preparing in small dining room) very clean. would stay there again.American breakfast only fair, but adequate

Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Okay hotel, rooms are a decent size with a functional bathroom though the bathrooms could do with an upgrade. Definitely ask for a non-smoking room, the smoking floors are stuffy and even using the air purifier constantly in the room there is still a smell of musty smoke. Located in an area that is close to the imperial palace which is great if you plan to visit but it is out of the way. A 5 minute walk to the subway which makes sightseeing easier. Breakfast is okay but nothing to rave about. The bar is closed on the weekend so be prepared to arrange to go out to find a local bar or somewhere to eat. Reception staff are very pleasant and helpful.

I’ll get past the main negative first, yes the rooms are small but for this value in Tokyo you’re not going to do much better.What you do get is a great hotel close to the Imperial Palace with an excellent view, relatively modern rooms and peace and quiet. Plus the WiFi is free and very fast.A short walk from the Hanzomon tube station, it’s 20 mins from either Tokyo Station or Shibuya which makes it a good location to get to many different places.

We stayed here a total of 4 nights. The staff are very friendly and helpful. The rooms are badly laid out with a huge deck but nowhere to put your suitcase (if you have more than one). The bed is against one wall, so if there are two of you, you need to climb over each other. Some of the halls smell of smoke. The location is reasonable and the views from the rooms are excellent.
user_name:
Stephen M
Alhama de Granada, Spain

review_body: We were really surprised, the hotel turned out to be much better than expected. Very conveniently located near Hanzomon station and overlooking the park. The view from the room was really great what with Cherry blossom in full bloom. Our mission was only Cherry Blossom and we were so very happy!!The front office staff was very helpful and they arranged for our large suitcases to be sent to Kyoto to our Hotel there. This is a very convenient arrangement in Japan and one can travel very easily in trains without bothering about luggage.

Clean sums this hotel up. Restaurant serves breakfast which is ok, not excellent. No bell boy to bring up bags, carry your own, ok but not great.Clean and unexceptional room, little small and tight (too much furniture) noisy a/c fan, again clean but unexceptional. Bottom line is if the price is lower than surrounding hotels .....you get what you pay for.

A beautifully situated hotel in an elegant area of Tokyo. Opposite the Imperial Palace and 2 minutes walk from the metro station. Our room offered amazing views of the city and at night the lights looked amazing too. Our room was extremely comfortable with tea/coffee making facilities provided. Staff speak English so thankfully no problem with having to struggle with Japanese. I would not hesitate to stay here again. The area is unhurried and relatively quiet even though it’s in the centre of town. A lovely hotel.

Santa Cruz de la Palma, Spain

review_body: Hotel close to Caesar Palace. Very nice view from the rooms. Staff very helpful and nice. Rooms are very standard in terms of Japanese hotel accommodation: small, clean with all necessary things. Small bathroom with basic cosmetics. Breakfasts very nice - I recommend traditional Japanese breakfast set. Definitely the best start of exploring Japan.

This hotel is a A $ 20.00 cab ride from Tokyo Central train station.You can walk it if you don't have much luggage by following the jogging track around the gardens as it is located on the direct opposite side of the palace to Tokyo Station.The rooms were a good size and immaculate .We had a good value lunch though the breakfast was rather sparse.Only downside was that it was rather pricey and there is no concierge baggage to room service.We were able to purchase basic needs from local shops which are a few minutes walk away.

My wife and I spent almost a week at the Grand Arc Hanzomon.Our room was small, pretty typical of hotels in this price range in Japan.The room was clean. The bed was comfortable and the air conditioning worked well.The staff was friendly and helpfulThe location is hard to beat. A short walk to two major subway lines.I loved being right across from the path around the Imperial Palace grounds and went jogging on it 3 mornings during my stay.It's a 20 minute walk to the shopping just South of Tokyo Station

So it is an average 3 star hotel. OK for a business stay, but would not stay here if travelling personally.Checkin: was OK, the staff speak English fairly well and was given WiFi password. Which worked for half a day as on Monday the password is reset and a new one is generated(?). Be aware of this.Rooms: Rooms are tiny even for Japan standards. The bed was squashed up against the wall - it was just enough for 1 person to move. There is a huge amount of hidden engineering in the room to make comfortable. For example the floor in the bathroom has a big incline, so the toilet seat buffers are different heights to keep the seat level. The toilet engineering has been covered in various posts, so will skip this plumbing marvel. The kettle has extra button that makes it inconvenient, but at least there is one. There is not enough room to open a bigger suitcase. Asking for an iron, I got one, but again over engineered. But no place to set it up.Slept OK though.Breakfast: You have a limited choice of US (scrambled eggs and ham), continental (yogurt and a couple of rolls) and Japanese a mixed concoction of weirdness for a western pallet. I tried the Japanese, but asked for black tea - was charged handsomely for this, despite this being just a simple substitution. Facilities: Website claims "outdoor pool" and also fitness center. Hotel has NOTHING.It is primarily used for events on function floors.Location: OK, it is close to a couple of Metro stations, but basically you are next to the Royal Palace grounds so quiet and not much happening. There are few restaurants, but basically you will use Metro for any trips.Summary: I was there on business as office is close by - If I stayed personally it would definitely NOT be first choice. Be aware if you do anything "off standard" you will be charged, and not by a small amount. Rooms were noisy at night, quite a bit of police activity.

I hadn’t been to Tokyo before and reviews suggested that Chiyoda or Shibuya were good neighbourhoods. Chiyoda is more central, so we chose this neighbourhood and hotel. It’s a fine place - rooms are very small but that’s common with hotels in Tokyo (and japan more generally). The subway Hanzomon is literally 3 min away, and there are a number of coffee shops, family Marts/7-11/lawsons nearby if you fancy buying food instead of eating out. There’s also plenty of restaurants. We didn’t eat at the hotel. There are pleasant shrines and temples nearby. The imperial palace garden, parliament and theatre are also within 20 min walk. The next metro station, Nagatacho, is well catered for most lines. I’d recommend getting a day metro pass for 600 yen (basically, over three trips per 24 hs and it’s worth it). Shibuya is also on the purple hanzomon line so from the hotel you can be in Shibuya in 15 min. Overall a great place. Cleaning staff were attentive and replenished shampoo and others every day ( there’s a generous supply of everything including make up cleaner, lotion and face foam, which is a nice touch). The toilet is an experience - you need a PhD in engineering to figure out how to use it for the first time- but you’ll see these toilets everywhere (including public stations). The best part of the hotel is the spectacular view of Chiyoda (day and night). I read reviews that check in wasn’t very pleasant - I guess most tourists from Europe will arrive jet lagged early morning. Be mindful check in is at 2pm (although they let us in at 1pm). There’s no vending machine or complimentary stuff in the shared areas but if you sneak into a floor, they are there. Better yet, hoof it to family Mart in 3 min and get what you want.

It is hard to find fault with this hotel, located in a very convenient but less than happening area of Tokyo (close to the Imperial Palace grounds, embassies, businesses and government/political offices). The subway stop is close by, allowing easy access to more lively areas of the city. The rooms are small by Western standards (which is to be expected for Tokyo and completely normal) but very well appointed, organized and clean. Most of the rooms have fantastic views of the moat surrounding the palace and the business and government district surrounding the hotel. With the weddings and other events taking place at this hotel, you sort of feel that you are staying at a much more luxurious hotel. (By the way, it is not noisy at all.) It is definitely good value for money, and I would stay here again.

New York City, New York

review_body: The location of the hotel is perfect for those wanting to visit the Imperial Palace and the National Theatre. It is walking distance from the Budokan indoor arena where major concerts and major Sumo contests take place. The Hanzomon metro station is only 300 metres away with major shopping and entertainment centres of Tokyo only a few metro stops away. The hotel is not on any of the limousine bus routes from Narita or Haneda but it is not too hard to get there by public transport.The Room I had on the 11th floor was a little on the small size but not a surprise for Tokyo. I had a great view from my floor. The room was very clean. The shower worked well and there was bath (albeit a small one) which is becoming increasingly unusual in standard hotel rooms around the world. The toilet as is often the case in Japan is a jet toilet and for those who have not been to Japan before are in for a surprise. I stayed here over a weekend and there were a couple of weddings taking place but this was not a problem at all and did not disturb at all.The staff were excellent. Nothing was too much trouble and answered all the questions I had. Very helpful staff. I only ate breakfast at the hotel which is presented in a very pleasant area. My rate included breakfast and looking at the price was reasonable. It is not a buffet style system and there was not a great deal of it but for me enough to satisfy.There are a number of 24-hour shops in the area (as there are everywhere in Japan) and a few restaurants but this is more of a quieter area of Tokyo so if you are looking for wall restaurants and bars, take a quick metro or taxi ride.Overall my experience was excellent. I Will certainly stay here again for the price I paid and I look forward to returning.

A decent hotel in a good location in the business and diplomatic area. The staff were very friendly and the rooms were clean.We took one of the Japanese style rooms, which are made up as living areas during the day then converted to Japanese sleeping in the evening. This involved futons on the floor with pillows and quilts. We asked for and received extra pillows. Contrary to expectations it was actually quite comfortable. The drawbacks with the room, in common with many hotels in Tokyo are the lack of space for effective manipulation of suitcases and the bizarre need to purchase a card to watch television. This would have been worth it if there had been anything decent to watch in English! The effective WiFi meant that this was not necessary as we could watch our own programmes on iPads etc.The hotel coffee shop was a disappointment for dinner and the breakfast, to be frank, was awful. The American breakfast offering of runny scrambled eggs and anaemic bacon was disappointing and in my case was cold so I sent it back asking for a hot serving only to get the original back after a quick zap in the microwave! It might be better to skip breakfast there and find a local coffee shop which offers more palatable fare.

Room a bit on the small size, but this is Tokyo. Fabulous view from 12th floor room. Very helpful staff. Amazing bathroom, the shower was great & the toilet has to be experienced to be believed!! Receptionist organised for our large bags to be transported from the hotel direct to the airport, & provided us a note in Japanese to show anyone at the airport so they could direct us to where our bags could be collected. Fantastic!

We had an offsite meeting for a whole day at Topaz room. We also enjoyed lunch which was excellent. The foods were great as well as the services. We realized it because it was a subsidiary of Imperial hotel or Teikoku hotel, one of the best quality hotels in Japan.

We only stayed here for one night, our room was just a basic standard room that we booked for the price more than anything else.Everything was 100% clean with a comfortable bed again Japan style jammed up against the wall. A nice bathroom with a relaxing enjoyable bathtub. But best of all was our view of the city from our 10th floor room, truly amazimg.My wife described the AC as smelling if dust. One slight annoyance was that on check in a deposite was taken for the mini bar, but we found it to be empty when we arrived into our room.Overall a very nice hotel

In July I stayed together with my daughter for 10 days at this beautiful hotel. It’s a great location in central Tokyo where we enjoyed beautiful views over the Royal Palace area. It’s also a very quiet place with little traffic. I was surprised about the very large and comfortable bedroom with two single beds and much space. The bathroom was also clean and and well maintained. We did enjoy daily breakfast at the restaurant, all employees and the managers were very friendly and helpful in any situation. I will certainly be back again.

I have stayed at the Grand Arc Hanzomon a few times over the past 20 years. The location is great. It is situated two blocks from the Hanzomon subway station, on the Hanzomon line, with easy access to Akasaka Mitsuke, Shibuya, Sky Tree and the Tokyo City Air Terminal. Many rooms look out onto the Imperial Palace grounds, and views of the Tokyo skyline are really nice. One can jog around the Palace perimeter in 30-45 minutes without having to dodge traffic. The National Theatre is situated right next door. Hotel staff are helpful and efficient. As might be expected, the hotel is spotlessly clean. I can recommend the traditional Japanese breakfast, although western options are also available. A web search will reveal that the Grand Arc is very competitively priced. I can't imagine staying anywhere else.

A good room in a reasonable location - the area is quiet and it is a 20 minute taxi ride from Tokyo station; there is a local subway to get out and explore.The breakfast situation is odd, with staff leaving people standing around at the restaurant entrance because of a byzantine serving arrangement - many people who had flights or trains to catch had to give up on having breakfast because of the poor organisation - staff were indifferent to comments or feedback around this. As a business hotel one should be able to expect a prompt and efficient access to breakfast rather than the laboured and poorly organised service on show. The hotel has no room service or facilities to eat after 9pm which should also be borne in mind if you should be checking in late. Reception desk staff were polite but also indifferent to feedback.If you stay here I would suggest leaving 1.5 hours to comfortably have breakfast.

Great hotel with great view over Imperial Palace Park also all cherry blossoms around the park. Friendly staff and very sweet old lady who did the cleaning everyday. We never had any food at the hotel but there are few restaurants inside the hotel. Hanzomon station is just few steps behind the hotel but don’t get locked to this station only there are few more just mins walk from the hotel, specially Kojimachi station look at all these stations before leaving anywhere because some of them may go straight to your destination instead of changing two or 3 times. That will save you same money. With the view and how clean and central the hotel to all big names around Tokyo I would say it’s worth it. Pro tip - get a pocket WiFi before you get here to Tokyo or get it at the Airport! Because it will be very difficult to find one when you leave the airport.

Wonderful hotel.We had a very pleasant stay.Great view from the window.Comfortable room,good size.Staff very friendly(special mention for breakfast staff).Very good breakfast.Wonderful location.Highly recommend. We will choose the same hotel next time.

I got here with a very high fever from Los Angeles.I emailed them the day before asking if it was possible to get a room that early and they never answered.At the desk the 2 guys didn’t speak English at all and kept just saying “check in at 2o’clock”.So I had to leave and I spent five hours in a movie theatre and 2 walking around.I come back feeling so bad and took forever to get a room,I asked for a glass of water and the lady at the desk said “no no water in the room”,and guess what there was no water in the room and you should never refuse to give a glass of water to anyone.The rooms are clean and the view is very cool but is not enough with the service.I would not recommend this place to anyone and I ll never come back.

This hotel is well located near the Imperial Palace and accessible by the Hanzomon metro station.The room is quite small (welcome to Tokyo) but clean. Nice view of the city from the 9th floor we stayed.Restaurant for breakfast at the ground floor is available and propose good menus.Service was professional.

the hotel was clean, service was very good. location is quiet and a good place to retreat to after hustle and bustle of Tokyo. there are nearby shops and restaurants which are convenient. hanzomon station is just a few minutes away and makes most places within Tokyo accessible, the added bonus is the proximity of chigadorifuchi park where we viewed beautful cherry blossoms. Hotel accomodated our requests of side by side rooms, on a high floor, and with a great view of the imperial palace!

This was a very conveniently placed hotel with a great view of the park(from floor 13). The room was quiet, and room and bath were clean, if a little on the smallish side. I asked for a non-smoking room with a view - and received it. It is not too expensive considering it is in close to the city and the underground. The staff were friendly and very helpful with reservations, taxi etc. Overall a good hotell to stay in.

We stayed in this hotel for five nights. We chose the smallest room but it was still a bit bigger than other hotel room. Surprisingly, two small luggages were able to store in the room and there was still enough space for us to move around. The room was very quiet that we never heard any sound from outside even though our room was quite close to the elevators. Personally, we concern the quality of bathroom the most when we choose a hotel. The bathroom was clean and tidy, the shower was stable and the multifunctional toilet made us felt amazed! Besides, the hotel was just 3 minutes walk from the metro station, it was very convenient. Regarding the breakfast, we didnt have breakfast in the hotel as some people complained the small portion of breakfast. We had breakfast in Matsuya (松屋）everyday, it was around 5 mins walk from hotel. All in all, our stay in this hotel was wonderful. The room was cozy and comfortable. We will stay in this hotel again and may choose a bigger room.

Trivago found this fab room at the right price. I was nervous that a small room with a three-quarter bed might be primitive. Imagine our surprise when we walk in to discover an elegant hotel, right across from the Imperial Palace, to boot!It had everything, and then some. View, comfort, lots of plugs for charging, pyjamas, slippers, a very fancy toilet of course, and a shower whose controls required a PhD, to say nothing of the slot for the door card that connects the lights.The restaurant was a pleasure, a mixture of Japanese and French food.The location was 2 blocks from the metro station.Staff were great too.

Stayed for almost 8 days in this hotel and it has been a wonderful experience staying here. Room is always clean and well made when we got back from our Tokyo adventures and it only 5 minutes walk to the Hanzomon station (exit 1). There is Family Mart as well as Kitchen Origin opposite the station. There are several restaurants as well around the area. Front desk were very helpful and always ready to assist in anything from booking of restaurant or taxi services. Taxi from Haneda airport for a sedan type cab is about ¥6500. Prices may vary and may be more than this if you are traveling past midnight.

Just back from a 4 night stay with my family of 7. We took 4 rooms.We arrived in Haneda. Took the monorail to the final stop, then switched to a cab to the hotel. About JPY1,500.Room size is small, typical of Tokyo hotels. Functional for 2. Clean. Staff spoke good English. There are a few restaurants 5 minutes walk away. There is also a convenience store. Honzomon Station about 7 minutes walk away. The station has a lot of stairs. Not child friendly. It is a 30 minute walk from the main Asakasa restaurant, shopping, entertainment belt. The downside to this hotel was the location (for me). I chose this hotel based on a review that it is near Tokyo Station. (needed the Shinkansen) sigh... IT IS NOT NEAR TOKYO STATION! it is JPY2,000 cab ride away. Ginza would have been nearer. (my fault, should have checked but was super busy with work).Because we had young children in the group, we had to cab everyday. The money we spent cabbing could have gotten us a nicer hotel. Not to mention the time wasted traveling. We spent JPY5,000 on cabs per room per day. Conclusion, the hotel has good hardware and software. Location-wise - it's not good for travelers who are not familiar with Tokyo. Not good for people with young children. It is good for people who want peace and quiet. And for people looking for a nice place to jog (around the palace).

I spent three nights at this excellent hotel and was quite pleased by everything - impeccable cleanliness, surprisingly spacious rooms, excellent Japanese breakfast, friendly staff... Well, the same can be said about many business hotels. What I really liked about the Grand Arc Hanzomon is that it has a distinct Japanese "feel" about it. Unlike so many business hotels that seem identical no matter where you are, here you KNOW you're in Japan which can make it an option worth considering for vacationers, also.

I read so many reviews on this place & they were all positive so I was so excited to stay here & it didn’t disappoint! We were lucky enough to get the most perfect room with an amazing view that I could have looked at all day! The amenities were great especially the deep bath which I found myself in nearly every night. The ground floor restaurants food was delicious though I was a bit shocked at how much a coke costs! I loved the atmosphere, the staff and the location which we found easy enough to walk to the train station or even to ginza. (That is about a 2km walk but we didn’t mind at all) Plenty of restaurants & little supermarkets close by too. We will definitely stay here again :)

We enjoyed our stay at this hotel It was a bit difficult using subway as Hanzoman Line is not on JR route so JR pass was not able to be used. That meant we had to buy a Suica Pass or pay 170Y every time we used subway it was a short walk but go around the corner for the elevator if you don't want to walk 3 flights of stairs. Local area was pleasant and view from our room was wonderful Staff very courteous and helpful Continental breakfast was a good start to the day at 1000Y. Beds were comfortable and bath was lovely and deep. Overall nice, quiet , away from busy areas.

Situated conveniently close to Hanzomon station which is just on the right when walking out the street and crossing road at traffic lights, also, only three subway stops to Tokyo Station where all city transportation and Limousine bus to Airport are located. Good value to have a comfortable fair size room with suitable facilities and panoramic views to the city and the Imperial Palace garden. It could be more impressive if the hotel lobby can be renovated and decorated more decently with an up-graded modern design. Overall customer service is satisfactory and staff are polite.

This hotel is located close to our Embassy and was the perfect choice for work reasons. I would stay again but next time ask for a bigger room as they can be quite small. Great views across to the Emperors compound

Nice business style hotel, wonderful Japanese breakfast. Room is clean, small but good size for two. Beautiful city view of imperial palace and Tokyo tower. 2-3 minutes walk to subway. Staff English is ok.

Comfortable stay, room was a good size even if it was a bit tired looking with dated furnishings & older style bathroom fittings. Like other older Japanese hotels, they've struggled to totally eradicate the stale smoke smell from the rooms but don't wish to sound too negative, as there's lots to recommend this place. Handy location for Hanzomon metro & nice walks in the Palace grounds. Quiet night's sleep, great views of the city & helpful staff. Although it didn't cause us any problem, the 10:00am check out time wasn't comparable to other similar hotels we stayed at.

Very good location, 200m to Hanzomon metro station.Convenience store 100m away.Polite, helpful staff. Few perks I have never seen in Europe - umbrella for free, Febreeze to refresh your clothes in every room. Smoking rooms available.WiFi works great. Great Japanese restaurant in level B2.No airport transfers ( but with metro so close, whats the point?).Bit expensive late check in. I needed to stay till 3pm - over 5000yen.Room on 16th floor, view of Tokyo downtown at night - unforgettable;) Would definitely stay again !

Very well located hotel, near Imperial Palace. We had a room with very nice view to the palace gardens. Metro station very near with different exits plus lift and escalators. So easy with luggage. Room had a good size, very clean and quiet. Loads of eateries around, for every taste. Plus food market two blocks away with everything you need.

I enjoyed staying here. The hotel is located near Hanzomon metro station and the Imperial Palace. It is a quiet part of Tokyo, with some good restaurants and cafes near by, though not the best place if you are looking to be near nightlife. Check in is efficient, although it could be friendlier. The rooms are tiny, as you would expect in Tokyo, but they are extremely clean and well maintained. Wifi and TV are excellent. The room could do with more plugs though, especially near the bed. Breakfast is a set menu, and you have a choice of Japanese, Continental or American. All are good and filling. Service at the restaurant is excellent. My only complaint of the hotel is the 10am check out time, which seems is too early, though they are happy to hold any luggage if your flight is later in the day and you want to return and collect it. All staff speak English. I enjoyed my stay here and would stay here again.

Attending a conference in Tokyo, I stumbled upon this hotel and what a great find. Amazing views, nice size rooms, and attentive staff. Next to the hotel is the National Thearter, and Supreme Court Building. Right outside the hotel, is a gorgeous jogging path meandering through the Imperial Palace - if you're not a jogger, the walk is pretty spectacular. Lots of coffee places and restaurants near the surrounding area for small bites or quick meal. Conveniently located to the train station - 4-5 stops to Tokyo Station where you can take the Airport Limosine to Narita. The only drawback is a check out time @ 10:00 am - doesn't seem fair. Otherwise a great place to stay and enjoy the city.

Check in was pretty fast and easy. The staffs were friendly and they were able to understand English. Staffs were also helpful with getting taxis for tours and ride back to the airport.Had a double room, pretty small compared to western hotels but it worked for us since we were out during the day and only needed a place to sleep. The view from the room was super good though.Wi-fi and TV was pretty good. One downside is that there's no outlet next to the bed, well there aren't many outlets.Food at the hotel itself was ok. The sushi down in the basement was pretty good.Overall it was a pleasant stay, I would stay again if i'm ever in the same area.

This was a fantastic and affordable hotel. I think my actual rating would be a 4.5/5 but I rounded up because I believe there were a number of amenities that other people could take advantage.I will start with my one con. I thought there weren't enough electrical outlets or that the ones present were too far from the bed.Otherwise this was one of the more comfortable and nicer hotels I stayed at during the trip. I would like to stay there again!

Well located i.e. central to the main attractions. Amazing view of Tokyo, especially at night from the bar on 4th floor. Quiet neighborhood. Three hotel restaurants to choose from. Rooms, depending on your choice from small to large ones, Western or Japanese style. Service room every day. Bathrooms comfortable.

I attended the hotel on business for 10 days. I found the hotel extremely clean and the staff was friendly with outstanding service. However, the hotel has limited restaurants with one on the main floor that closes relatively early as well as their lounge on the 4th floor both close by 11pm. The lobby shop is extremely tiny. If you are looking for shops and restaurants I recommend either via walking 30min, taxi 5-10 or Tokyo Metro 10min-15min to go into the Ginza shopping district. You will find that Tokyo is very clean and safe. The Tokyo Metro train is very user friendly. Signage and train announcements will change from Japanese to English for ease and level of comfort for those who read/understand English. Using the train ticket dispensers are equally easy and offer a language option. It's roughly $170 JPY ($1.95 Canadian, $1.54US or $1.20 Pound Sterling) to get from the hotel to Ginza district.The hotel can provide you with umbrellas as well as maps. I also suggest to ask for a Hotel flyer that provides a map and address of the hotels location in the event you take a taxi so that the driver knows exactly where to take you back to the hotel. The front desk staff will call a taxi service for you if requested. Again I have traveled extensively around the globe and found Tokyo to be one of the cleanest and safest cities I have visited. The rooms are very clean and most toilets in the City including the hotel are Toto wet wash with seat warmer and bidet features. Rooms may vary in size - my room was compact but very functional. Note that Tokyo has strict smoking laws you cannot smoke outside unless in designated signed areas and the hotel has two smoking areas on the 3rd and 4th floors. It's a $2000 JPY fine to smoke in areas that are prohibited. . As a non smoker with business colleagues that are smokers I wanted to add this Vending machines in the hotel are plentiful and offer a variety of beverages, snacks and cigarettes.I hope this has been useful.

Hotel Grand Arc Hazamon is a good business hotel. I had a room overlooking the Royal Palace gardens. As usual for Japan the room was small not what I expect for a double room.The cleaning staff were extremely polite and the room was very clean. I had a problem with the TV and reported it to the reception the next morning. They must have though stupid foreigner as three members of staff appeared with a remote control and started to tell me how to push the buttons. I eventually got through to them, they said that they would check it out. When I returned later that evening there was a message on the room telephone. I contacted reception and a member of staff advised that the tv in my room has problems, and there was no problem with the remote. Their solution was for me to change rooms, why they did not just replace the TV with a working one from another room I’ll never know?. So I was moved to room 2 doors down the hall, a mirror image of the room I was moved from. I was hoping for a bigger room, but they did give me 2 free drinks vouchers (soft drinks only) for use only in the hotel restaurant while enjoying an expensive meal. I passed. The down side was that there were no English speaking channels.

If you stay here, it is definitely for the amazing view across the city and the moat. We managed to book while reduced/on offer one day, for the 9 night duration of our stay in Japan. The hotel is in a very nice area with lots of restaurants and shops nearby.The Hamzomon station of the Hamzomon line is within walking distance and generally wasn't too busy, even at rush hour, for travelling to the rest of the city via Tokyo Station, Shibuya or Shinkjuku from Hamzomon. We stayed here and then travelled out for day trips to Kyoto, Yokohama, Mt Fuji, Kamakura and of course the districts of Tokyo. The room we had was fairly small, with the double bed pushed against the wall, but think we had a budget room. There are tea making facilities and a television in the room, and all the toiletries are provided. Everything was very clean, and the bed neatly made and fresh towels each day. The hotel lobby is also very smart and staff very friendly and helpful, despite our terrible Japanese. Everyone is very polite too.We tried the breakfast one day, and although it was nice I felt it was a bit pricey for what you got, so we usually went to the corner shop down the road. I wanted to try the dinner but we ended up finding a fantastic yakitori restaurant nearby which we ended up going to instead.Despite maybe sounding a bit moany above, we had an absolutely fantastic time here and felt it was great value for money for the deal we found. I would highly recommend it to anyone travelling to Tokyo and would say to at least stay here for one night. We will be booking again on our next visit!

This hotel seems to be located in the business area of Tokyo. It is located near a JR Line entrance, which is not the same as the Tokyo Metro. Theres not much around if you only plan to walk to places but the JR line can almost take you anywhere in the city.The hotel itself is clean, and nice. Probably better for families.

The room we were staying in was on the small side and the bed was definitely too small for 2 tall Dutch people. Having said that, the hotel had an amazing view of down town Tokyo and the Imperial Gardens :) I would rate the bathroom so-so. It was very clean, it just looked a but out-dated to me.Breakfast options are great as well: choose between an American breakfast (eggs different styles, toast, ham or bacon), continental breakfast (yoghurt, toast, fruit) or a traditional Japanese breakfast. Coffee and (green) tea are available and included.It is more of a business hotel, so expect lots of people in black suits. Staff was very friendly!

We were pleasantly surprised with this hotel. Set opposite the Imperial Palace Moat with a view of Tokyo Tower it was in a very pleasant area. Near the National Theatre, and within walking distance of Parliament. Our room was a good size and clean. The bed and pillow were hard, like many beds in Japan! Quite a classy area. We had a continental breakfast in the morning; not nice. No cereal, just breads, a croissant and yoghurt with a few berries. The price was quite a lot cheaper than a hotel we had in Shinjuku and much much nicer.

Ask for a room on a high floor overlooking the imperial palace gardens. We had reserved the least expensive double room and it was the least expensive room of our entire 3 week vacation in Japan, so good value for the price. It was so small no room to open 2 bags except we could get my bag shoved into a tiny niche in the room. Great location for a walk around the Imperial Palace. Breakfast in hotel pricey, but right down the street was a Dotour coffee/breakfast which had great double cappuccinos and a yummy "croque monsieur" cheese/ham on toasted bread which we had both mornings of our stay. Just beyond the Dotour was a fabulous boulangerie (called "bread") on the hotel's local map - great place to pick up sandwiches to take to a National Theater performance or for our Shinkansen ride to Kyoto or bakery items for an afternoon snack. The subway stop just around the corner was very handy. We took a taxi to the train station when we left Tokyo to travel to Kyoto as we had large bags for our 3 week trip.

Nearest metro station: Hanzomon (lots of stairs - less than a 5-minute walk to the hotel). When you are in front of the station, cross the street and go to your right side and turn the first street on your left. The hotel is after the first block.Just stayed for one night and we arrived there on a downpour day. If you haven't booked an early check-in (there is a supplement informed on their website), they do not seem to let you check-in before 2 PM. They do have a luggage room and they will store for you for free.We had a room on the sixth floor and it was compact (not good for those who have a lot of luggage - we had 2 pieces and left at the entrance of our door/bathroom) and clean but in need of a renovation (70's or 80's feel). The double-bed was 140cm large, so it is considered small for western standards. There was an empty mini-bar, a kettle, some tea bags (I don't recall them having any coffee sticks). The best thing about the room was the view. As it was raining, the view wasn't that great but at night, it looked something out of a postcard!!!!The bathroom had the best ammenities from all the hotels I have stayed. They even provided oil blotting papers!!!The breakfast was included in our rate and we had the option of having the Japanese one or western one. Honestly, it wasn't worth it. It comes with a fruit juice (not freshly squeeze), a hot drink and a toast with butter (salty) and jam on the side and an egg (small portion of scrambled egg). There is a very nice bistro-like cafe across the metro station called "Kojimachi Cafe" (not handicapped friendly as there is a flight of steep stairs to go their restaurant). You can have a main dish and dessert for less than 3,000 yen. It wasn't the cheapest but the quality was great and very tasty.

We booked the semi double room, it was exceptionally small, but worth the price to be honest, the views of the city are great, the nearest metro station is hanzomon and is 5 minutes walking, there is also a bus stop 3 minutes away from the hotel and can get you to other major metro stations, neighborhood is quite and safe at night, so it suites families very well.I highly recommend this hotel if you don't mind the small size of the rooms, or if you upgrade to the bigger size one.

Check in late on Sunday night after a long flight from Melbourne.Could not find any fault, staff were very courteous, helped me with a few maps etc.Room was nice, clean, had all the stuff I need, bed was terrific- better than my one at home- also lived the bathroom with the high tech dunny!Seemed to be a great location for what I wanted to do. Just a few minutes walk to a metro station.Price was ok for me.Definitely recommend

If you are staying in this hotel there is no need to visit skyscapers with views. I could see Tokyo Tower and royal gardens.The room was okey, not small. Staff is also good.I expected something special about breakfast, but food was just OK. I recommend this hotel for staying!

We traveled around japan for 3 weeks & our last stop was tokyo for 5 days. This clean and comfy buisness hotel was perfect as a starting point to explore the city. The subway is nearby & it's directly located at the imperial palace gardens. For this location the price per room/ night is very affordable. The breakfast is a bit expensive though. But there are plenty of opportunities around to get your stomach filled :)

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights and couldn't have been more delighted with it. The rooms were large and comfortable. The views were great and the location was perfect for getting around Tokyo. Just 3 mins walk from the Hanzamon line (exit 1). A litre tricky on public transport from Haneda with 3 or so changes but doable and once there just great!

We stayed at this hotel on our first visit to Tokyo. All of the reviews are correct - the rooms and small and in parts tired but the staff are wonderful and the location sensational. We arrived at Tokyo Station from Narita airport and got a taxi ($20 Aus) to the hotel. For the rest of our stay we used the Metro which was a less than 5 minute walk. The view from our room was spectacular- overlooking Imperial Gardens with the Tokyo Tower in the distance. We would highly recommend using this hotel as a base for your stay in Tokyo.

The view was worth a million dollars. The customer service was great. Everyone at the front desk seemed to speak at least some English so that was helpful. If you follow the directions the hotel was easy to get to from the subway. Coming out of door 1 was the easiest and there is a map on the street that shows the hotel right when you leave the subway area. Be warned it is a lot of steps! There's a coffee shop just up the street that seems to be a local chain. They were great for breakfast. Or the hotel offered breakfast as well. The room was beautiful and clean. They offered many amenities like toothbrush lotion shampoo razor so no need to pack all of those things. I would love to stay here again. It is a quick walk to Tokyo station and a beautiful stroll thru the gardens.

Good location for those doing business in this area. Room is large for Tokyo standards, amenities are simple. My room is on the fifteenth floor and water pressure in the shower is a dribble. I will not be staying here again despite the proximity to my office.

If you are looking for a decent hotel in a quiet distract in Tokyo, then this is the one for you. The hotel is just only 5 minutes’ walk from exit 3, Hanzomon Station. If you carry heavy luggage with you, then better use exit 5 where there’s a lift.Hotels in Tokyo on a Saturday night are expensive and we found that The Grand Arc offered a very reasonable price for a 18 square meter double room with 140cm width bed on the Sat. night we stayed. The room was clean, comfortable and came with a great view that was facing the Imperial Palace garden where lots of locals were doing the running on the Sunday morning.Choice of dining around the hotel was a bit limited since it’s not located in the tourist area. However, there were a few convenient stores nearby.

The room was nice and big enough for two people. It was pretty clean, and the staff cleaned the room every day, even taking all of our huge amounts of daily trash away. We got new free bathroom items and tea everyday. They even had vending machines in the hallway and had a few konbini stores just a few minutes away from the hotel. The hotel itself looked very professional. There was even two huge parks just 20 minutes away from the hotel by foot, which makes a great afternoon walk.Overall, very pleased. If there's something to complain about, the bed felt like sleeping on a big brick and the duvet was very thin. We're used to a rather soft mattress and huge, fluffy duvets.(Visited: June 2015)

I booked this hotel a long time ago to ensure that we could get a room. It was a great location, not too far from Tokyo station or subway. We love to walk around outside of Imperial Palace. We woke up early and got to see the beautiful sunrise with Tokyo Tower. Staffs there are super nice and work efficiently. We will stay there again for sure.

Our room in another location, without the view, would rate a three or four. Small, a large double bed, along one wall, perhaps originally designed for one occupant. Only one bed reading light, and overall not the best lighting arrangement, a standard lamp in one corner, and a strip light over the desk. Desk with drawers, fridge under, only green tea making facilities with small bowls. Windows could not be opened, however a large, efficient air humidifier kept the room comfortable. Bathroom small; as are most Japanese bathrooms, though this bathroom was an awkward layout. Good thick towels. Both Front Reception and Breakfast Staff were welcoming. Our breakfast, (we chose American-other choices Continental and Japanese) was of small portion, good, freshly prepared. We asked for some additional toast, which was quickly and happily supplied. The overnight rate for the hotel was reasonable for the location.

Grand arc hotel is an amazing choice close to hanzomon underground station (Z08) and with a breathtaking view on the Emperor's garden. We were at 15th floor and we could enjoy a great view at night.Rooms are small as in every Japanese hotel but totally comfy. Great bathroom and facilities (vending machine and Ice at the floor).Breakfast is good, not a buffet style offer, but good especially because everything is prepared fresh (bread, eggs and bacon are made after the order).Very kind personnel. Every time I pass here in Tokyo I choose this hotel, also because there are many small restaurants in the neighborhood (or you can jump on the tube and feel the fresh of Shibuya in 10 minutes).

I spent weeks researching hotels for our trip to Japan and eventually came across this one. I am so glad I did because I could not really fault it for what was a really decently priced hotel for Tokyo.Our room was small (but this is usual in Japan from what I can tell) but it was perfect for the two of us - comfortable, was cleaned every day and had everything we personally needed. My partner is notoriously known in our family for being hard to please when it comes to sleeping in anything other than his own bed, and he slept very well every night we were here. We were located up on the 13th floor and had a lovely view of the moat of the gardens to the imperial palace and a view of Tokyo Tower.Most staff we spoke to spoke English - some just very basic broken English, but this was more than enough to get through ordering food at breakfast, and they were all very polite.We ate breakfast in the restaurant in the hotel every morning, and offered 3 options for breakfast - Japanese, continental and American. The American breakfast probably isn't what you normally would expect it to be and probably a lot smaller, but we really enjoyed what was offered. We ate in this restaurant once for lunch and dinner and the food was lovely.The nearest station is Hanzomon Metro station which is about a 2 minute walk down the road. Although it doesn't offer a direct route to Tokyo station but you only have to change lines for 1 stop and then your there and didn't take long at all.Although not something you probably look for in a hotel - we were there during a big earthquake in November 2016 (I think 7.3 on the richter scale) and the building did sway and creeked a bit but all was good!If we were to ever visit Japan again I would not hesitate to stay here again.

First of all, the room overlooked the little island surrounded by water that houses the Imperial Palace. It was truly gorgeous, especially just past sundown. The room was smallish, but I really didn't care because it was an incredibly thrifty option that didn't feel terribly thrifty as it is a super lovely area of Tokyo. There are nice little restaurants and coffee shops nearby, I didn't check out the restaurant on the premises. The front desk staff was helpful and genteel. Loved it and I'd go back!
user_name:
Nancy O
New York City, New York

review_body: Just arrived into Tokyo and check into the for a night sleep with the family before we board the train for Nagano. Hotel is located near the Palace and only 10 mins to the Tokyo Railways. We stayed at the Japanese Style room for 3. Small but clean and tidy. Breakfast was included (choice of continental or Japanese) and the price for 3 of us come up to around US$145, not bad for Tokyo. If you are looking for shopping then this is not your stop.

Great situation in Central Tokyo overlooking the Imperial Palace Gardens and with a view of Tokyo Tower. Two minute walk from Exit One of Hanzomon Subway Station. Good standard hotel; usual small Japanese room with everything you need for your comfort and very quiet. Very helpful English speaking staff. Would definitely stop here again.

The location is awesome and the view of Tokyo skyline absolutely stunning. It takes roughly 5 minutes to get the hotel from the Subway. If you have a heavy luggage you'd be better off taking the exit number 2 with a bit longer walk to the hotel. Exit number 1 doesn't have an escalator nor elevator. The room was very well cleaned every day. Very good value for the money.

The hotel was not easy to find if you do not know the way. We were lost and had to ask for directions at Family Mart. The booking website mentioned that Exit 1 was nearest but Exit 3 has escalator so we took Exit 3. Turned out, there was still a flight of stairs to tackle at Exit 3. What a bummer.From the Family Mart, it was just straight ahead and round the corner. Not viewable from the train station exit side. Along the way, you'll pass by Japanese restaurants and a police station.The hotel room was smaller than expected but it has a nice view. There was even a card in the room that displayed the names of the building viewable from the window. But it's in Japanese though. Just realized that hotels in Japan do not provide coffee in the room. Only tea. No bottled water too. Not an issue as there's a vending machine on the same floor that we were given.The room was quiet and the airconditioner worked well in cold weather as it will be working as a heater instead. There's also a dehumidifier in the room. The bathroom was clean but its door can't be locked properly.If you walk towards the back of the hotel, there is a jogging path where many locals used during weekend. Walk along this path and you'll reach one of the gates of the Imperial Palace.At night, we were able to view Tokyo Skytree from our room on the 12th floor.Overall, a comfortable hotel for a good night's sleep.

We stayed in August 2016, and it was extremely hot in Tokyo. We had gone on a cruise then had three days in Tokyo. This hotel is not too far from the train, but we got lost (so it took us longer to get there). The staff was so helpful. They not only let us leave our bags for a couple of hours, but they also let us check in earlier. We had arrived before 11, and I believe we checked in at 12 or 1? The room was a smoking room which sucked. We do not smoke. Other than that, it was small compared to American hotels (which is expected). It was clean, and it had the most amazing view of the park. I loved it! There were a lot of convenience stores nearby, and the train was so close. We walked around at night (coming back from our adventures as late as 11 pm). I felt safe in the area. I would recommend this hotel if budget is important. I really liked it.

The hotel is in a neighborhood away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo's glitter and glitz. On the other hand, it is across the street to the (rear) entrance to the Imperial Palace park, which also houses several museums. But to get to Ginza and other places of street life you have to take the metro several stops, the entrance to which is 2 blocks away. The hotel, as seen from the outside, is a modern, high-rise tower of steel and glass, very impressive. The lobby is of the four-star variety, but the room... well, let's say we were glad not to have too much luggage, because it might not have fit in. The bed is squished into one corner, and there are two feet of walking room on the other two sides. That, plus the compact bathroom, is it. The TV has ONE English language channel, BBC World Service. On the positive side, the room had a nice view.So the way we see it, you can't take a three star room and put it in a five star slab of concrete and call yourself a luxury hotel. What do Americans call it? Putting lipstick on a pig. So, sorry, Grand Arc, we have to call it what it is, three stars.

Located near Nanzomon subway station and Imperial Palace. Small room but very clean. Friendly staff. Linen and towels changed every day.Breakfast in not buffet, there are 3 choices of set menus : american, continental and japanese. Each of which is small for someone who likes to start the day with a substantial breakfast

Great location with amazing views and a good size room compared to many in tokyo.I have stayed in cheaper hotels with ability to recharge mobiles etc via USB but this wasn't available here which was a minus point in this day and age of technology etc.Would definitely look to stop here again

The hotel is close to Hanzomon Metro station, around 300 m. We got a Japanese style room, which to be honest was not convenient. The room provided a fair space, no English TV channel. No coffee or drinking water provided! If planning to travel out of Tokyo by train or shinkansen, staying at this hotel is not a good idea. There is no direct Metro line from here to Tokyo or Ueno, however the hotel is very close to the Imperial Palace and has nice view surrounded.

All good The only thing is that its not on the line of the "jr" The staf is very very helpful The hotel is located near the palace and has beautiful view to the south of Tokyo.The room is enough for me and my wife and all our thingsTy hotell it was nise to be hear

The hotel location and restaurant staff are excellent.Front desk staff needs to be trained / counselled on being more helpful to guests, specifically w.r.t tourist and local travel information. The room size was extremely small and uncomfortable for a double room. We were checked in to room 804. 2 sides of the bed were blocked by walls, third side blocked by a chair and table which made access to the bed extremely difficult.

Pretty close to Imperial Palace on Island but less touristy compared to Shinjuku. Nearby train station is convenient but not covered by JR rail pass because it is a private one. Rooms are clean and adequate for Japan standard (i.e. very small). For more than 2 people in a room, try "traditional style" with mats on the floor as bed in regular room barely fits 2.Consider to purchase room with breakfast plan as it is like $10-12 more per day for 2 persons. If you change your mind later and want to eat, it will cost a lot more.Breakfast in Japanese style or Continental style with sunny side up eggs and bacons. Very good and could be the best fried egg I ever had - ? super organic one. I also enjoy authentic small eating places near the hotel.

I had a comfortable and clean room on the 11th floor with a great view. The room was of decent size with all amenities including satellite TV but I suspect foreign language channels (like BBC World Service) attract an extra charge. I paid ¥13,300 per night breakfast included. Otherwise breakfast is ¥1,300 extra and gives you two choices – American or Japanese. Breakfast starts at 7am. So be wary in case you plan an early start. I don’t know how but the coffee had a slight taste of vinegar. Staff have been friendly and there was no problem at no time to communicate in English. As far as I can tell there is no smoking in or anywhere close to the hotel. Hanzomon Station is within walking distance but I found it quite difficult to find my way when requiring the use of an elevator. All in all not a bad hotel if you want to explore different parts of Tokyo and don’t need to be in a particular part of the city.

The hotel staff was nice and the rooms were very clean. I could see some stains on the chair and carpet but I could tell it was because it was old. The room was quite small but I've been told most places in Tokyo is small. I did like the pressure of the shower water. I loved the beautiful view of Tokyo the most, we were on the 15th floor with the windows facing towards the Tokyo tower. This was the best feature of the room and hotel.The hotel is very close to the subway, but the closest subway had a lot of stairs and no elevator. Carrying suitcases up was a challange for me.

This hotel is great!! Pros: Wifi is great Close to a Tokyo metro station (Hanzomon) Room is clean with wonderful viewsFriendly staff Close to everything Very quiet - big must for me Accommodated food allergiesBed was comfy and so were the pillows Value for money!! Cons: Western breakfast is the same everyday and gets a little boring. This isn't a major con for me just more of a side note. I would stay again and recommend to anyone!!

Just 3' walk from Hanzomon subway station, some nice local restaurants in the area, ad a sunkus grocery store.. We had an awesome view from our 13rd floor room on the Imperial Gardens, Tokyo Tower.... Rooms are very well equipped, good bedware and reasonable size. Breakfast is nice, served at table (choice between continental, American and Japanese).. but a little more variation would be welcome for a longer stay. However, do try the Japanese breakfast, it is really nice. Staff is very very friendly....

The hotel is very close to Hanzomon station, which was really helpful as I was using the subway to get around Tokyo. The Hanzomon line makes it really easy to get to Ginza, Tokyo and Shibuya stations in particular. The location for the hotel itself is right across the road from the Imperial Palace and surround gardens, which is very picturesque! One morning I even walked around the gardens to get to Tokyo station which took about 30mins. There are some nice restaurants near the hotel, and I also ate at the Patio restaurant within the hotel which was lovely (they make an awesome cheeseburger!). The staff were all lovely and very helpful and my room was larger than other hotel rooms in Japan! The wifi worked well, which was great. I would definitely recommend staying at the Grand Arc if you don't feel the need to be right in the middle of all the neon of Shibuya and Shinjuku at night (they're only about 12 minutes away by train anyway!).

This hotel was more than what I expected especially since the pricepoint is on the lower end. We stayed in the 7th floor and had an awesome view of the Imperial Palace grounds and even the Tokyo Tower from afar! The rooms are small and the bathroom even smaller but it was extremely comfortable for 2 people. You'll definitely have to get close if you want to share the bed :) It's far enough away from the noise unlike Shinjuku, but very easy to get around to and from. It's literally across the street from the Imperial Palace so it's very easy to find. If you like quality with a steal of a price, you must stay here!

I have been going to this hotel each time I am in Tokyo for a long time. The hotel looks at the river and the Emperors Palace gardens and has magnificent views of Tokyo. Very nice staff who all speak English. Nice restaurants in the hotel. Good breakfast served to the table. Pleasant and nicely decorated rooms.

Upon check-in, the staff were very professional & helpful. We were presented with wifi code, room keys and breakfast voucher. The view from the 15th floor is amazing. The room & bed was spacious for Tokyo standards. The only criticism I could suggest was that there was no porterage offered and one would expect it given the room rate per night. The location of the property is close to a railway station.

I don't normally bother reviewing places that have hundreds of other reviews preferring instead to review places that need (and deserve) the attention. In this case, however, I am making an exception not because of the hotel itself but because of its location. The hotel's accommodation is, certainly, more than adequate - good a/c, clean rooms and lobby area and standard hotel-type decor. Its geographical location is, to be positive, on the quiet side and at least equally inconvenient for all the far-flung Tokyo sights (with the exception of the Imperial Palace gardens). Its food is unremarkable but perfectly acceptable. No, what makes this hotel so special and worthy of a review is the stunning night-time view. Like the "framed-picture" garden at Adachi, the sight of Maranouchi lit up at night with the Palace moat in the foreground framed by the large windows is sensational. We sat for ages watching the darkness lit up by the skyscrapers and the tropical storm clouds lashing themwith rain. To get that Hyatt Regency Lost in Transalation view at a fraction of the cost, look no further than this hotel.

Highlights: Wonderful view, very good value, staff were accommodating to my requests (in particular to helping me forward my luggage to my next hotel for a small fee).Downsides: Only main thing to mention would be that if you're staying long-term then the breakfast will quickly get boring. It however is nice and fairly fulfilling. Otherwise the hotel met all of my expectations.

The Japanese room is a bit small for three persons. After laying the mattresses on the tatami, there is almost no space for sitting. Also, there are not many restaurants and shops nearby the hotel.The bathroom is big and there is an additional wash basin outside the bathroom. The room has a great view of the Imperial Palace garden. The room rate is quite reasonable for a hotel in the center of Tokyo.

This hotel was amazing, for such an affordable price it felt so luxurious! We stayed in another area of Tokyo when we first arrived and then came to this hotel, and it was as if we were in another city! Right near the imperial palace which was amazing, the staff were friendly and helpful and the room was spotless and really nice and spacious. They also had vending machines on each floor which was an added bonus! We didn't eat at the restaurants but they seemed nice, and the other good thing was it was really close to a subway line which made it easy to get around! The staff also suggested a really helpful way to get to the airport that we wouldn't have figured out if we didn't ask!

The hotel was better than I thought it would be, room was big enough for me, always cleaned, staff friendly enough, could really improve on the breakfast, lots of restaurants around to eat at, the beds are hard but no harder than any other Asian hotel I have stayed at,

Hanzomon station is right across the street! Quality affordable Japanese food (Tempura Don; Yakitori; Sushi) where locals eat are within walking distance! Coffee shops and 24hr stores scattered around. Quiet area. Stayed here twice, and will stay again next time!

We stayed two nights in this hotel. Easy access from airport with Airport Limousine buses from Narita to Tokyo Palace hotel + a short taxi ride (approx 1200 Yen for the taxi).We had two rooms, one ordinary western style and one Japanese style. Beds are not very comfortable. Clean room, but small. Great view from the rooms. Friendly and efficient staff. Short walking distance to restaurants, supermarked and metro station (Hanzomon) with direct line to Tokyo Station, Shibuya...) Breakfast was ok, but not much food (fixed breakfast meny, but 3 choices). Over all, value for money. I could stay here again for a short stay.

Having stayed at the hotel for 5 nights two things have given ma a lasting impression. The first is a bad back, although the beds are firm (to my liking) they are uncomfortable, coupled with heavy pillows I did not get much sleep. Second, the hotel is boring and very beige! Don't get me wrong the hotel is in a good location away from the crowds with excellent links to the subway. The staff are super nice and helpful, I just wanted a little more. Maybe it's a Japan thing, let's hope it gets better as I have another 3 weeks in Japan.

Stayed here for three nights and was most impressed. Staff were very efficient, rooms were comfortable with good fittings and reasonable amount of space. We stayed on one of the higher floors and there were beautiful views across the Imperial Palace grounds. Is situated in a nice quiet neighborhood and is an easy walk from the subway station.

My fiancé and I spent a lot of time researching hotels in Tokyo. Our main criteria were room size, cost, location and room quality. From our research we found that a lot of the hotels in our price range seemed to have very similar rooms sizes and layouts. No matter where you go, the rooms in Tokyo are going to be small. Once we had resigned ourselves to a small room, we concentrated on our other criteria.We went for a western style room, we were on the 9th floor with a view over the Imperial Palace gardens. This view was a good selling point for us, although because of the angle you really just see a load of trees as the Palace itself is out of sight. Still, it was a nice view when the sun was out. The room was, as expected, small, but we made the most of it. The room was clean and comfortable. The bed wasn't as small as we were expecting. The bathroom was nice. A fairly powerful and hot shower, and a nice Japanese style toilet that my fiancé loved.The reception staff were courteous, helpful and spoke good English. The 24 hour reception was a plus point as we arrived late to check in. They were also happy to take delivery of a Japanese a SIM card for us before we arrived.We had booked breakfast with our room, which came as a choice of Japanese style and American style. The Japanese style was tried once and involved rice and fish based items. Wasn't really our cup of tea first thing in the morning! The American style involved eggs, potato things (like hash browns) and ham/bacon (although Japanese 'bacon' is slightly different to American/British, still tasty though).The location of the hotel is fantastic. It's less than a 5 minute walk to the Hanzomon line subway station, and is very central to the main tourist points in Tokyo. Next to the station there is a convenience store with very good Japanese style food, along with a couple of restaurants.All in all very happy with our stay at Grand Arc. Would definitely stay there again, and maybe even try out their restaurants (we never got back in time from sight seeing to try any of them!).

Stayed there during our first visit in Sep 2014 and came back in Apr 2016. The hotel is clean and decent. It's at a great location, 3 minutes walk to Hanzomon subway station, and close to Convenience stores, cafes and restaurants. Every room faces the Imperial Palace and has a view of Tokyo Tower, which is fab. And it's especially good for joggers and sakura lovers. Room and bed sizes are Japanese and no big bath in the hotel.

Room was rather small but very clean and well appointed.Room overlooked the Imperial Palace which was wonderful and so nice to wake up to in the morning.Breakfast was a strange affair. A first in that we were given a choice of 3 types of breakfast. It was inflexible and there was no option to request more. This left us immediately looking to eat again shortly afterwards outside the hotel.Locally, the main attraction being the Imperial Palace was situated directly across the road. Other attractions are nearby as is the nearest metro station with links to all parts of the city. Stay at this hotel is recommended, but be warned breakfast is not merely sufficient.

We got a "japanese stile" room. It looked different from the picture I saw during booking. Madrasses on the floor, small cairs. But ok room and authentic. The worst thing was that we got a "smoking" room (no nonsmaking available), no window could be opened. However, its an ok hotel for the price and with short connection to the subway and railway.

I had an amazing view from imperial Palace, Tokyo Tower and The Diet Building. Fantastic staff and very good facilities. I got a very spacious room, very well cleaned every day and will definitely stay there again next time I visit Tokyo.

Great place.View fantastic even if room was small. We only sleep there. Staff are so helpful though english limited but finding this all over Japan. Breakfast adequate but nothing to rave over. Metro close by. Would recommend.

Staff is very friendly, patient and helpful. Magnificent view from our room to Imperial Palace and Tokyo Tower. Room was very spacious for Tokyo standard. We stay at 1011 room.Breakfast is super delicious!! Only 3-5 minutes walk to station and nearby convenient/bento store. Very good and peaceful surrounding area, near to several embassies.

Overall no complaints...did not provide some the same cute amenities as a smaller hotel but not bad overall. The location made it challenge to find and connect to other subway lines or get back to the airport. So if its your last night before heading out, I'd pick some other place...we had to hire a taxi to the monorail then go from there.

This was my first trip to Japan and I feel I could not have picked a better central hotel to see all of Tokyo. As others have said, it is next to the Imperial Palace, however the entrance to it is on the other side of the lake but still an enjoyable walk. When I checked in I was glad I brought my paperwork with me as I knew no Japanese and the staff that helped me at the time had very basic English skills. That being said, you are checking into a hotel, so most things could be figured out and they were able to provide me a English map of locations near the hotel.The subway is one block away and because of that I did not use a taxi or anything for my trip. There are many local like restaurants and personally I did not use them as I went to the quick eat locations that were also near by. The other major point for myself is that the location was very quiet. After a long day in Tokyo it was nice to be able to come "home" to a peaceful place to sleep.I used the hotel restaurant a couple of times for breakfast and overall it was a very good American style breakfast and the service was excellent. I am used to American portion size and it was not close to that but I was not expecting that either. The room sizes as expected were also small but well furnished with a mini refrigerator Because of that fridge I brought a fair amount of snacks and the like back to my room. My only major downside that I had with the hotel is a lack of self-service laundry. The hotel tried to help again with the map in English but I made other plans and if I had the funds I could have used the hotels full service laundry.The hotel wifi was, as many hotel wifi's, slow at best, to the point I just used the personal Mifi that I rented for my trip.Last thing that I want to point out is that the hotel seems to read the comment cards. About a month after my trip, I got a letter in the mail thanking me for both my stay and the comments that I sent. It was a very nice touch.

Peaceful hotel with great view of japan. Walking distance to mini market and subway station. There are halal restaurant (indian and pakistan restaurant) nearby the hanzomon station. This hotel located in the government buillding and less tourist. The view is stunning. You could see tokyo city from tour room. But the channel available in their television not suitable for kids. No filter. some other hotel requires prepaid for adult channel.

This hotel is located near the Imperial Palace, but not in a great location if you want to walk anywhere apart from the Imperial Palace. It is near the tube station though so can provide easy access to other areas. The rooms were good with comfortable beds and the staff were helpful and spoke good English. There was free Wi-Fi which worked well.

Very nice room, not expensive, metro/subway in close walking distance. Beautiful view of the imperial park from the room. Wonderful desserts served in the cafe downstairs. Great location for taking walks around the park, not too many trees blooming yet but we were a bit early.

Let me start by explaining popular area. Its very clean, safe and good quality restuarants and importantly near Hanzamon underground. But it is not a busy area and you will need that underground to get about. With regard to the hotel. I thought it was amazing, different types of rooms to choice traditional Japanese or western style. Even western style will have the unique toilet system and Japanese bath.The hotel is massive but you don't feel lost in it or forever walking miles down corridors. The restaurant is very good but a little bit more expensive than going out to the restaurants nearby. The same with the view bar. You can sit with a pint of Guinness and watch the Tokyo Tower changing colour from the skyline view window.

The hotel is located near Exit 1 of the Hanzomon Station. However, there are no elevators for Exit 1 and 2 which are nearest to the hotel. For those who have heavy luggage and need the elevator, you will need to walk further to another exit and then walk a distance uphill to reach the hotel. There are many convenience stalls/bakeries/cafes/restaurants nearby for you to have your meals or buy a snack. The hotel was really clean although the room was slightly smaller. The best thing was the beautiful view of the tokyo tower and part of the imperial palace gardens from our room!

The Grand Arc Hanzomon hotel is very well located, in front of the imperial palace which offers a great view especially during Sakura time.The staff speaks very well english and you can feel the business hotel atmosphere. Thus, the facilities, the products provided in the room and the bed quality is more than satisfactory ! Will definitely go back to this hotel, but it's often full because of its popularity.

We stayed six nights at the Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon from February 29th to March 6th. We already communicated with the hotel ahead of our stay and received fast and helpful responses.We easily found the hotel. When arriving with heavy luggage you do not need to worry as the Hanzomon station has an elevator. Just follow the signs. If you wish to have the shortest way to the hotel you should take the first or second exit (stairs only, no elevator for these exits).The check-in was fast and uncomplicated. The staff spoke English very well so we had no issues. With our room keys we also received the password for the free Wi-Fi so we didn't need to request this.The lobby was welcoming and very neat. If you need a mail box, you can find it in the lobby next to the front desk. You can also get stamps from the staff of the front desk. Once we arrived in our room (normal double room, non-smoking) we were very pleased. The room is big enough for two people and comes with a bed that is about 1.40m wide (and quite hard), a desk with chair, an additional chair and a little coffee table. Furthermore a small fridge, an eletric kettle with tee bags and a hair dryer are available. The bathroom is also big enough and equiped with everything you need including a shaver and a comb. The best detail regarding the room was the amazing view. Even the smallest room does come with a big window. In our case we were able to see the Imperial Palace garden and the Tokyo Tower. Really amazing! We left the curtain open at night to enjoy the city view.And don't worry because of the bigger street in front of the hotel. You will definitely not hear it. It is very quiet at night. Also every floor offers a vending machine so you can get cold drinks very easily. Just bring a few coins as they don't work with Suica or Pasmo cards. We had breakfast at the hotel only once and ordered the Japanese breakfast. The breakfast is a set menu and you can only choose between Japanese, Continental and Western. The Japanese breakfast was okay and rich. We additionally ordered coffee which was quite expensive (around ¥600) and was only a small cup and quite bitter. Overall we were not fully satisfied with the breakfast and therefore decided to not eat at the restaurant again. Furthermore we did not test the other restaurants that are connected to the hotel.The area around the hotel is very nice. You can find convenience stores near the hotel where you can shop 24 hours a day. There's also a nice cafe with connected bookstore at the entrance of the Hanzomon Station. If you love to jog in the morning you can take the beautiful route around the Imperial Palace. Especially on weekends this seems to be a popular route. Overall we were very satisfied with the hotel. The room was big enough for the two of us. If you stay longer you should keep in mind that there is no real wardrobe in the room (at least not in the smallest available category we stayed in). Only a small open wardrobe with 4 to 5 hangers. So you will need to keep most clothes in your suitcases. Still we would highly recommend this hotel as it is quite cheap with a perfect location and view. The service was excellent. Thank you very much!
