we stayed at the hotel for 5 nights early feb 2016..I loved the hotel. it was near to the Hanzomon subway station exit 5. near a Lawson, near an Aeon food shop, near a Sunkus supermarket.. Also about 5 minutes walk away is an Indian restaurant that serves good briani and masala chicken..Ok about the rooms.. it was spotless. We got a smoking room and the room didnt wreak of cigarette smell the moment we entered. The hotel itself was a medium sized hotel.. Didnt get to try the breakfast as it wasnt included in my room price..The view from my room was amazing...... the city view after dark...the lit up Tokyo Tower...Room was always made up by the time we got back after our outings.. amenities always topped up..Hanzomon station is also centrally located in Tokyo.. so easy access to all the sightseeing places. Only one line to shibuya...Will definitely want to come back to this hotel

This is amazing. If you aren't already convinced google "Grand Arc Hanzomon Views" or look at the fabulous pictures posted on this Tripadvisor section. It's worth it for the view alone. The only reason I've given this place a 4/5 is strictly because of the location. It's not near any decent shops, and you have to walk quite far to the main train stations. It was kind of confusing being first time Japan travellers, and the only reason I wouldn't stay here again is because next time I want to be more central. However, I think being away from the main city helped a lot when it came to working out the trains and the overall feel of Tokyo. If you're going here for the first time, or want a relaxing holiday as opposed to being in the center of the city, then go here. The view is amazing.

This place is located west of the Imperial Palace, which you can see from the hotel! This area is very businesslike and political, so quite tranquil compared to the rest of Tokyo.Got a fantastic rate with Agoda, 10 nights which came out cheaper than a lot of lower end hotels.... Truly a grand hotel with a huge lobby and several good in house eateries (Patio lobby rest stands out!) Our room was fantastic with a wonderful view of the Imperial palace and Tokyo Tower! Reception and housekeeping were so kind and considerate! A block away from the Hanzomon metro stop, so if you find the area a little too sedate, the zanier parts of Tokyo are just a short ride away!

Stunning window view of the Imperial Palace Gardens. Close to shops and stations without being too close to the hustle and bustle. When we go back to Japan we will more than likely stay here again! Staff are very friendly but do not speak a whole deal of English (No one really does in Japan) but they're polite and don't mind you using silly hand movements! Food was amazing from the restaurant and you can use your bank card (Pounds Sterling).

We stayed at Grand arc hanzomon from 1st to 5th of Feb. We had slight difficulties in reaching it from the airport. We did not know the best way to get there so we walk quite far from tokyo station to otematchi station just to reach the hanzomon line. And when we finally arrived, the subway exit had to be done by stairs. A very long stairs with no escalator and no elevator near. our bad to bring 3 big luggages. Fortunately the hotel was great. We stayed at 15th floor and we can see tokyo tower from afar. Nice view. The room was not to big but is fine as long since it is clean and comfortable. The bathroom was clean and the the shower products were nice. The staffs were helpful even they could not speak english very well. We stayed for 4 nights and leave to Sapporo and came back on 8th to stay another night before leaving to Kyoto. Overall we had a good experience there.

Having been to Tokyo before and being well acquainted with its hustle and bustle, we were looking for somewhere a little bit removed. Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon was reasonably priced, not too far from fashionable shopping district Ginza and close to Hanzomon station. Whilst you're not plunged into the middle of Shinjuku or Shibuya, I didn't mind this as they are only a 5 min subway ride away and although it is next to the main road, you don't feel over stimulated as one can. Bed is comfy, room is standard Japanese double size and the bathroom was SLIGHTLY more spacious that others we experienced. Staff are hospitable and helpful. Would stay again! (and we are when we return at the end of this year).

Ok, I get that this hotel is not marketing itself to the average tourist and is largely a mid-range business hotel. I thought the location was great with a fantastic local yakitori place just opposite the station. Easy few stops to Shibuya and short taxi ride to Tokyo station for the Narita Express, Shinkansen etc. The hotel was functional and clean.The service from the front desk however was quite inflexible and abrupt. We stayed in a Japanese room which was fine. When I requested an extra futon (as has been provided in Ryokans I have stayed in previously) the response was as per the title of this review. Additionally, we requested a non-smoking room but got a very smoky one on a floor that smelt strongly of smoke. The western room (we had 2 rooms) was a little better and was non-smoking. Requests to move only resulted in an air freshener being delivered to the room.Overall, functional and in a great location. Just don't expect the legendary hospitality that is typical of a Japanese holiday experience.

this hotel is best hotel at 2013 and i think they can be more good on detailgood point:1 hotel outlook is beautiful!2 view you can see in hotel is good! hey you can watch out "tokyo tower" in your room.wooohoo!!3 staff English is well4 near Metro stationbad point:1 only 1 Metro line can direct to hotel and this line is no common for visit famous point2 near hotel only some small coffee shop3 room hardwear is old

We had a room located on the 14th floor and the view of Tokyo was amazing, looking directly towards Tokyo Tower. The room was meticulous, many products to lavish in, a tiny bath-tub with a Japanese automated toilet. The windows were huge which made the view even more incredible. The location was also great next to the the Imperial Palace. By far my favourite hotel in Tokyo, so far!

Trying to find a location, centered to all the sites we wanted to go see.The hotel in my opinion was in a perfect location for what my buddy & myself wanted to do.Decent size room for Japanese standards. Two single beds, good size bathroom, extra sink in hall, free wifi (great speed), good size closet, & decent size bathroom.I stand at 6'-2" and I could stand in the tub for a shower, but the shower head would be around my chest. Had to duck a bit but no biggy. As for the beds. If you like a firm bed, it is, firm. Firmer than what I was expecting but I had an awesome sleep & my back actually felt great. A couple of times we ate at the restaurant on the main floor for breakfast & once for dinner. You pay more but to be expected when eating from the hotel. Around $12 for breakfast. The staff were awesome to deal with. One of the staff members there, Takashi Okuaki was very helpful. We enjoyed having little conversation with him. His understanding & speaking of English wasn't too bad. Actually the staff from check-in & the restaurant were the same. Decent basic knowledge.Our rooms everyday were very clean & bathroom amenities were topped up (razors, toothbrushes, etc.)Our room was facing out towards the Imperial Palace and we could also see the Tokyo Tower from our room as well.As for smoking, I'm not too sure on the rooms. I went outside to the front of the hotel to have a cigarette.Two minute walk to visit Imperial Palace gardens, (if you're curious about walking around the perimeter of the Imperial Palace, it's 5km or 3 miles).Three minute walk to Hanzomon station. If you want to go to the Tokyo Skytree, get on the Hanzomon line & take it almost to the end. One train, 15-20 minutes & you're there.You can take the Hanzomon line with a connecting line to get to Shibuya (10-15 mins), Shinjuku (next stop north of Shibuya), or Akihabara (10-15 mins)On the other side of the Imperial Palace grounds from the hotel (20-30 min. walk) is Tokyo station (main train station), where you can get the JR bullet train or the other line of bullet trains, if you're going to Osaka, Kyoto, or Hiroshima. In my opinion the hotel has everything that we needed. The staff are friendly, the service was great, the hotel & the rooms were very clean, and the room size was cozy & decent. And the location was perfect for the places we wanted to go to.

We found this place last minute and it's only slightly more expensive than other budget hotels, and what a great experience this was. The room was spacious, twin beds were very comfortable. Due to its arc architecture our room doesn't have view to the Tokyo Tower but view to the palace was fantastic. We visited during the gingko/maple season and the scenery around was gorgeous.The hotel is three minutes walk from the Hanzomon station. The Hanzomon line is convenient enough, and just one stop away at Nagatacho/Akasakamitsuke station you have access to four more lines which go almost anywhere in Tokyo. Also it's only a 1200yen cab ride from the Tokyo station if you don't want to drag your luggage.

We stayed several nights at this hotel. When we booked we were a bit worried about the size of the bed since we choose the "SemiDouble" room, but space was no problem for us. The view from the room was even more amazing than we were expecting, especially at night time.We thought that the laundry service was expensive, but decided that we would give it a try. When the laundry was returned to us, every single piece of our clothing was neatly folded and wrapped in plastic (shirts were wrapped around a piece of cardboard) with socks paired together with safety pins.The bathroom came with soap, toothpaste, toothbrushes, razors, shaving gel, etc. The room also had two robes that were replaced each day if used.

Great hotel. Spotless clean, conveniently located 5 min. from the metro station. Amazing views, each evening I enjoyed the view from my room for a while before going to bed and this times are a good memory have from my trip. Even though the hotel is located on a busy boulevard the soundproof is great and you dodn`t hear any traffic noise. Staff are polite and efficient. Would stay again in the hotel if I go to Tokyo.

Nicely located close to Hanzomon station and the imperial palace, this hotel feels a little bit fancy and has wonderful views of the city and Tokyo Tower. Room was comfortable and clean, staff were friendly and efficient and the vending machine contained Dr pepper. That made me happy.

I am very impressed with the view from my room and I sleep with the curtain opened. Service offered by the hotel was good and receptionist was fairly helpful. However, I am concern with the fact that the lift of the hotel do not require room card to access to the upper floors. Room size was small and with 2 big luggage, we are barely able to find space to open our luggage. However, we are able to fit in by moving the chair and table. We still enjoy our stay at this hotel which provided us with excellent facilities/services. During our stay we asked for iron, umbrella, storage of luggage and pickup of parcel delivery which they able to provide or done well. Area around the hotel was relatively boring but it was very close to bus stop and train station which is less than 5mins walk away. This area is very safe with a huge police and royal palace around the corner. Food is limited near but mini mart was available nearby. I have to give a credit to the room service which arrived daily without fail to clean up our messy room.

It's located right at the center of administration buildings, next to Imperial Palace, Jogging Track (Imperial Palace Park), National Theater and local restaurant plus Family Mart and other groceries shops all nearby the hotel.The room is quite small, though you had twin beds, but it's still comfortable. Small wide window that can viewed the best Tokyo City view from your room.Thumbs up Grand Arc!

The hotel, being owned by the police department next door, is at a very safe and convenient neighborhood. There ate many little restaurants and several metro stops nearby. The room itself, like most Japanese hotels, is not big but very well set up. The toiletries are fine and bed is comfortable. The breakfast is very decent. The choice for the Japanese one is varied every day. Although I had the coffee from the restaurant patio and it was certainly not very good. I wouldn't recommend anyone to pay to order it. That being said, overall it was pleasant and staff members are helpful.

I am very surprised that I was not taken aback by this accommodation. All places we stayed at in Japan were so refreshing and amazing so maybe our bar was higher when we checked in here. This seemed like a confused combination of modern and traditional Japan. The view from the room was amazing - we could see Tokyo tower from our window however, getting to the window was a battle. The room is tiny and poorly organized. I had to spend some time moving the furniture around just to be able to put our backpacks somewhere. There is absolutely no moving space in the room, you enter and then just stand there before you can figure out where to put your foot next. Once rearranged, it was better. The next problem was no tea/coffee in the room - only Japanese tea. This was surprising. We had stayed at some very traditional place in the west of Japan and even there, we had access to coffee and tea with cream and sugar. And there excuse for not having these in the room was that they were doing the traditional Japanese green tea. Maybe this was not such a big deal, but being able to get a hot cup of tea or coffee in the room is a luxury that I like to enjoy on my travel. The location is pretty convenient - you can walk to the Honzomon station and connect to anywhere on the subway which is nice. Overall, I would recommend staying here if you are seeing cheap rates, if not, look for something else - there is nothing that made this place stand out for me. If I went back, I will not be staying here for sure.

Absolutely great Hotel. Directly at the Hanzomon Metro line (to Shibuya!!) it's very convenient to get everywhere! Lovely neighborhood with great restaurants and a lot of convenient stores. Service at the Hotel was great. They really did their best to help and were always very friendly! My room was really cozy (15th floor with a superb view) It is a little bit small, but not crowded! It felt like home (I was there for 2 weeks on my own). The toilet was typical japanese, with warm seating and bidet functions. I would definitely go back and also recommend it to everyone!

This hotel was great; we stayed for 4 nights. It is very near the Hanzomon subway line, as well as a convenience store just before exiting the station. The room is quite spacious, with a great view of the lake at the imperial palace. The bathroom is really clean as well and it is really comforting to take a hot shower after a long day out. As mentioned, the hotel is very near the imperial palace, which attracts many joggers on weekends, so visitors who need their dose of exercise don't have to venture far. Wifi signal was good throughout our stay. I would definitely recommend this place!

My partner and I booked through Expedia for a hotel + flight deal. With a view to travelling around Tokyo and then taking the bullet train out to some of the more rural regions in Japan, we were looking for somewhere quite central. You could say whichever district you stay in in Tokyo, you are central, due to such a fantastic underground network. On this occasion, we opted for the Hanzomon district.Situated right next to the imperial palace, this 17 story building is a real gem of a hotel. We were given a very friendly, hassle-free reception on both our arrival and departure. The room was perfect for what we needed, albeit slightly on the small side. We chose a non-smoking twin room, which comprised: a double bed, table and chair, floor lamp, tv, hairdryer, dressing table/desk area, small alcove for clothing, bedside table and telephone, bathroom (with shower over bath, sink, toilet with numerous functionality (hours of fun pressing all of these and filming our reactions!)). The alcove also served as a space for storing one suitcase, though because of the general space limitations, the other suitcase had to be left in the middle of the floor.We were up on the 10th floor, so had a pretty amazing view over Hanzomon. You can opt for a view over the imperial palace gardens, though we didn't feel we missed out by not having this.My only gripe with the room was the bed and pillows. It took quite a few days into our two week holiday to achieve a good nights sleep. Not only because of the jet lag, but because the bed was hard and the cushions were almost 'crunching' under our heads. Other than that I really can't complain about the room.We dined at the Patio restaurant in the hotel many times during our stay for both breakfast and our evening meals. Dining in Japan is like doing Bushtucker trials(!), so eating at the hotel was a safe bet, plus the food was absolutely lovely. Quite often we had the continental breakfast in the morning. For dinner, I'd recommend the Beef Steak in Teriyaki sauce. Mouthwatering! The service was also fantastic. Everyone is extremely pleasant and accommodating. They couldn't thank you enough for your custom. There was one particular waiter (hoping I have his name correct - Okuaki), who always had a smile from ear to ear and couldn't do enough to help. At one point I caught a bad cold during the holiday, so requested some hot water with honey and lemon. They promptly obliged (after showing them a Google translation on my partners phone to assist with the language barrier) and didn't even charge us for the privilege! In terms of the hotels location, it's only a two minute walk to the nearest underground station, which was ideal for us. Hanzomon itself errs on the side of being more of a business district, so isn't thriving with bars, nightclubs or restaurants. But with such a lovely hotel restaurant, and the ability to hop onto the underground at any time, we really couldn't complain. If I ever went back to Tokyo, I'd have no hesitation in staying at the Grand Arc Hanzomon again. Top notch accommodation and service!

We stayed for three nights at this hotel while visiting Tokyo. We were very happy. The location is very good, just a short walk to the nearest metro station. Nice staff in the reception, check in and out was very easy. We had breakfast included and it was nice, nothing luxurious but nice anyway. Room was ok, maybe a bit old the furniture and decor but clean and nice. Very good wi-fi. We can recommend this hotel!

We were here just for a night. Its about a 200 Mtr walk to the subway station. Room size is decent for Tokyo standards. Didn't interact a lot witht he staff but whatever limited interaction we had, they were helpful and accommodating.

Situated in the Hanzomon area (Legislative, Embassies, National Theatre) of Tokyo the Hotel overlooks the Imperial Gardens and is an easy 25min walk to the Palace. While most of the staff do not speak much English they are very helpful and accommodating. The deluxe rooms on the top (17th) floor are spacious by Tokyo standards with comfortable twin double beds (King beds seem rare in Japan). The room has a large bathroom with bath and a decent sized hotel fridge (no mini-bar but it's cheap enough to buy goodies from the local store). Hanzomon is a little off a big Metro line, but only a NZ$12 taxi ride to the Ginza (main Tokyo shopping precinct). We paid about $270/night for the deluxe and $120/night standard (with breakfast).

The complete lack of customer service and any notion of accountability has made my stay memorable for all the wrong reasons. There was a lack of communication before arrival so upon check in one is met with a list of unexpected demands. I had bought a new pair of ornamayed earrings which was carefully placed in plain view. When the ear rings went missing after the room was cleaned there has been a complete lack of acknowledgement of responsibility  by the hotel of the missing ear rings and I was faced only with acqusitory questions on if I had misplaced them. Todate the hotel has taken no responsibility in the loss of my ear rings nor offered any apologies for having played any part in their loss. The facilities are no better or worse than any other hotel room so I would strongly recommend against staying at this hotel.

We stayed at room 1410 and we have an excellent view of the surroundings. Tokyo Tower is very much visible. We were also near the Imperial Palace.Near Hanzomon, Kogimachi, and Nagatacho train stations.Peaceful surroundings. Not very crowded. Many trees nearby also. There are many joggers around as the area is good for such activities.Many convenience stores nearby - sunkus, lawson, and family mart. We also spotted some restaurants nearby. There is a nearby restaurant which offers delicious chinese food.Wifi has very strong signal.Paid 48k yen for 5 nights. Good value for money.Room is spacious for a japanese hotel.Good service though they were not replying to our email queries before our flight to tokyo. We had to call them from overseas just to confirm our booking.

My husband and I stayed here from October 15th to October 17th. Other reviews are correct as the room is not spacious but was adequate for the two of us. My husband is a big guy whereas I am rather small. I am mentioning this as beds in Asia can be on the smaller side and this was a concern for us when we booked. However, we fit just fine! The room is clean (I am VERY hard to please in this regard) and comfortable. The bathroom was great and the toiletries they provide are fantastic! Also, the location of this hotel is wonderful. It is a 2 minute walk to the subway and from there we reached all of our destinations rather quickly. This includes Harajuku, Rapongi Hills, Shibuya Crossing, the Pokémon store, an Anime mall, Sensoji temple, and others. From the Narita airport it is definitely a bit of a distance but we didn't mind the train ride as it was well worth it once we got into the city. I would highly recommend! A classy hotel.

Stayed in a Twin Room for 5 nights and can't complain - room was a great size and even had a separate sink outside bathroom which we found very convenient. The views were fantastic over the Imperial Palace and city of Tokyo particularly at night..a short walk to the railway takes you to the Hanzomon line and from there you can go anywhere.We purchased 24 hour day passes for 1000 yen each day and you can hop off everywhere - we also caught a cab from the hotel to Tokyo station for 1800 yen as carrying bags up and down stairs would have been a pain..wound highly recommend this hotel but be careful when you turn the TV on as we found out - first few channels we flicked to were showing Porn - not a greet look if you have kids with you so be careful..

Having gone to other three star hotels in Tokyo that have tiny toilets and no room to put your luggage this was a great upgrade and for the same price too of the other three star hotels this is the best value for around 10000yen a night. You get a great view of tokyo and the sky tree plus everything feels new and modern the bath tub is much larger than the typical Japanese ones that require you to sit like a ball in them. Even thought it is not on the JR line it is on a very convenient Hanzomon Metro Line that goes straight to the Sky tree and very close to ikebukuro and akihabara and Shibuya

We booked this hotel as our first stop on our Japan tour. The hotel was great the staff were very friendly and the hotel was ideal for the subway and train station for trips out.The area itself was good right by the Imperial Palace. We booked a double room which said it was small but when we arrived it was plenty big enough and could not get over the heated toilet seats.The breakfasts were very good you could have western or japanese your choice we had both as booked for three nights to allow us to visit different places. There are plenty of shops and restaurants/cafes nearby. All in a we were pleased with our choice a good start to what was a great holiday. The only downside is you cannot use pools or baths if you have tattoos we knew this as had checked before so be aware.

First, this hotel is NOT a full service hotel. Doesn't have all the amenities that a luxury property should have. That being said, it is not a dive by any means. The pros, great location. Just down the street from the Hanzomon subway station, across the street from the Imperial Palace Gardens, practically beside the National Theater. They have very fast wifi. Both my wife and I were running netflix of their wifi without issue. Size of the room we got was reasonable. Not North American huge but for Japan, it was bigger than most places.The cons, we wanted a massage but none was to be had. No convenience stores nearby. In fact, you had to go back to the subway station to buy a bottle of water. There are very little restaurants nearby. You will see lots of dignitaries and VIP's and their entourage running around blocking off elevators. This isn't a big deal.We booked our room here via online auction and it was significantly reduced price from list price. There are bargains to be had if one looks around.Parking, this is one of the cheapest parking places in the area. It costs 1500 yen per day with in and out privileges for guests. Pay parking nearby can go upwards of 2800 yen per pad without in and out privileges.

Stayed in the Grand Arc Hanzomon for 2 nights in October 2015. The rooms are small but very nice and clean. The beds are suitable for 2 people (I'm a big guy and fit comfortably with my wife). They provide complimentary razors, soaps, pj's, combs etc. No iron or ironing board in the room. Fantastic view from the room. When exiting Hanzomon subway station follow the signs for Grand Arc Hanzomon exit, cross the street directly in front of the exit. Slightly to the right is the street the hotel is on, just keep walking straight you'll see it. Hotel is a 5min walk from the station, if that. It is centrally located in the city making all the sights easily accessible. Recommend shopping in Harajuku (oriental bizarre for souvenirs, tons of high end american brands), Sunshine City Mall (Ikebukuro station) (Disney Store, Pokemon Store), and Broadway Nakano for nerd items (DBZ and other anime items, pop culture items, etc.). Visited Senso-Ji temple, Meiji Shrine, Shibuya Crossing and the Kachiko statue, all well worth seeing. Had traditional style sushi in Harajuku (on omotesando street just past the oriental bizarre), food was fresh and delicious. Paid about $30 Canadian for 2 people. All in all Tokyo is a beautiful city and my wife and I can't wait to go back. Would recommend spending 5-7 days there in order to get the full experience. Well worth the money. Would stay at Grand Arc Hanzomon again without question.

After coming off of a couple of very bucolic weeks hiking around the Japanese Alpine route and enjoying some lovely onsen and Ryokans, I didn't want to finish my stay in the hustle and bustle of Kabuki-Cho or another bust part of Tokyo. We chose the Grand Arc Hanzomon as it's near Tokyo Station (10 minute cab ride). The Hotel is near the Imperial palace Grounds and located in a quiet area of office buildings as well as being next to the national theater. The hotels has 17 floors which offer a great view of the Imperial Palace Park, a beautiful tree filled green expanse in the middle of Tokyo. We were lucky and had booked a deal getting us the Grand Arc Suite on the 17th floor. it was a lovely space with real closets, a nice sitting area and a twin bedded bedroom. The Bathroom was very nice with a Japanese Bath and Shower system as well as a separate WC.It was a nicely equipped room with a tea kettle in the foyer wet bar area complete wiith teas and a fridge, air purifiers in each room and free wifi.However, service is a bit lacking. We arrived and there was no bell help or cart to help us with all our bags (I was traveling with extra suitcases that had accommodated gifts from the US and would soon be filled with Gifts from Japan for the return).They had a laundry service which seemed very regular. I was expecting them to be placed in my room, but getting in very late from dinner, I found a message on the phone that asked me to come down to the desk and pick up my laundry. Not terrible, but not the service that one expects when staying at a nice hotel.On our departure, we were once again struggling to get our (now filled ) bags out of the hotel to a cab. Once outside the front entrance, we saw a uniformed man and a man in a suit standing at attention. When we asked for a cab, they notified us that we would d have to walk to the nearest main thoroughfare and try to hail one outrrselves. They stood at attention and watched us struggle by. We did find a cab after walking 3 blocks.it was a nice hotel, clean, well kept and in a very nice area. Just because its perceived as a business hotel, it doesn't mean that the extra added bits of service should be forgotten. Still not a bad place if you get a good booking deal like we did.

Walking distance to the Imperial Palace and a short taxi ride from Tokyo station makes the location good if you're not looking to stay in the more touristy areas. On arrival we were early for check in but the staff member immediately offered to store our bags until the room was ready. He also organised to ship one of our bags to our next hotel in kyoto. The room was ready slightly earlier than specified and we were able to check in. The rooms are compact, but not suffocating. Everything was very clean. Personally I find all hotel beds too firm and this bed was no different. Highly recommended.

Quiet area of Tokyo with some great views, during day or night time. Breakfast was plated continental not buffet which i prefer but still they didnt fail since the breakfast was good enough. Staff were okay and accomodating.But I dont know if I'll come back because i had a creepy or a weird experience around midnight while fixing our luggage. the faucet on the bathroom was opening by itself for three times. Didnt know if it was automatic sensor or something was broken. But really felt there was something wrong.

A lovely comfortable hotel with Hanzomon subway just a 2 minute walk away and Tokyo hotel a pleasant half hour stroll past the Imperial Palace gardens. Striking view from window over Tokyo city. Staff friendly and English speaking. Room and bed comfortable and very clean. All amenities provided. We stayed for seven nights and were able to get to various locations throughout Tokyo via the subway with only a transfer or two. There are many restaurants around this area and several convenience stores for supplies. A great base from which to explore Tokyo each day.

Small, but comfortable room with all necessities. We had a room on the 15th floor with a great view over the city. Close to the Hanzomon metro station. This means that you can get most places relatively fast with just one metro line change. Breakfast is rather bland.

Stayed here for a couple of nights as ratings were good when researching. Wasnt disappointed, great location and fantastic views across the imperial park and tokyo Worth the extra bit of money that your standard decent budget hotel, worth a stay
