London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed for 3 nights, check in & out went smoothly. Business hotel with very few Japanese details.Location: Just in front of the Imperial Palace and near Hanzomon metro station and Tokyo StationLobby and common areas: pretty standard for business hotelRoom: standar japanese size (see: small) but functional, window has great view of the imperial palace zone (not directly to the palace) and the neighborhood was quiet enough.Room has the standard japanese business accomodations like TV, Safe, Hairdryer, alarm, teamaker, heated toilet seat and bidet. Provides everything for shaving and brushing teeth. Room maintains the standard business look so don't expect anything traditional. Didnt check if it had pool or gymPrice: good value-price relationshipService: we didn't require much room service but all the personel were very servicial and actually kept my luggage safe for several days while i travaled to the rest of the country with no extra fee (huge thanks for that)Conclusion: I really liked my stay and felt like the location was perfect for moving via metro or train. Would definetely stay again.

This was a lovely hotel and the view from our room was amazing- we loved sitting out looking at it before bed and opening the curtains to see the city in front of us every morning. Well-equipped with all the toiletries you could need and staff were incredibly helpful and friendly. Perhaps not the best location if you want to be in the centre of the nightlife, but it was in a quiet and safe neighbourhood with Hanzomon station only a few minutes away. Would definitely recommend.

The hotel smells like second hand smoke. The rooms smell of old cigarette smoke.The restaurant needs renovating. The chairs are old and stained. The walls have chunks of plaster missing and the windows look like they were tinted by a 5 year old.The reception are not very helpful. I needed late check out due to our flight leaving at 11:45pm which i was happy to pay an extra night but they told me they were fully booked however when i checked the internet there were rooms available.The breakfast is small and over priced.

I stayed here with my wife for two days and the room was small but well appointed with amazing views out over Tokyo and the Imperial gardens. The staff were friendly and spoke English well, we both really enjoyed our stay but it was plain to see that the hotel was targeted at business.All in all Grand Arc Hanzomon offers exceptional value for money and a comfortable room.

Spent 4 days on conference this hotel I feel is good for business and meetings it's in the business district area of Tokyo so would not recommend for families except if they are willing to travel for everything. There are few shops in the vicinity and a metro station few yards away. The hotel facilities are adequate and rooms well kept with a good bar in hotel. I would recommend for business only in my opinion but okay for couple with no kids as not much activity in the hotel.

Nice, clean rooms and a very helpful staff with good english skills. Sentral and quiet location with subway just around the corner. Accepts european Mastercard and Visa. There is also a 7/11-atm close by for cash withdrawals. Recomended!

The Grand Arc met our needs perfectly for our 24-hour layover in Tokyo: easy access to Tokyo Station (a short cab ride around the Imperial Palace) easy access to Shibuya (subway via Hanzomon Line) and a Japanese style room--all without blowing the budget. The bathroom was roomy, spotless, and well equipped. The futons were comfortable, and the room very quiet. Would recommend. Please note that this hotel is in a district dominated by government buildings, so there is not much in the way of food, culture, or entertainment (head to Shibuya for the lights, shopping, and eats).

Location is great for access to metro and convenience stores (there is a kettle and fridge in the rooms) and a few little bars and restaurants within close walking distance. The stores stay open until around midnight but the bars and restaurants seem to close earlier. There is a hotel bar but last order is 10.30. We only went once as it didn't have much of an atmosphere..... only 3 occupied tables, but again there is a good view and the food is ok. There are a selection of vending machines on each floor along with an ice machine. The machines sell sort drinks and beer too, which is thoughtful!Room was very comfortable indeed with air con and dehumidifier. Ask for a room on the upper floors and stipulate non smoking room (if you are a non smoker!). The bed was very comfortable and was changed daily along with the towels. The room was compact but ample in size and the view from the huge picture window fantastic by both day and night. We weren't disturbed by any noise which is a rarity in most hotels we have visited. The bathroom was a reasonable size and the shower quite powerful. The toilet provided a good source of amusement with the control pad for seat heating, water noise, and a range of spraying/ jetting options! Be aware that there is not a lot of storage space for clothing. We ate lunch in the restaurant a few times and the food was ok. There is an outside dining patio too. Service all through the hotel is excellent. The wi-fi was reasonably fast too.On arrival I would suggest you look at the tourist info available in the guest Internet room off reception. There was some very good and helpful info there which we only came across towards the end of our stay.The only thing I missed was a bar open for a night cap when we came back after a long day/ evening out and about. I would be happy to recommend this hotel and I would be please to stay again.

The hotel is in a great spot just a few minutes walk from Hanzomon Station. This means getting round Tokyo is really easy and the journey in from the airport is quite straight forward. The hotel is clean with large rooms and amazing views of the imperial Palace Gardens. It's a really nice place to stay and if I'm ever back in Tokyo I would book again. I would recommend contacting the hotel for directions before you arrive as we had difficulty finding the hotel as there are so many exits out of Hanzomon station. We took the wrong one and ended up being taken to the hotel by a lovely Japanese man who took pity on us.

This hotel is ideally situated just a few yards from the metro so it is easy to get around. We stopped out late a couple of times and got the cab back to the hotel 2000 yen from Shinjuku. Also there are a few watering holes and eating establishments nearby as well as a handy mini supermarket. The rooms are big enough and are equipped with a decent sized fridge which was handy. The rooms are scrupulously clean and many offer a decent view of the city skyline. This has to be one of the quietest and most comfortable hotels I have ever stayed in!My one gripe would be the hotel bar it does have one but it is well removed from the action and closes at 10.30pm

Stayed here for 6 nights - the duration of our stay in Tokyo. It was a lovely hotel, located nicely near a whole lot of restaurants - I had the best Miso ramen a short walk from here! - and transport - the subway is only a short walk away! It has a nice restaurant and bar.

We stayed here for the first 3 nights of our Japan travel to explore Tokyo. The hotel is centrally located in a quiet area west of the Imperial palace and on just a few minutes walk from hanzomon metro station. From here all districts of Tokyo are easily reachable.The hotel is big and modern. Rooms are Tiny (2 person bed is cornered against the wall) but comfortable. The matrass is quite hard though.Bathroom is good with an awesome supply of bathroom tools like brushes, combs, oils etc. View on the skyline of the Ginza area is also neat. Breakfast quite allright with continental, japanese or american choices. Staff friendly, though i felt we could've been more actively helped at the reception desk when asked to help book a restaurant. The restaurant wasn't open yet and hotel staff insisted we HAD to be there when the call was made. Not convenient when planning to sightsee all day.All in all a decent choice.

We had a very pleasant stay in this hotel. It is located a couple of minutes walk from Hanzamon subway station so it is very easy to get about the city from there. It is also next to the Imperial Gardens so going for a walk is not an issue either. The area itself is very quiet and has a couple of restaurants near by. The reception of the hotel is quite nicely decorated and there is a little shop selling flowers and related items. The restaurant is fine, a little bit clinical but still nice and served a passable breakfast (unfortunately I had been spoilt by the Sheraton Breakfast in Osaka the previous week so the bar was pretty high). Staff on reception were helpful and helped us organise our transfers back to the airport. The room itself was quite small but that is to be expected in Tokyo. It did lead to some interesting issues about where to put clothes but that was not really a problem. It had everything you would want so nothing really to complain about. The bed was very comfortable and the view from the window was amazing! You could see the Imperial gardens and Tokyo Tower. What more could you ask for!I would stay there again.

This is my 2nd time staying at the Grand Arc Hanzomon and it's quite a nice hotel to stay in.My room had a view of Tokyo Tower and part of the Imperial Palace Gardens which is a short stroll away. The rooms are clean, hotel service is excellent and I have no complaints at all.Although Hanzomon area is a little boring, just 1 stop on the metro will get you to Nagatacho Station which connects to Akasaka-mitsuke which has many places to eat and drink.

My husband and I stayed here on the last night of our trip, and were very impressed! Our room was very comfortable, and I was amazed at how many little toiletry things they had for you if needed. We were on the sixth floor and had views over Tokyo and the Imperial Palace grounds. Although there aren't too many eateries located near this hotel, we were able to find a very nice Chinese restaurant, not too far away.I chose the Grand Arc Hanzomon for it's proximity to Tokyo Station, but had not judged the walking distance all that well. We walked from the station when we arrived approximately 45 minutes of hard walking, and decided on a taxi back in the morning. Much more sensible!As a one night stop this was a great place to stay, but it would have been nicer to stop and enjoy this a little more. It felt much more luxurious than the budget hotel tag - not sure if its correct?

We booked traditional Japanese hotel rooms -which means we were greeted by futons and tatami mats. The hotel room fit so much in so little space. However, the bathroom is not for people over 5'8". My brother literally could not fit in the shower without hunching. The room also has a very strong odor of green tea, in case that's not your thing. We loved the traditional Japanese room though, and it was incredibly fun to sleep in the futons and figure out how the sophisticated bathroom worked. IDK how, but everything you need will be in the hotel room. There's a weight scale, stuff to take care of your shoes, and all sorts of bathroom needs, from face wash to hair supplies and elastics, to razors and shaving gel.However, like most places in Japan, people do NOT speak English. The hotel staff has very limited English. They are as helpful as possible, and we encountered little problems. It just takes a while to communicate what we need or want. The hotel also provides a map they created of the surrounding area, colorcoding different places like subway stations, types of restaurants, and 24-hour stores. The hotel location is perfect, and a metro station is just minutes away.We thoroughly enjoyed our stay and recommend it to anyone looking for an affordable hotel room in Tokyo.

We stayed here at the beginning of our 17 day stay in japan, 2 nights in the grand arc was pleasant enough but wouldn't want to stay longer predominantly due to location. hanzomon is a nice safe quiet area but a long walk or tube ride to anywhere interesting! The rooms are small but comfortable, the bathrooms are even smaller and look like they are from a boat or camper van! The view is great, the service is standard yet smiley and most importantly the cost was good! Recommend for a lay over, next time I think I'll stay closer to shibuya or ueno

Each night we went to sleep with the curtains open to an amazing view of Tokyo. The breakfast int he hotel is good and the service is excellent. The bar does good food with again excellent views and London Gin, if you are missing something from home.

We booked here after reading the fantastic reviews on tripadvisor and booked a 5 nights stay. However, we were extremely disappointed with the service provided to us.On the last night, I went to the front desk and requested for information of international shipping options. The lazy man said that he did not know and did not even bother to find out. I blatantly told him to go research online and he finally obliged. It appears that common sense is not so common anymore. Obviously, basic level of customer service was greatly lacking. After that, we went back to the room. Called front desk to request for a weighing scale via the phone. The smart aleck receptionist, Yamamoto kept asking me to repeat like a fool when his competency level of english sucks. After several times of repeating myself and he did not understand, I requested to be put to another person. Finally the front desk supervisor (a female) took over the call and told me that he does not speak english well. If that is the case, it is common sense for him to transfer the phone call immediately and not treat a guest like a fool and ask her to repeat several times. Service was so bad that even a budget hotel chain like hotel mystays is significanly better. The pillow was uncomfortable. Reception was old and dim. Only saving grace was the view from the room. After speaking to the front desk manager and general manager (the general manager could not even speak basic level of english), I am very certain that this hotel caters to japanese business guests. Hence the number of staff who is competent in the english language is minimal. Naturally, the service is better towards Japanese guests and foreigner guests are discriminated in this hotel.

Everything went well. From the limousine. Bus from Narita , the short metro ride from the TCAT terminal to the Hanzomom stop. The photo , from the hotel, steered us on the correct road and it was it 5 minute stroll to the hotels front door.We arrived early but were given a roomThe room was described as a semi double room, biggest room I've had in Tokyo in 3 times I've been there.Bathroom was standard and goodThe room had a fridge Eat in the hotels restaurant for lunch and the food was goodStaff were very helpful and spoke excellent English Locally there are good restaurants, 24 HR convenience stores and we found an ATM in the station that took our MasterCard , instead of the 20 minute walk to Asakasa Citibank.I will happily stay there again.

We booked a room at this hotel for the night before our flight out of Tokyo. It is located conveniently near the subway, and isn't terribly far from the train. Every room in the hotel has a great view of the Imperial Palace and surrounding city. Our room was a decent size by Japanese standards, and immaculate. Excellent wifi, polite service, and a reasonable price.

It's my second time in Tokyo, and i never knew this kind of location existed. The moment we get out of Hanzomon Station from the Airport, i fell in love with the place. Its about 3-minutes walk from Exit 1 of Hanzomon Station. But please warned that if you bring heavy suitcases, you'll have to take the staircases - no escalator or lift. You'll have to go through the other exit to be able to use a lift, though a little farther walk.The hotel itself is very tidy, though as expected small. We got a very nice view, very relaxing. Food on their restaurant is good and moderately priced. They also have a set breakfast for Y1,030 per person, which i think is just fair enough. There are nearby restaurants and convenient stores, but don't expect much more. Otherwise, you can always take the train and go to Shibuya, Shinjuku, Ginza, etc..It's always good to return after a busy day at this hotel. I would definitely stay again if i go back to Tokyo.

In a quiet business district. Close to Hanzomon metro station. Close to small convenience store. No matter where you stay, what you want to do or see is invariably on the other side! Don't stress about location as long as there is a metro station around.Reception-Good English and helpfulRoom-Pretty good size for Tokyo with a nice view. Part of the wall was galss blocks, too bad it was not all window.Light for reading –GoodBed –Comfortable for Japan with 2 types of pillow. Air Conditioning-Good and quietWi-Fi-Worked wellTV- No English or other western language channels.Refrigerator-GoodRoom for bags-GoodTea Kettle Bathroom-Good size for Japan with an extra sink outside.Shower pressure-GoodCloths line-yesTowels-Nice and clean. Hair dryer-GoodFull length mirror-YesMakeup mirror-No Laundry-No self-serveIron and ironing board-NoComplimentary bottle water-NoPlugs-Not by the bed

Very nicely run and clean hotel with a pleasant mix of typical old-school japanese hotelery with modern touches. Rooms are decent sized, with western styled toilets and showers. Beds are smallish, but clean and comfortable. upholstery is clean, and the rooms have a modern feel. Small touches, like the main control unit for the lights, and the smaller bathroom with the fully automated toilet reminds you that you are in a japanese hotel, but it is very comfortable. Dorm size refrigerator (empty) and wi-fi in room, and beverage vending down the hall.View out window was spectacular, looking out over the avenue and grounds of the Imperial Palace. One block walk in the other direction to train station, and restaurant area. There are restaurants in building, and a bar with a great view. Good security, with doorman access after 10pm. Laundry service was reasonable,and quick.I could detect the smell of smoking in the hallway, even though we had a non-smoking room/floor, but no smell was detected in room.Reasonable cost for a nice hotel with access to train station and Imperial Palace area.

Arrived very late - but the reception was open and very friendly - smoking floor/smoking room - smell was awful. Must get breakfast included on these sites as it does bump up the cost of the hotel when you dont. Very close to the imperial palace, Theatre of japan, 20 minute walk round the imperial palace to the best shopping area and the Tokyo station.

My room was quite new and well organized. A little small, but I expected it to be this way in japan. The bed was almost a double bed - 120 cm. The location was good, not great. Really close to the subway, but not the most exciting neighboorhood. There were a couple of nice restaurants nearby, but not many things to see at a walking distance. We split our days in Tokyo between Chiyoda and Shinjuku. Ask for a room on the upper floors facing the river - we had an amazing view of the par and city.

What a view. Looking across to the Imperial Palace and the Tokyo skyline was a wonderful experience. The room itself had the most comfortable mattress I've slept on in an hotel and though the decor in the bathroom may have a hint of the '70s about it everything was spotless and first rate.

It is situated near the Hanzomon station which is smack in the centre allowing easy exploration of the other areas of Tokyo. The hotel itself is very modern, clean, and well equipped. I happened to stay in one of their Japanese style rooms, so if you're ok with sleeping on the futon on the floor, it is an excellent choice for the price as the room is quite spacious, especially for Tokyo standards. It also offers a view of the Imperial grounds.

This was the first of three hotels we stayed in during a 10-day trip around Tokyo and Kyoto. It was the perfect starting point to explore the city, and a great, comfortable sanctuary after a busy day. The rooms are larger-than-average by Tokyo standards, although still relatively compact to European or American expectations. We opted for a twin room, which based on images seems to have slightly more space than the basic double rooms. The style is bright, fresh and clean, making the rooms very inviting. Aside from the two large twin beds, we also had a small seating area with a coffee table, and a small entrance hall which boasted a vanity mirror and stool along with the sizeable wardrobe. The beds were firm but comfortable. From the 15th floor, the views across the city with Tokyo Tower in the centre were spectacular, especially once night fell. The TV was easy to use and navigate (something of a rarity in Japan!) and the bathroom was quite basic, but fit to purpose and equipped each day with a full gambit of toiletries. The AC worked a treat and was very powerful. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants, but we sampled La Mer lounge for drinks one evening. It had a very pleasant, more-formal atmosphere and lovely views. Service was great and the prices, though slightly higher than other bars in the city, were still relatively cheap when compared with European hotel bar prices. Guests here are just a couple of minutes walk from Hanzomon subway station, meaning you can get anywhere in the city exceptionally easily. There isn't a great deal to see or do in the immediate area - a few restaurants, convenience stores and a nice cafe for a cheap breakfast before setting out for the day. For those who plan on exploring, I'd totally recommend buying a PASMO card from the subway station for Y500 - you can top it up as needed and it works on all public transport, so you don't need to worry about the price of each single train trip. You can also use it on subway vending machines and in convenience stores, plus it worked on the subway in Kyoto and also on the Kyoto tramline! For every tourist I saw struggling with the prices on the tube map, I really wanted to go and tell them to opt for a PASMO instead. The front desk staff were very helpful and efficient and helped us with a number of questions about services and directions. The clientelle of the hotel definitely seemed more business-like, and I felt a little awkward negotiating around the well-dressed salarymen in shorts and a t-shirt, but considering the low price we paid and the high quality of the hotel I'd absolutely recommend tourists to make this their base of operations.

The hotel is conveniently located just 2 blocks away from the subway and walking distance to the imperial palace/gardens. It is suuuper clean and comfortable. The standard room (cheapest fare) has a very decent size. It is quiet, comfortable, and if you get a high floor you'll have an amazing view of the city. The downside is that the area around the hotel hasn't got restaurants nerby so you'll have to eat somewhere else. They also don't exchange foreign currency, so bare that in mind if you don't have yens at hand. I had a very pleasant stay here, though next time I might look for a hotel near omotesando just to have places at hand to have a bite before going to sleep after a long day.

We stayed in this hotel 4 nights in April 2015. The hotel is modern, clean, the room has a small refrigerator, an electric kettle, hairdryer, slippers. The hotel is whithin a short walk from a metro station.There is a spectacular view from the window.We will definitely return to this hotel

We stayed here at our first visit to Tokyo.We didn't realize that Tokyo Hotel rooms were so tiny. So this hotel's rooms were pretty small which is their standard. So that's fine.This hotel has a nice lobby, nice staff, very clean, neat, organized.We really enjoyed our stay here.Bathroom was small too but ergonomic and had good amenities so it worked well.Right as we were checking out, I realized I got very sick with food poisoning but at the time I had no idea what was happening b/c i've never had food poisoning before so it was that I ended up all of a sudden I was like I was paralyzed and couldn't move so I laid on their lobby chairs. No idea where i got the food poisoning from as my husband ate the exact same foods as me. It wasn't from this hotel for sure b/c we never ate there.So I laid there for like 20 mins b/c i thought i'd be able to move again soon and we had plans to meet my friend before we headed off to Hong kong that day, but I still couldn't move. The hotel staff saw and was really nice and offered for us to stay back in our hotel room that we just checked out of for as long as I needed.I felt so terrible that I threw up on their floor right as we're in the hallway right before we made it back to the room. eeeeekkk.... I had no idea i was going to throw up.It was a crazy experience.This hotel was so nice about it and I'm sure it was so gross to clean up, but they were very understanding and kind and didn't make me feel bad about it.They were very helpful.This was a wonderful stay and we highly recommended this place!Price is very reasonable as well.Good quality hotel & stay!=)

Magnificent view of the city and Chiyoda Park from the room. The night view is also stunning as we could see Tokyo Tower and the city lights. The location is just great. Only few minutes away from the metro line Hanzomon (exit 1) - purple colour line, Tokyo National Theatre and not too far away from Yasukuni Shine. Excellent service, the room is very clean and comfortable with good wifi line. Small local restaurants around the area is worth trying. I definitely recommended this hotel. Can't wait to go back there !

We recently stayed at this hotel for a week at the end of an extended stay in Japan. This hotel is a 5 minute walk from Hanzomon station exit 1. While exit 1 has four flights of stairs it is much closer that exit 3 which has the lift ( still quite close though). The sign to the hotel is immediately opposite Exit 1, directly across the pedestrian crossing.We enjoyed a very comfortable room on the 14 th floor with panoramic view of the Imperial Palace Gardens and towards the Maranouchi area of Tokyo. We overlooked the National Theatre, the Diet and Tokyo Tower in the distance. Spectacular views at night.Hanzomon station is convenient to other link in with other subway lines eg for getting to Ginza, Shibuya, Asakusa and Shinjuku.For the great rate we had through Booking.com, we certainly recommend this hotel to others for its centrality , relative few changes of train when travelling to/ from Narita and the views!Hotel staff are very professional, many speak English and a high standard exists.Breakfast was included in our tariff and while adequate there are limited choices from the set menus.There is a number of quaint local restaurants nearby, as well as many convenience stores. Staff can direct you to a neighbouring coin laundry. Walking is a great activity to do in the environs, especially around the palace.

The value was beyond our wildest expectation. For what we paid in peak season, we had a rather large twin bedroom up on the 17th. floor with magnificent views of the Palace grounds. Very very comfortable beds. Excellent amenities provided.I must say the staff were all very helpful, without any exception. Language was not a problem at all. We felt so humble when the lady at check-out actually accompanied us to the taxi and waved us goodbye. We usually expect this from a bed n breakfast host.We did not try the restaurants but did have our breakfast there. The choice was limited, quite out of keeping with the class of the hotel. We saw a lot of business people. Maybe they were all satisfied with a simple breakfast. Mind you, there was really nothing wrong with the breakfast. It was good value, a la carte, although a buffet would be my preference.Please take good notice of what I have to say about the location. You will not be in the centre of activities, like the bustling Shibuya or right in the middle of Shinjuku. But u will find yourself with the peace and tranquility area near the Imperial Palace. Like a quiet oasis right in the middle of busy Tokyo.So it really suited us as we like an early morning walk right around the palace moat, wonderful and blissful 1.5 hours it took us.Yet, u are so close to Hanzomon subway station, which will whisk you to anywhere in Tokyo in next to no time. There are many good restaurants nearby. We love Indian food that is halal and we can recommend Siddique (just walk south once out of Hanzomon exit 1) and Mother India around the corner north east of exit 1. There are a variety of other nice restaurants too. The neighbourhood is very peaceful.I think we found the perfect location in Tokyo.

I would give this hotel top rating for the size of room (we had a deluxe twin bed room on . 17th floor), the cleanliness, the wonderful sleep with comforable pillows and overall atmosphere. However we found the reception staff to be less than friendly compared to other hotels in Japan and unhelpful when looking for an english menu for two of the restaurants in the hotel.

Staff very helpful. Couldn't do enough for you.Speak very good English.Breakfast very good.Excellent dinner in the hotel restaurant.Lovely clean hotel, in a lovely clean city.Hotel is very popular so try to book early, we wanted to stay again at the end of our holiday but it was fully booked.Of course as in most Tokyo hotels the rooms are fairly small, although they were larger than we expected.Good free wifi.Exceptionally good selection of toiletries including hair tie, razor, comb etc and even a nightgown. So if you're limited for space you can use a very small overnight bag and save the space for your clothes. We were staying the night before a cruise so didn't have to open the large cases.Very impressed - would definitely stay again.The area was very nice and quiet. Opposite the imperial palace, near the British embassy.The Japanese people were very helpful and although most didn't speak a lot of English they always tried to help, (most spoke a little English).The only thing we had any real problems with was trying to buy train/metro tickets - we found the system very complicated and were never sure which machine to get the tickets from. We almost always had to ask. It seems to be different line different machine. The metro is fairly easy to navigate thanks mainly to the English translations (written and spoken) at very stop and on a lot of the maps.If you want to go out of the city I would suggest tours and book before you go unless you are staying for more than a few days.

Stayed at this hotel for five days before boarding a cruise ship leaving from Tokyo. When arrived in Narita airport we took the limousine bus that left us near by in New Otani hotel and from then took a taxy that charge us $10.00 dollars to the Grand Arc Hanzomon. The room at the hotel was very small but very clean and bed sheets were change every day and supplies of toiletries were refill daily. The view of the Imperial Palace and The Diet Building is amazing. We had breakfast at the hotel and it was very good. There are several restaurants in the area. We in particular enjoy a Indian restaurant Mother India in front of the Hanzomon line station gate number 3, we also had a relax coffee break in a nice bakery located out side in front of gate 4. For those arriving with luggage there is an elevator near gate 4 of the Hanzomon line. The staff at the hotel was very helpful answering our questions. Enjoyed our stay at this hotel very much and had a wonderful stay at this beautiful country of Japan and its friendly and polite people.

The Hotel is good value in an expensive city. Rooms are well sized and have nice views. They are nothing fancy but are comfortable and quiet. The location is decent but you will need to change lines to be close to Hanzomon line. It is only a 5 minute walk to the station.

This modern mid-price hotel is located in a calm and leafy location on the west side of the imperial palace. My small room was adequate and well insulated. There was a good Japanese breakfast, and a western option. Overall I felt that the hotel was a little sterile, with few decorative flourishes to pep up the predominantly bare and beige rooms and public areas.

Truly, this hotel is indeed incredible. I only stayed for a night to be honest, my last night in fact. My perfect view of the Palace from my hotel room was indeed amazing and a moment I can't seem to forget even to this day.

After reading the reviews I booked this hotel for my fiancee and I because of the price. Although cheap, this hotel packs a punch. Service was amazing and we were greeted every time with a smile. My limited Japanese combined with the staff's limited English was more than enough to get by. Rooms were a little small, but that is a given in Tokyo. Close to train station (Hanzomon Station on the Hanzomon line) and Imperial Palace. This is a business district in Tokyo, so not ideal if you're after nightlife, however, Shibuya is only 4 stops away on the Hanzomon line,so perfect to party it up and still get back for a quiet night's sleep. WiFi is also available for free everywhere in the hotel. Overall we loved the experience and would happily stay again.

Stayed two nights in mid-April and paid just JPY 10,500 per night (USD 90) for a “Semi-Double” room (small queen-size bed), including tax and service and free wifi, but not breakfast. Excellent value for such a central location in Tokyo, with amazing views across the Imperial Palace grounds from the room. However, this was a good rate through agoda.com, via tripadvisor.com, and I expect standard rates are much higher.Most of the rooms are in the outward facing arc of the building, which looks towards the Palace grounds, but note that some are at the back, facing on to non-descript streets.The room was of a reasonable size, by Tokyo standards, and everything was perfectly clean. All facilities and gadgets worked as they should. My flight landed early morning and they couldn’t or wouldn’t let me check in early, but there was no issue to leave my bags, grab a fairly-priced breakfast in their restaurant, before I headed out for the morning.The hotel seems quite new (maybe five years) but is well maintained. The lobby is a bit gloomy but the staff are helpful and welcoming.I had pre-booked a different hotel for my third and fourth nights, in the Asakusabashi area, but now wish I’d stayed at Grand Arc for all four.Not only is the hotel the closest tourist-price hotel you’ll find to the Imperial Palace running circuit, it’s also just a 3 minute walk to Hanzomon subway station, which will easily get you anywhere you want to go in Tokyo. Note that if arriving at TCAT, after landing at Narita or Haneda, the day-time taxi fare from TCAT was JPY 2,100 for me.

Very close to the Underground station so easy access to most of the city.Quiet neighbourhood and a little far from the main sights/zones of the city.Small (as are most) room but comfortable bed and good wi-fi.Breakfast was included and was OK.We got a great price for a 3-star because of booking early.Staff were pleasant and helpful.

Let's me start with facts Tokyo is very expensive land yet again not more then NYC and the room of our hotel in Tokyo was sheer post size. The service was ok I mean we only stayed one night but it was too long!The bed the tiny full bed was attached to the wall: on the length side !! So in order for me to go to the bath room I needed to Maneuver my body and get ready to the 2020 Olympic The room was old looking and the bath tub is good for children ! In all I will say not recommended however it was not expensive ! So we paid 110 dollars a night in Tokyo I must shut up

Happy with the hotel and bedroom. Efficient desk staff. Good bathroom with loads of toiletries provided. An extra basin and mirror in the bedroom area gave us extra space for getting ready. Good wifi. Fantastic city views. Plenty of lifts. Less than five minutes walk to the Metro, but also only about 20 minutes downhill to the entrance of the Imperial Palace. Breakfast was included in our deal but this was only a choice of American, Continental or Japanese. A buffet is always preferred.

We stayed here for four nights immediately on our arrival in Japan (before moving on to Kyoto) and were more than happy with the hotel.We arrived mid-morning because of the flight and so our rooms were not ready, which was expected and no problem. The hotel looked after our bags while we had a lovely lunch in their outside part (the weather was beautiful) and when we went back and checked in, our bags had already been delivered to the rooms.The staff were all extremely good - we did not have plug adaptors but these were provided immediately. The wifi was excellent. The rooms were spacious and clean. The toilets were amazing (with the bidet facility built in :-) ).Although I smoke, I hate smoke in the bedroom and so was happy that all the rooms seemed to be non-smoking and there was a great smoking area just outside the main door.The view from the rooms was great (overlooking the Imperial Palace park) and the area round the hotel was lots of great restaurants and cafes.A very short walk from the metro (and despite our trepidation having read about the crush, we had no problems with the metro at all).We will certainly visit Japan again and will certainly stay at this hotel!

This is a very modern hotel. Rooms are quite small but very clean and the view we had was amazing. There was floor to ceiling glass and after watching the beautiful city lights at night we were lucky enough to wake up to a light snow shower which looked amazing. We stayed here one night before leaving for home and enjoyed it very much although with the size of the room I don't think I would like to stay for a length of time.

We stayed here two nights during spring blossom season. The hotel overlooks a big park with a beautiful lake and lots of Sakura. We had flown from London for 12 hours so were very jet lagged when we arrived. The hotel has a lovely grand lobby and rooms are easy to get to via lift. The bathroom had all the toiletries you could need. I won't bother packing a toothbrush next time I visit Japan as every hotel I stayed at provided several. The toilet seat was heated which was really nice as my legs were exhausted from walking around so much. We had booked a small double bed and I was really worried our feet would not fit or it would be too cramped. The bed was actually quite big so this wasn't a problem. TV was pretty limited, You could buy a tv card for 1000 yen per day. This didn't buy much but if you are craving English speaking TV you may catch something. The view of the park from our room was really nice especially at night. We would definitely stay here again and felt alot safer at night in this area as opposed to Shinjuku.

We stayed here for 5 nights in April. The hotel is clean and the view from the room at 9th floor is amazing. The bed is comfortable. There are walking trails across the street from the hotel. There are several restaurants nearby. The hotel is very close to the Hanzomon station. Be sure to use Exit 1. If you have a lot of luggage, you can use exit 3 or 4 where the elevator is located. The walk from exit 3 or 4 to the hotel is about 10 minutes, but it is flat. There is also a post office nearby where you can get cash. I will definitely stay here again.

My partner and I enjoyed our stay at this hotel. The rooms were spacious, especially for Tokyo standards. Our room was well appointed and had a superb view of the Imperial Palace gardens which were just across the street. The hotel is in a convenient location right in the centre of Tokyo, making it a great place to base your trip. You can get around the city easily via the metro with Hanzomon Station only about 10 mins away.We would not recommend the breakfast in the lobby restaurant. We were offered a ham roll with a bit of sliced fruit and weak percolated coffee, one of the most dismal hotel breakfasts I have ever experienced. Although the night before the dinner at the same restaurant was perfectly fine, so it's a good option if you arrive at the hotel late.The other disappointing aspect was the staffs' inaccurate advice regarding access to the airport. They advised that the cheapest way to get to Narita Airport was by using the limousine bus service. In fact, it was considerably cheaper, more comfortable and much faster to catch the Skyliner express train from Ueno Station which you can reach by the metro.

I had a room over looking the Imperial palace. When I arrived at the hotel, the lobby looked old and tired but inside the room was quite nice. Unfortunately, weather wasn't good so I didn't walk around the palace. However, the hotel's main restaurant was facing a lovely garden and food was excellent there. If weather was good, I could have enjoyed viewing cherry blossom while having my lunch. If there was WIFI in the restaurant, it could have been better. I went to a traditional Japanese tea room next door to the hotel and had lovely Japanese sweets. The area is rather quiet for Tokyo and peaceful but very convenient to go to Shinjuku. Shibuya, Ginza and Tokyo Station. A taxi from Tokyo Station to the hotel costs about $20.

I was lucky to stay on the arc itself facing the Japanese parliament, where i could see the road and the emperors palce in the park. The room was brilliant and well looked after and you can hire a laptop for aboy $5 a week, which was great for home TV and radio when you get jet lag at 2am. Staff were great and with three resturants inside and outside and a panoramic bar which you can see the Tokyo tower, changing colours at night time.

Loved the Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon. Beautiful room with a fabulous view Day or Night! It was clean & comfortable with all the extras you could possibly wish for.Nice area that is really convenient to access trains & restaurants etc. It is a lovely location that is quiet & relaxed yet still close to everything. The service was excellent & staff were always attentive & polite. The restaurants within the hotel were great with many options & affordability. Two nights weren't enough :( I can't wait to stay at The Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon again!

We have spent 2 nights there and we had a room with an amazing view on Tokyo!!! The location is perfect, the room is clean, there few very good restaurant around. The service is nice and they speak English very well. Very happy! You should stay there !

I stayed at this location for two nights while doing business in Tokyo and I really enjoyed this charming hotel, with great views of the Imperial Palace, adjacent River and Tokyo Tower. A "roomy" room by Tokyo standards and great food service at moderate prices. Very convenient to go to Shibuya and other main attractions by train; it is truly walking distance to a station.You will feel you are at a five start hotel, paying the Tokyo equivalent of a 3 start. Great value.

We stayed here for 4 nights in February while touring Tokyo and were very impressed by the quality of the accomodation at the reasonable price we paid: quick and efficient check-in (in English); warm, quiet room with wonderful views over the Imperial Palace moat; tasteful , newly updated furnishings; and tasty American or Japanese breakfast included in the price. Clients are mostly Japanese or other Asian businessmen but as tourists we found the location central and convenient to most areas we wanted to visit. Using Hanzamon metro station a few minutes walk away, you can easily travel to Shibuya, Shinjuku, Roppongi and Ginza or walk or jog around the Imperial Palace area.

Location: excellent. 5 stars. This hotel is in the centre of Tokyo, but away from all the hustle and bustle of the main spots. It's only a few short stops on the subway to the crazy action in Shibuya. And only couple of stops to the amazing shopping in Harajuku and Omote Sando. Getting to the nearest metro station (hanzomon) takes two minutes.Room: everything you would ever need! Mini fridge, kettle, tv, comfy bed, bathroom with all amenities and more! We were very happy with our room which we paid the most basic price for. Although it was small (everything is small in Japan) we felt very comfortable and not squished at all.Bonuses: keep asking through the booking phase for a room on the higher floors. Our view on the 16th floor was insanely amazing. Also, they have free wifi all around the hotel and it works better than my wifi at home. 5/5.

This is more Hotel than packed small rooms stereo type "Business Hotel" in Japan. Room reminded me of smaller size of sleek 4-Star hotel. Bath room, and furnitures were clean, nice and very neat. Bed was not as cushion soft as the Hotel's bed in the US, but was pleased and comfortable. Washlet toilet seat was nice and clean. (Washlet toilet seat is standard in vest majority of Hotels, Business Hotels and in public restrooms in Japan.) Interior designs were upscale and classy. User-friendly Safe, nice flat screen TV, good design nearly silent refrigerator, a small coffee table and nice chair. Heater was library silent and kept me very warm all night. Room was small, but I felt very specious and comfortable. ( I am 6-feet tall.) There was large suite case folding stand and a big enough wardrobe with many hangers. Hotel staff were very humble, respectable and friendly. Restaurants were available inside Hotel. There were convenient store, Bento (Lunch box) store, Ramen noodle restaurant and some more stores near by Hotel. My room was Single room type B. I paid approximately US$90 a night. And there was Free WiFi. I will stay at this hotel again, if I have to go near Tokyo station. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone, Japanese national or foreigner. By the way, I took Taxi between Tokyo station and Hotel. About 10~15 minutes and cost was 1,070 Yen.

Check in/out was fast.Easy to reach from Hanzomon station (purple color Tokyo metro subway line), exit the ticket gate and turn left till the end, walk up a high staircase and once you reach the road level, go straight across the road and you will find a board direction to the hotel. It is nearby, just 5 mins walking.Hotel was clean and big enough for two. Many Toiletries are provided. Vending machine every floor (beer, softdrink, tea, coffee, etc).Location is great, near to Tokyo Imperial Palace, and the view from the room is absolutely beautiful. Tokyo tower on your right, and beautiful river and garden from palace on your left.Very worth the money. glad to be back.

We stayed in December 2014 through the busy Christmas period. The hotel room was a very decent size (especially compared to where we later stayed in Osaka). We had a lovely view of the palace and the staff were helpful. Overall a very comfortable stay and we would be looking to book this hotel again for our next visit.The station is very close to the hotel. It is not on the most convenient line, but does go straight to Shibuya. As mentioned in another, the ATM in the station accepts foreign cards, which was convenient for emergency cash withdrawals.

My wife and I loved our stay at this hotel. We agree with all the wonderful things people have to say. One thing that hasn't been mentioned but is so nice is that Hanzomon station has an ATM that accepts foreign cards. With Japan being a mostly cash economy, you need to have plenty on you. However, ATMs in general are not that common and those that accept foreign cards are even harder to find. Choose this hotel for your stay and you won't be disappointed.

Rooms are clean and modern. We stayed on the 9th floor so had a good view. Close to Hanzomon station so you can get anywhere easily. Vending machines on each floor. Staff are friendly, check in and out was a breeze. The bed is small (double) so beware if you are a little larger. Free wifi that works great. The only negatives are the pillows were horrible and there aren't many food options close by. Would stay here again

A seven week journey around the east, so needed the hotel to be decently priced, in which this was in comparison to a lot of other decent hotels in Tokyo. Location was perfect, metro was literally a 2 minute walk which lead directly into the city.Welcome was simple and straight forward as was check out. Would definitely stay here again.The rooms are compact but did the job. The views were amazing from our room, watching the sunrise when you get in from a night out at 6am was priceless.Bathroom shower was really powerful and after a very long journey from hs UK was needed.Didn't eat here so can't comment on restaurant, however they do have vending machines in the hall way, which can be handy.Thank you for a pleasant stay.

Nice location for see The Imperial palace close to Honzomon subway station, very peaceful place and very good staff service, Good view from the room and breakfast start at 7:00 am -9:30 am only. Guest will get 10% discount for Bar in hotel that open tills 11:00 pm

A second visit to this hotel & the quality is still high.I was on the 15th floor with a great view over the city.The rooms are more spacious than so in Japan.The free wifi is reliable and if needed a laptop can be hired.For those who want a little more than the vending machines offer there is a 7-eleven close by.While the Metro is a short walk away I was making use of Tokyo station about a miles walk around the Imperial Palace.I had an early checkout, via the night porter and was directed out as the main doors where locked, so be careful if you are returning late.

We stayed here at the start and end of our trip in Japan and it was absolutely superb! Really could not find fault in it. All the staff were very pleasant and polite (obviously, it's Japan), the breakfasts were simple but tasty and everything was spotlessly clean.The rooms were superb, very comfortable beds. All the amenities you need in a room, lovely bathroom.We booked through booking.com and I don't know if they get a special on the park side of the hotel but the views overlooking the park and the city are absolutely breath-taking day and night! pictures do not do justice to it.You are only 5 minutes walk to Hanzomon station which is only connected to the Hanzomon line but subway travel is so efficient and fast in Tokyo it takes you no-time to get from A to B in this city.Would highly recommend this to anyone and if I ever return to Tokyo I wouldn't look anywhere else.

Ok hotel, not great but not bad. Air conditioning didn't work properly so even in December the room got super hot in the morning sun. Room was small and clean. We didn't need any bigger so this was fine. We had a small double bed which could have been more comfortable. Breakfast was a bit let down. No buffet and especially the Japanese breakfast didn't meet our expectations. Over cooked salmon and just generally not good for even though I like Japanese food.Location was good and very close to the metro station. Note that if you're traveling in Sunday not many of the restaurants are open in the evening. We had difficulties in finding a nice restaurant. What ever you do don't go to the Korean bbq house opposite to the metro station. Exceptionally bad food!To sum it up, ok for a couple of nights but nothing more. I wouldn't come here again

Have stayed at Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon for 7nights while we were in Tokyo.- Around 45mins from Haneda Airport (need to change train - 2x)- Around 45mins to Disneyland & Sea- Around 15mins to Shibuya- Around 30mins to Shinjuku (need to change train - 1x)- Overall the travelling time is around 30mins - 45mins to those popular desitnatons.- 5mins walk from Hanzomon subway station.- Outside the subway station, there is a café that served nice & decent breakfast; - There is also an outlet served nice Bento & rice dumpling (open @ 8.30am & closed @ 11pm)- Not to forget, there is an 24/7 convenience store as well.- Tokyo Grand Palace is just across the street of this hotel but it's better for you to check the direction with the hotel staffs to avoid heading to the wrong direction- National State Theatre is also just around the corner - 5mins to 8mins walkThose that love shopping, do dropped by Omote-sando (Subway station Z02 / G02 / C04); Is a nice shopping area that featured both big brands as well as other brands.Overall:- The staffs are very polite & helpful- Stayed at 13th floor with great views- Size of the rooms are pretty decent (not too big or small)- Rooms are clean up & fresh towels are changed daily- No room service menu - Reasonable price for great location & services.Important Note:For those who are travelling with kids or teenage & are sleeping in a separate room from the parents/adult, do take note that the TV in the room do have pornographic programs. You may want to educate your children to avoid pressing that particular button on the remote control to access to that particular channels.

The hotel is pretty much in the middle of everything. Great access to the metro (Hanzomon line) only 5 minutes walk from the hotel but also within walking distance of tokyo station (probably half an hour or so). The room is small but has everything you need (really if you are doing Tokyo right you wont spend much time there). We were on thr 15th floor and had an amazing view over the imperial palace gardens and could see the tokyo tower. Room was cleaned daily with fresh towels etc and we had a shower, bath and electronic toilet. Vending machines with drinks including beer, soft drink and coffee were on the floor too. The hotel is surprisingly quiet. Breakfast isn't anything to rave about, but its still a handy way to start the day. Its served downstairs until 9am and you have a choice between a western breakfast (eggs bacon coffee etc) or a more traditional japanesd style breakfast (rice, fish, miso soup etc). Service is great at the hotel. The staff speak english and are very helpful if you have any questions about getting around tokyo. We arrived before check in but were still allowed to check into our room. as we had a late flight out the staff were very accomodating in assisting us to store our bags until we left for the airport. I highly recommend this hotel, such a great price and quality hotel!

I have staid three nights at the Gran Arc Hanzomon Hotel. The room was not very big, but big enough for one person in the city of Tokyo. It's located next to the emporers Palace and the national state theatre. Only three hundred meters to get to the subway station of Hanzomon. It was very easy to get to the hotel from Haneda airport, just two times changing the train, after 45 minutes I arrived safely at the hotel. Since Hanzomon is more likely a business district, there is not much going on in the neighborhood at night. But you will still find some nice restaurants and cafés, supermarkets etc next to Hanzomon subway station. I really enjoyed my stay. Next time I come to Tokyo I will try and get a room at this hotel again.

Best keep secret - Hotel in middle of Tokyo - next to the Imperial Place.Cater to mostly Business folks but the Tourist get the best deal.Room large for Japanese standards - medium for Travelers from USA - plenty of room.Early morning coffee before 7 - have to go out of Hotel.Subways near by as is National Theater & Supreme Court.

The Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon is small, elegant, and scrupulously clean. Run by the Imperial the service is top notch. It is an excellent place to just stay or hold a conference. It is located next to the palace grounds (moat) and a 5km walk/run around the perimeter is a a lovely way to start the day. Ant-clockwise is the norm unless you like being the lone wolf.The breakfast is excellent, especially the Japanese breakfast, they will absolutely strive to meet any meal request however exceptional the diet.On a Japanese or global scale this hotel ranks high, not opulent or gaudy, but a quiet level of excellence.

Anjin_San_99
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel is well located. The next Metro-Station Hanzomon can be reached within 5 minutes walking distance. We had booked a standard twin room which was not very spacious but really ok. The bed (120cm large) is definitely too small for two large adults. The great view to the imperial garden was quite a compensation though. The only thing we would improve is the breakfast. You have the choice of three different type of breakfast (2 continental and 1 japanese). Eating the same breakfast during one week is not really enjoyable. This hotel seems to be a typical business hotel with conference rooms and customers might stay only one night or two only. Probably an explanation for the lack of variaty.

Fantastic location to metro lines. Quiet area thats full of life just 2-5 mins walk to the most quaint bars and restaurants. The service is so friendly and helpful made a lot of great recommendations and helped with direction with a map to find everything you need. Next to the national theatre. On the same street is a cute sento I reconmen you check it out bring you own towel, fantastic cheap local experience, local patrons are so friendly. Next to the imperial place and just devine view of the gardens and reppongi City scape. Best bathroom every seen in a hotel. Really surprising since we didn't know what to expect and has really made our stay in tokyo.

The location of the hotel is really convenient for getting to many of Tokyo's points of interest. The Hanzomon train station is only a 2 min walk from the hotel and will take you to Shibuya on one side and the Tokyo Skytree on the other. With making only 1 change to can get to loads of places including Ropongi, Shinjuku, Odaiba and more.The only location issue we had was getting to the hotel from the airport. My recommendation would be to get the N'EX to Shibuya and switch to the Hanzomon line to the hotel.The local area is very quiet and peaceful. points of interest nearby are the Imperial Gardens, The National Theatre and the Japanese Diet building (parliament).We stayed in the Japanese style room which was fun for the first night but I wouldn't recommend it for many nights if you aren't used to it as its basically speaking on the hard wood floor. My other issue with the Japanese style room is that I prefer to be able to just come into the room and flop on the the bed but you can't do that as they pack the beds away during the day.The room it's self was fantastic, clean and with an Amazing view of the city and the Imperial gardens and was fairly large for a Japanese hotel room.The restaurant at the hotel was ok but you would do better to eat out in my opinion. The bar is well worth a visit as the staff are great and the views are spectacular.Over all we were extremely happy with this hotel which we thought was fantastic value for money.

We stayed 2 nights prior to our SE Asia cruise out of Yokohama. We loved the location, easy to get to everything. Staff provided us with a jogging/walking path map around the Imperial Palace which we used on a beautiful Sunday morning where we encountered many walkers and joggers along this beautiful route. Friends of ours also stayed here and walked down the hill and took in 4 Kabuki plays at the National Theatre on a rainy day. Rooms are provided with small refrigerators and small pot for heating tea and instant coffee. Big screen flat TV, ask the staff to help you get an English speaking BBC news channel (hidden on the remote). We ate 2 nights at the downstairs main restaurant, which was good, serving mainly Western style food. There is also a mezzanine level restaurant which our friends visited for evening cocktails. I recall the desk telling me this was a 15-year-old hotel and it is apparent that it does cater to business people. Be aware that the beds are quite small - quite sufficient for one person but can be somewhat uncomfortable for 2 people. Staff is very efficient and wants to please. We would stay here again.

My family and I stayed in two rooms in the Grand Arc Hanzomon for three nights while visiting Tokyo, prior to a SE Asia cruise from Yokohoma. The staff were efficient, polite, helpful and friendly, even calling a taxi company in Osaka to assist with an online booking I had made for later in the holiday. My wife and I had a standard double room that was more spacious than I was expecting and had a good view over the Imperial Palace with a decent bathroom and everything you would expect of a good modern hotel e.g. fridge, room safe, Air-Con and flat-screen TV. My adult offspring shared a triple traditional Japanese style room which was not so spacious and involved putting the Japanese beds away during the day; there was also a not so pleasant smell in this room, which we attributed to the bamboo matting on which the mattresses were placed for sleeping. We ate in the restaurant on two nights, due to Typhoon Vongfong preventing us from eating out; the menu was a bizarre mix of Japanese and Western dishes including a number of German choices and between the five of us we tried several different dishes which were all pretty decent. Be aware however that the restaurant closes quite early in Western terms so we were unable to order dessert on the first night as it had gone past 21:30. We also ate breakfast in the hotel on all three mornings and again they had a decent selection of Japanese and western choices such as fried or scrambled eggs on toast with ham or bacon but strangely garnished with carrot and cauliflower! The hotel is only a five minute walk to the metro station and there is also a convenience store, a couple of restaurants and a good French bakery in the same area. There is a small business area with a couple of PCs with internet access for guest use but these cost JPY100 for 5 minutes! There are also a couple of different restaurants and bars but opening times vary depending on the day of the week. Overall this hotel suited our requirements and I would have no hesitation in staying here again.

I've stayed at this hotel several times over the past five years. The service is always excellent, but I keep coming back for the views. The views of Tokyo are just incredible. This hotel is also conveniently located, super reasonably priced, and has a nice breakfast available. The bar is also a great place to relax and take in the views of the city.

New York City, New York

review_body: Nice hotel near Subway Station Hanzomon. Room small for western standards (as expected) and it was clean, staff was friendly, good location near Hanzomon line and within walking distance to the Imperial Palace. Breakfast was good, but it wasn't buffet. I would stay there again.

Directly across from the Imperial Palace, Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon is in the heart of Tokyo. The hotel provides comfortable rooms, with free Wi-Fi and features 4 restaurants. The Tempura restaurant in the lower level is authentic Japanese. Near subway stops. I have made numerous business and pleasure trips to Japan. This was a short trip to enjoy some of what I most enjoyed in the past. Great value for Tokyo.

For the people that have traveled a lot, this is the place to stay. This hotel is clean, convenient and inexpensive. I understand that they are people that look for Ritz Carlton services when they travel. I personally have stayed in many hotels from Ritz Carlton to a Motel 6 in the US. I prefer a clean hotel with a great location. I don’t care so much about anything else. Having said that, this hotel has everything that you can ever ask for a hotel. It’s clean. It’s a great location. It’s quiet. It’s easy to get to and yet inexpensive. For those that think that the room is small in the hotel, let me tell you something. In Japan, this is what you get. I have stayed in Hilton Tokyo and Western Tokyo,. They both have bigger rooms than the Grand Arc Hanzomon. But they are much more expensive and out of the way to the city. In my opinion, if you travel to a foreign country, a big hotel is very unimportant. What is important is the location and the cleanliness of the hotel. Let me tell you. I have stayed in Grand Arc several times and I would stay there gain any five stars hotels that I’ve ever stayed in Japan.

This stylish hotel is located near the Imperial residence, well the opposite side of the entrance though but still. The atmosphere is very safe and quiet, not as convenient as staying near Shinjuku or Tokyo station, but the view to the Imperial residence is impeccable.However, the bedding situation is not as elegant as the exterior. The bedding reminds me of the famous chain budget hotels in Japan, Toyoko Inn. Very thin layer of mattress and no comforters, only duvet cover with a sheet in between. Exactly what Toyoko Inn provides with the customers. Very disappointing offer from a fancy hotel.

I can only say one word - SUPERB!!! One of our best hotel experience ever! Truly great place for stay, excellent value for money and perfect base for exploring amazing MEGA city of Tokyo! Hotel is spotless clean, staff is more than polite and helpful, breakfast excellent... Hotel is situated very near to Hanzomon metro line so it is very easy for you to go to any place in Tokyo. We had room on 15th floor with amazing view of the city and really it was AMAZING... esp at night! No words to describe how happy I am with the fact that we choose this hotel for our stay in Tokyo... Truly recommended and without any doubt if I ever come to Tokyo again I know where I will stay!

Visited Tokyo in June 2014 for a week and stayed at this lovely hotel. Nearest station is only a 2 minute walk away and many places of interest are easily accessed. The hotel staff were very friendly and helpful and even spoke English. The rooms were a reasonable size and had great views of the imperial palace gardens and Tokyo tower. I would definitely stay here again and recommended anyone else to do so.

Just came back from Japan. I have stayed in this beautiful hotel for 5 days. Simply one of the best hotels that I have visited lately abroad. Reception stuff is very kind, helpful and polite. Rooms are comfortable, clean and supplied with all things you need. Breakfast is also very good. Every floor has vending machines, ice machine. Position is excellent. Subway station, Hanzomon is 5 minutes walk. They were changing our towels and sheets every day.And of course, if you are lucky, like we were to have magnificent view on Tokyo from the 15th floor. We had no problems with hotel stuff for any question. As far as I am concerned I would recommend this hotel with no hesitation. Thank you for making us feel like we were at home. Wishing you all the best and definitely if I ever come to visit your adorable country I will gladly book a room again in Hotel Grand Arc Hanzomon.

I was making a quick stop over in Tokyo and didn't want to spend a fortune so I was very pleasantly surprised by this hotel, The single room I had was compact but it all worked beautifully and what a magnificent panoramic view from the enormous window looking out over the river and Imperial gardens... breathtaking. The food was excellent in the Tempura restuarant they cooked it in font of you... the breakfast terrace had a lovely outlook and the Japanese breakfast was great. ( don't go for the western ) Hanzomon station is two minutes walk away it's small and easy to navigate.and It's only 4 stops from Ginza with one change... easy once youv'e got the hang of it. The neighborhood is a quiet business district but there are a few restaurants around. UNBELIEVABLY good value. Staff are so lovely. and polite but not much English spoken. I no longer review anything on B.C as they don't publish negative comments.

Had a lovely stay while exploring Tokyo for 2 weeks with a friend. Had a deluxe twin room on the 17th floor (make sure you request this when booking for the best views). Room was very spacious for Tokyo, great shower. Room gets warm on a sunny day but the aircon is more than capable of dealing with this. Hanzomon station a very short walk from the hotel which you can get to the action areas of shinjuku and shibuya and was easy to to Haneda airport for the journey home. But as its a business district its nice to come back to peace and quiet after a night out or a long day of sightseeing and suited us perfectly. Free wfi in the rooms. Only reason its not 5 out of 5 is the breakfast could do with a little improving, very basic ham mcmuffin and a small croissant didnt really cut it. Oh and being next to a police station you did hear sirens from time to time. Also the hotel do not do room service (do not make the mistake i did and order a Dominoes pizza on your own online to the hotel- got back late and was starving- this didnt go down well with reception but they let me off the one time haha)Overall pro's out weigh the cons, hotel is great, view from the room was awesome- never got bored of it. Smack bang in the middle of Tokyo and a perfect base to explore the city from. First time i went to Tokyo and would stay there again

Saint Albans, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Clean, near metro stop Hanzomon and 17 USD with the taxi to Tokyo train station. Excellent location, great views! Room was small, like anywhere in Japan, but we still could move around a bit. Facilities were good.not that good:No variation in breakfast. Be smart and book without breakfast.We booked also breakfast but when my husband went ill, i coudn,t take it upstairs for himthey didn't like that my friend came to visit me but she wasn't allowed apparently because of the way she dressed.
This hotel is awesome.Big, clean and with a lot of services.The room was really nice, and there's free Wi-Fi everywhere.It's a 3-minute walk from the "Hanzomon" metro stration.The restaurant is good.

The Grand Arc Hanzomon was a stunning hotel for our first trip to Japan!Upon arrival the staff were very welcoming, and could see were were absolutely exhausted.The hotel isn't overly easy to find, well that depends if you know what Metro station to get off at. Located on the west side next to the imperial palace, the closest station to the hotel is the Hanzomon Metro Station. As soon as you exit Hanzomon it is a two minute walk to the left (east).We had booked a Deluxe Twin room (highly reccommended) and they immediately got our reservation and withing 5 mins and making the payment we got our keys to the room. The room was huge by Tokyo standards with a spacious living area, great bath (wet bath so water will flow out and drain on floor as they do in Japan), we receieved the standard slippers and robe as well as a welcome pack explaining the hotel and what to do. We had breakfast included so we received breakfast coupons as well.The room had plenty of supplies as in shampoo, soap etc and upon request they would give us what we needed. The TV had free channels plus the option of some pay channels that required a 1000yen top up card to slot in the TV, they show for free for around 2 mins then require the top up card. These pay channels were basically more up to date movies and porn channels :pThen again when in Tokyo why bother sitting around watching TV.Room service was brilliant, they clean up the room top to bottom, (other than under the actual bed, which was a bit dusty, but im nit picking) and replenished the shampoo etc.The breakfast itself was a set menu containing 3 american style breakfasts and one Japanese breakfast. I had to have only the Japanese breakfast as I do no eat meat, only fish, the breakfast though was very well made and tasted wonderful. They are very strict with timings though and breakfast was from 0700 to 0930. Outside food in there is a no no, but that is to be expected, you can however bring in and eat whatever you want in your room.The staff were by far the best part, they were extremely helpful with local directions and amenities, and especially when helping us find our way on first and last train to Kyoto for the day.Also when leaving they organised a taxi to take us back to Tokyo station to get the Narita express for Narita airport.The general warm feeling from staff made the whole trip feel great.Location is great, right next to the imperial palace, the general area is quite quiet, right near Hanzomon Metro station.The only thing is to get to the main districts eg. Asakusa, Akihabara, Shibuya, Shinguku, take maybe one or two connections, but as Hanzomon is so central it takes under 20 mins or less to get to the further destinations.Great staff and service, clean room with great view and space (Deluxe Twin room), great breakfast though slightly limited and great locationWould highly reccommend to any first time travellers to Japan, will definitely look to book again for my next visit!!

We were delighted with this place. The location, very near the subway across from the imperial gardens, is superb. We had a lovely view over the moat and a reasonably spacious room at a modest ( for Tokyo) price. The place is very quiet & clean with free wifi and helpful English speaking reception. There is a very well stocked wine & beer supermarket around the corner. We particularly enjoyed the hi-tec toilets once we discovered how to turn them off! We'll probably stay again when we return to Tokyo.

My kids like this hotel because we managed to get tatami style of bed rooms. So it was good experience for them. The view from the room also nice as we got the view of royal palace. Overall, it was great experiences.

We stayed for five days in a original Japanese style room. We had a great experience and because we had a two year old baby she sleep with us on the tatami.all amazing.Restaurant option on hotel a little old and not great food, but good service and price for Tokyo.Close to metro stations and parks.

It is 10 minute walking from the hotel to subway station. The room is small but it is Tokyo standard. The room cost is cheap comparing to others in the same level.Only one complaint is too small double bed for two person.

We stayed here for 6 nights at this hotel it was excellent.Location of Hotel is convinient,reaching there from Narita was easy.Also it's on Hanzomon station is minutes away by walk and it's a central metro location for travelling..Rooms are compact as per Japan standards but provides all facilities in good rate .Amenities,cleanliness was great.WiFi was free as well in the room.Also the area is nice for stay as it's quite and calm and near Imperial palace.Highly recommended.

This hotel is outstanding! This is definitely a bargain - great breakfast, friendly & polite staff, beautiful location, clean, comfortable & modern rooms and quiet. I would definitely stay here again. The hotel is located across from the Imperial Palace, which is a great place to run (beautiful & safe) and measures 5k. It's a 5 minute walk to hanzomon station and there are several restaurants near the hotel.

This hotel has a truly memorable location with views over the Imperial Palace and the iconic Diet Building. The Hanzomon metro station is literally out the back door and there a number of convenience stores and cafes in the area. It was easy to walk along the track by the palace moat into the Ginza and Tokyo station areas. Our room was a good size with 2 large single beds and plenty of storage. The bathroom was well appointed but it was the view that really made an impression. It was very good value for money.

The Grand Arc Hanzomon has an outstanding location with a great view of the park surrounding the Imperial Palace. I stayed in a Japanese-style room, which was quite interesting (and slightly cramped, as is typical for hotels in Tokyo). The facilities are all very modern. The staff was very friendly, but their comfort level with English was a bit variable. The wifi was complimentary and worked great. The hotel is a just a short walk from the subway. Overall, I enjoyed my stay there.
