review_body: The Grand Arc Hanzomon is a modern luxury hotel located right next to the National Theater and the Imperial Palace. Upper floors have great views of central Tokyo and the Palace park. Rooms are very large and well appointed, staff are friendly and English-speaking, and the hotel restaurants are good and reasonably priced. For business travelers, the hotel is quiet and has fast, free wireless internet. The surrounding neighborhood is quiet, without as much street-life or as many restaurants as centers like Ueno or Shibuya, and the subway while nearby, isn't the most convenient line, but the Palace gardens and theater are great tourist destinations.A real refuge from the bustle of Tokyo in the center of the city.

皇居VIEWは端に少し木が見れる程度でした。「都会の夜景を一望にしながらのカクテル＆バータイムをお楽しみください。」とありましたが、バーは４階のため楽しめるほどの夜景はなくちょっとがっかりしました。そのうえ、とても騒がしかったです。また、誰でも絶対なくては困ると分かるものを部屋に忘れたのですが、何の連絡もいただけませんでした。忘れ物に関しては連絡はしないと言われましたが、連絡をすぐにしてくだされば取りに行けなtのですが、取りに行けずでとても困りました。I was disappointed in the Imperial Palace view room, a noisy bar on the 4th floor, and their unthoughtful service. They didn't even have the courtesy to call me or text me when I left something important in my room.

Nothing to fault with this comfortable place. Room size was practically palace-like considering it was Tokyo. Quick stroll to a subway station and restaurants nearby. It was wonderful going for a jog around the imperial palace which is right in front of the hotel. A++ breakfast

Room size was good even if we got a semi-double room which means the bed was not that big but absolutely enough!excellent toiletries. modern and great wifi service.lots of facilities around (cafè serving very good breakfast, h24 supermarket, metro stop at 2 mins walking distance)Absolutely to be recommend!Great view on the imperial park

Amazing quality for this price. Very good location close to subway but a quite neighborhood with nice restaurant options. Walking distance from imperial palace and museum of modern art. We ate once at the hotel restaurant great service and food was great price fair. The view was amazing and Japanese stile room was trendy buy not so big. I would defiantly stay here again if I am in Tokyo.

Hanzomon area became familiar with me, when I stayed at the hotel. The hotel is located a few minutes away from Hanzomon Sta. on Hanzomon Subway Line. The wonderful thing about this hotel is that Imperial inner moat is just under your nose. The scenery from the window is beautiful. One side is the luscious Imperial Palace greens and the other is modern buildings of Diet, National Theater, Japanese Supreme Court, and so on. Tokyo Tower is also visible. I am not an avid runner, but jogging around the Imperial Palace is the thing to do among runners. I woke up early and walked around the Imperial Palace. You can start your exercise just a few steps away from the hotel. Greens and spaciousness made me forget that I was in the middle of the city. It is a wonderful feeling.I occupied a room with single queen size bed. The room is relatively large. It is equipped with a safe, fridge, tea sets, and toiletry items. There are enough hangers and drawers to put away my clothes. The flower shop refreshes the air in the lobby area, which is simply but tastily decorated.Since the hotel is very close to the subway station, virtually you can go anywhere in Tokyo using the subway lines. I am planning to stay again at the hotel. It is a perfect hotel for me!

Loved this hotel. Rooms we're lovely, really well designed and beautifully finished. Staff were friendly and happy to help. Located 3 mins from hanzomom station, with stunning views from the window. For the quality of the room in Tokyo, I thought the price was good.

Stayed at this hotel in 2013. This was well worth the money we paid. Our double room was clean, of standard and spacious enough considering this is Tokyo. Best part of all, it came with a small lounge area (2 chairs and a table) with a nice view of the imperial palace's moat and garden and a fantastic view of Tokyo city at night (you can see the Tokyo tower). Hotel is located in Hanzomon, which is a pretty quiet district, if you're looking for a place away from the bustle of the city. It's also conveniently located (about 5 mins walk) to Hanzomon subway station, where from there you can easily get to the major train stations (e.g. Shinjuku, Shibuya) via the Tokyo subway in a couple of mins. Definitely recommending this place for the reasons above. And will definitely be staying at Hanzomon again the next time we're paying a visit to Tokyo.

It's an amazing hotel offering fantastic service. Located just in the heart of tokyo, a few minutes away from the Hanzomon subway station and the imperial palace gardens.All services are located around the hotel, along with little restaurants, bars, ramen shops and 7eleven (where they have plenty of snacks).

We travelled as a family of five adults and stayed in three small double rooms. The rooms are quite small but perfectly clean and modern. The views from the large windows are beautiful! You can see the Imperial Gardens with surrounding walls and moat, as well as the business districts of Chiyoda, The Diet and even Tokyo Tower which was lit in red, blue and white as Obama was visiting. Breakfast is a real bargain!The location is excellent with a short walk to Hanzomon station on Hanzomon line which is right in the center of Tokyo's convenient and clean public transportation network. There are also some very good restaurants nearby, including a chinese restaurant halfway to the subway station as well as Spoon (italian) and a great Korean right across from the entrance to Hanzomon station.All this for an incredibly low price, especially considering it is Tokyo! I will definately be staying at this hotel the next time I travel to Tokyo (which is soon I hope).ありがとうございました!

My husband and I stayed in this hotel for our last night in Tokyo after returning from Kyoto. The location is great (right beside the Imperial Palace) and a very short walk to the nearest subway station (Hanzomon). We got a room with an amazing view of the Imperial Gardens and Tokyo. The hotel itself is very nice and clean. We received free drink vouchers upon check-in for use at the hotel lounge, we found out upon redemption that this was limited to coffee, tea or juice :)

It was our first time in Tokyo. We wanted a nice hotel with a Ryokan style room. Its difficult to find a good Ryokan in Tokyo because most of the best Ryokans are in Kyoto. We were lucky to find a good one in this hotel. They also have hotel type rooms. This hotel is huge and the staff are very helpful. Its very near the Hanzomon train station. If you are looking for a quite hotel in Tokyo this is the hotel for you. They even serve Japanese set breakfast that is so good and filling. There is an ice vending machine in every floor. What we loved the most is the view of the Imperial Place and Tokyo Tower from the room. We would consider to book again here on our next visit

I had a price cut when booked for a semi double room, and i was truly on my knees.The hotel is made in a way to give each room a direct panoramic view over Tokyo.My room was irreproachably clean, in the 16th floor with a direct view over a big part of the Imperial palace and over the building in Ginza/Roppongi The staff was helpful and friendly as i left my luggage there even after leaving hotel, they accepted to keep them for a Day while i went to osaka.The rooms are big for Japanese standards, with a panoramic front made of glass.I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo.Only downside it was a little bit far from any Jr station (around 15 minutes walk or more) but there is very close metro lines nearby.The hotel is directly infront of the Imperial Palace and not far from Tsukiji.

We booked the top floor suite and it was way big in Tokyo standards. For a strange reason, it had twin beds as default, and they couldn't change it to a double- so watch for that glitch if you book the suite. Furthermore, it was at the far end of the hotel, so view wise it has more city and less royal castle.Other than that, the room was wonderful, breakfast yummy and the staff helpful and English speaking.

I had planned my trip to Tokyo for 6 months....the big question was where to stay the 9 nights there, other than the next for at a Tokyo Disney Hotel. Having looked for months, I finally decided on this one. And that was the correct decision.As the other reviews say, great location, very quite area,( so if you are into night clubs etc., forget it, this is not your place, ) several food stores and nice family run places to eat. I was in room 1405 which faces the Palace, a super view to be sure. The room was small by western standards, but since i was by myself, it was ok. The bath was normal size and had all the extras that you expect from a 3 plus star place.All of the staff I had contact with spoke enough English to get by, and some spoke it very well. Only at at the restaurant once, and it was fine. I needed to catch a cab on a Sunday morning to get to Disney, and there were none there...they called and one showed up in 5 minutes.Cannot say enough about this place, and for the price and location, you cannot do any better in all of Tokyo.

We stayed 3 nights in april 2014 and really enjoyed it. The room was not big but clean and modern. Breakfast was delicious. The hotel is not central but closed to a subway station. We would definitly go back.

Stayed as a family of four on the 17th (top) floor of this hotel in a "deluxe twin". The beds are "semi-double" size and there's a seating area with a big sofa so we had plenty of room. Very quiet. Beds and pillows very comfortable. Spotlessly clean with nice amenities. The views from the 17th floor are fantastic- looking straight down at the Diet building and Tokyo tower with Odaiba visible in the distance.We weren't as enthusiastic about the location as other reviewers. We arrived with a lot of luggage and a baby buggy and it's quite a march to the hotel from the nearest subway station, especially if you are stuck using the elevator (which is one of the furthest exits). The Hanzomon station is on the Hanzomon subway line (no surprises there, then), which is handy for Shibuya but not an awful lot else. Most trips are going to require a chance of line, which isn't a problem if you're not weighed down with luggage or the dreaded baby buggy but, given that elevators are still not widespread on the underground system and buggies are not allowed on escalators (which aren't always available anyway), you're going to want to change trains as little as possible. There is no direct connection between Tokyo station and Hanzomon- you might want to invest in a taxi if you have a lot of luggage.

This hotel was perfect for our first stop in Japan.Location is fantastic. Really close to the subway which was so handy, and seemed to be on easy lines to access lots of top sights. Also overlooking the palace grounds meant open views across the park which we weren't expecting in the city! Spacious room, very clean and we seemed to get a really good deal so was excellent value for money.Would definitely stay again.

We stayed in a suite at this gorgeous hotel. Very big room by any standard. We were on the 17th floor and the view was amazing.Only a few minutes walk to Hanzomon station where you can be anywhere in Tokyo in a few minutes.  We ate in their restaurant most nights we were there. Food was gorgeous and not expensive at all. Staff were friendly but like all Japan not a lot of a English is spoken.I can highly recommend this hotel.

Pros: location, cost, convenience, stunning views of the palace moat, sufficient breakfastCons: service was erratic to poor. At times the front desk was rude by our standards but this may have been down to cultural differences, we're not sure. One mistake was to fail to stipulate we wanted a non-smoking room, we didn't realise you need to make a special request to avoid being put on a smoking floor. We really noticed the smoke fumes, the front desk was not helpful about the issue. Our do not disturn sign was also ignored once or twice. The rooms are tiny. Overall we'd still stay here again, the location makes it worthwhile and the cost is incredibly reasonable for Tokyo.

A fantastic hotel. The staff are very friendly, helpful and efficient, and speak excellent English. The location is also fantastic, a mere 3 minutes walk from Hanzomon metro station (on the purple Hanzomon line). From this station you can get anywhere in Tokyo within minutes. We were on the 14th floor, and had a superb view over the river and Tokyo tower. And all for a great price. We stayed for 15 nights, and paid about £55 per night. What a bargainThe local area is very peaceful, but there are an abundance of restaurants locally, as well as 24 hour convenience stores at nearly every street corner, which has a great choice of foods and drinks. There is also a local coin laundry (5 minutes walk) to wash and dry your clothes in. Just ask at reception for a local map. The room was quite spacious we found, more than enough space even though we had 4 suitcases! The bed was comfortable and there was air con which could warm the room as well as cool it. There are also vending machines on every floor, and a mini fridge in the room to store your drinks.

This is basically a hotel of very high quality. I would have expected a hotel of this standing to have been much more expensive.As expected in Tokyo, the room was compact but the view over the palace grounds was wonderful. It being a full moon, the view was equally spectacular at night. It's rare to find such a view in Tokyo.And for running fans, you can't beat the location. Going for a run around the palace is a delight.Drawbacks:The only reason I can see for the prices being relatively low is the metro connection. The hotel is only a 3 minute walk from the Hanzomon metro station. The Hanzomon line terminates in Shibuya, but other than that it's not extremely well connected to other popular lines, notably the JR lines. And if you have big bags to carry, the Hanzomon line has a lot of steps to manage.My solution was to pay a ~15$ taxi ride to Tokyo Station and connect to the underground from there.The area is a little quiet at night, but you'll find a restaurant. And perhaps 'quiet' is not a drawback; it can be a relief after a few days elsewhere in Tokyo.

the price was fair, the room and the bed was really small but it was OK, the location was great, the breakfast was not open buffet but it was OK... I think this is the best value for money in Tokyo. No need to stay in Shinjuku!

Chiyoda is a quiet and pleasant residential district offering a selection of bars, cafes, restaurants and 24 hour convenience stores. The hotel is 5 minutes walk from the underground station Hanzomon. The hotel overlooks the imperial palace gardens, and is a short and pleasant walk down hill into Central Nihonbashi and the central Tokyo rail station. A short underground ride to more popular tourist districts. As mentioned in another review, there is a very pleasant jogging route around the imperial palace gardens forming a loop.The rooms are large by Tokyo standards, well appointed and clean. The wifi reception is good and is free. The staff were courteous and helpful.Good value.

My partner and I travelled to Japan for our honeymoon this was our first stop.No one spoke English at all, so we translated via phone. When we asked reception if they could book us on a tour they said no. Our room was extremely small. the only highlight was the view.

The location was better than expected. The hotel was only 3 minutes walk from the station and 10 minutes train ride to Shibuya. The downside is that you have to carry your suitcase up the stairs from the station if you are coming / leaving by way of the train. Otherwise, you can take a taxi to Tokyo station for commuting to and from Narita, which cases about 2500yen one way. The room / bed was small in international standard. I guess it's normal in Japanese standard, though. However, it's very clean and the view is good (overlooking the city and part of the palace). Also, lots of small, local eateries in the area, convenience stores, Japanese drug stores and supermarket within 10 minutes walk in the area. A quiet area but you can get daily necessities easily. Bonus for runners as there's a 5 km track very popular with locals right across the hotel. For the more cultural, the National Theater is right next to the hotel and you can get a ticket to watch kabuki. The price is very reasonable for what it has to offer. Staff are friendly and helpful.

Stayed in a single room for 4 nights here and was very fortunate to get a room with a superb view of the Imperial Palace park and Tokyo skyline. I liked the location of the hotel, it’s just a couple of minutes walk from Hanzomon station and is located in a quiet area of the city. There is also a convenience store and our favourite St Marc Cafe just outside the Hanzomon station. For those who are keen, you can run over to the very popular jogging route around the Imperial Palace from the hotel (it is a 5km loop). I thought that the single room was big enough for Tokyo’s standards, wifi is free and easily available throughout the hotel too; all in all, had a very comfortable stay here and would recommend this hotel if you do not mind staying a bit further from the more popular tourist areas of Shibuya and Shinjuku.

It took me a long time to decide upon a hotel in Tokyo due to how expensive the city seems to be. I think I made a pretty good decision with this place. The location is good, the staff helpful and the hotel is clean and stylish. The only compromise was that our room only had a 3/4 sized bed (as advertised). Although the room was small it could have accommodated a full sized double, so I'm not really sure why it didn't have one.

review_body: Made over night stay at Grand Arc. Got the train at Nagatacho at first, and then realized that Hanzoh-mon station provides much closer access to the hotel. It is almost adjacent to National Museum, and is accessible from/to most places near the Emperor place. Hotel is very clean and quiet. There are some restaurants around (incl. cafe). You may even walk to Yotsuya station in 15 minutes. All in all, it was a pleasant stay and cost performance was, i would say very high.

This hotel delivers excellent value for its price-range and is an "upscale" business hotel, probably compensating for its somewhat boring neighborhood near the imperial palace grounds, various embassies and government offices (including what seems to be police offices next door). It is, however, located near a jogging course around the imperial palace and few minutes from a subway stop, so it is convenient to more "happening" neighborhoods in Tokyo. The set menu breakfasts are very reasonably priced for the quantity and quality (again, probably compensating for the hotel location) and is a nice change from buffet breakfasts generally offered at other hotels (the restaurants overall are decently priced). The staff was generally helpful and nice (except maybe for one snooty person at the front desk when I checked in). Befitting the fact that the UK embassy is close by, the BBC is available on TV.

New York City, New York

review_body: Directly across the road from the palace. Once you cross the road the loop around the palace is approx 5k. The walkway around the palace is perhaps 2 meters wide so lots of room and no traffic to worry about. Next door to the hotel was Tokyo FM, they seemed to have a sign outside advertising "JOGLIS" the Hanzomon runners club. However I didn't try it. The Patio restaurant had an "American" breakfast for Yen 1200 ( approx 10 Euro ). It consists of a small salad, tea or coffee, orange juice, eggs, ham and toast. Very nice. At night the Patio restaurant serves Japanese and "American" food. I had Pizza and beer very nice.The room was small but very comfortable. I had an excellent view from the 14th floor out over the city. Room cost was 11,000 Yen / night including breakfast which seems good for such a nice hotel in a central location. Honzomon station is just around the corner and you need 1 change to get to Tokyo station on the far side of the palace. The area seemed very safe with lots of police in evidence due to the number of embassies and government ministries in the area. Had a nice pint of Guinness in the "Three Thread" English bar about a mile away.

Room turned out to be bigger than expected..great view indeed!Location is great..we had an amazing jogging around the Imperial Palace as a complimentary.You coudn't imagine better...Visited the amazing French restaurant Chez Oliver nearby (~5 mins in taxi). We haven't had brkf in the hotel so i cannot say anything.All good..

Excellent value business hotel within what seemed financial district. No buzz to the location/place, but 3 minute walk to Hanzomon Metro station made up for this. It is located right next to the Imperial palace boundaries, with a nice walk to the gates. If you fancy a walk, this takes you to Ginza after 20-30 minutes.The hotel itself was a standard business hotel. As per previous reviews, do not expect a large bed, it is somewhere between a single and double sized-bed. Otherwise it is clean, though has a dated feel to it. If your budget is tight, or planning to stay out most of the time, definitely have a look at this hotel, as it is very much worth considering.

This is an older hotel, built 15 years ago which my Tokyo standards where most buildings are torn down and replaced after about 20 years. However, generally well maintained.The good, 12th floor and probably others are smoke free, we stayed in room 1213 a Japanese style room rated for three people but it would have been tight. Quite comfortable for the two of us. Very, close 150 feet to the National Theater which is why we picked it. Two longish blocks from exit # 1 of the Hanzomon Station on the Hanzomon Subway Line. We were there on a weekend and only the Patio Resturant was open, good food but not great. The lunch pasta for 830 yen is best avoided unless you like your pasta well past al dente. Dinner is moderately priced and while not Haute Cuisine it is acceptable. I can not speak for the two resturants that were closed one is Washoku style food and the other is tempura.Room thermostat actually works a pet peeve of mine, and the sound of the fan is very low and will not disturb the lightest sleeper.Good view of the southern section of the palace moat, some of the palace grounds, Tokyo Tower, National Diet Building and the roof of the National Theater from our room. However, specify that you want a palace side room as the other wing has a view of a dreary part of the city.Excellent place to stay if you have buisness with the government as it is two stops from Nagatacho, and the National Diet Library, Diet Offices and Supreme Court of Japan. Also it is about 2 blocks to the south of the British Embassy, and 5-6 blocks from Chigoridafuji (The tomb of the Unknown Soldiers) and one subway stop from Yasukuni Shrine.The bad, if you are coming in from out of town and not familiar with the subways it is a $12.00 taxi fare from Tokyo Station, also exit 1 from Hanzomon Station has no escalator and you are a good 3 stories underground a major hike with luggage. The elevator drops you somewhere about 3 blocks west of the British Embassy, look for the flag, walk towards it and when you reach the palace moat turn right and go for another couple of blocks. I suggest not trying it if you are not familiar with Tokyo. I did not spot a lot of taxis except for those in front of the hotel. There was a very good supply of amenities in the room, but the lobby shop does not carry anything except gift items that I saw. There is a convenience store two blocks to the west catty corner from the subway exit though. Beer is available in the hotel vending machines along with a large assortment of soda all at reasonable prices.Basically it is a very upscale business hotel and probably does a huge business during the week when the government offices are open.Nothing really bad though, and the price is right we stayed for $220 including breakfast which is quite reasonable for central Tokyo in a hotel of this caliber.

We stayed here after a 10 day skiing holiday in Niseko for a weekend to have a quick look around Tokyo. We soon worked out the subway/train systems and there is a station (Hanzomon) very close to the hotel. We were on the 15th floor with great views of the Imperial Palace Garden. The rooms had everything you could need and were very clean. The Western breakfasts more than adequate - would have preferred the option of more fruit and yoghurt though. Only mistake is we booked using a travel website months in advance and completely overlooked that there are actually 'smoking floors and rooms' in many Japanese Hotels - ended up in a smoking room which was not very nice at all - would have been nice if the option was communicated to us at check in as by the time we got into the room after travelling all day and lugging skis and snowboards through the subway system (3 trains, on foot and by taxi) we were just too tired to moan about it - would know for next time. But honestly why should you be able to smoke in a hotel at all when most of the parks and shrines around Tokyo are all not only 'outdoors' but also 'non-smoking'? The Staff at Grand Arc were also very helpful in arranging taxis and advising of where things were etc. If in Tokyo again would certainly return - but would make sure of a non-smoking room!

I stayed here once for 5 days in December 2011 and again for one night in December 2013. I still found this hotel to be delightfully clean and quiet, and an exceptional value in one of the world's most expensive cities. I subtracted one star from this review, and as opposed to the 2011 review, because I found the bed to be very firm and didn't sleep very well. I think now my good sleep in 2011 was due to jet lag. Everything else met or exceeded my expectations. If you are looking for a hotel in Tokyo that is away from the most touristy areas, provides an above average quality of facilities and amenities, and is the cost of a La Quinta in the US, I could not recommend the grand arc more strongly. It is less than five minutes from the hanzomon subway station, and once again impressed me in all regards except the mattress.

Stayed leading up to New Year, so some services were reduced. Very well situated, with subway nearby and overlooking Imperial Palace. Room small, but had everything we needed; not much room for luggage though. Had breakfast daily, and it was basic but fine. Not a standard hotel buffet, but it was well prepared and tasty. Staff communicative and efficient. I would definitely stay here again.

We stayed here for four nights in January and after reading all the reviews on here I was expecting an old smokey tiny uncleaned hot room but luckily it was nothing like this! The room was extremely clean and bigger than anywhere else we stayed in Japan. It was all very modern and the restaurant downstairs provided a very decent lunch for a good price. We had a cracking view from the 14th floor of the palace and the bed was comfortable. Plenty of space to store bags and hang things up. Its ideal as a base to explore Tokyo and we booked it at a fairly decent price so it was great value for money. After trawling for ages trying to find a hotel in Tokyo which would suit our needs we were happy we booked this one. At the end of the day if you are on a leisure trip you don't come to Tokyo to sit in your hotel room and therefore this place is ideal. Closest underground is 2 minute walk, but can also get to two other lines within a 15 minute walk to save you changing lines. Easy to get to shinjuku, Tokyo and shibuyu by paying just for one single ticket (don't have to travel on different private lines therefore pay twice) and that's all you need really! Only slight downside was that the room filled with condensation and we had no means to stop this as the window did not open and the air con was all in Japanese hence 4stars instead of 5 (would give 4.5 but TA doesn't allow it!)

I heard this hotel was a very high class hotel for professionals in Tokyo but.......... it is old and need some repairs. The breakfast, that is not included, is not very tasteful, either Japanese and North American style breakfast were very average. We had a japanese style room on the 12th floor. It is small but we knew it at the beginning. One day, we came back to the room and it was not done so we had to make the beds for the night. There is a lack of service and that made me a bit disappointed for that stay. Overall it is not bad but could be better !!!!!

This hotel is great for a quick stay in Tokyo. It is located very close to the Hanzomon station (3 minute walk) which connects you to all the sights of the city. The hotel is very clean and the level of service is very high. Most of the staff are proficient in english. The rooms are small but not uncomfortable. The hotel has several restaurants which are all very good, quite nice if you have had a long day touring the city. The hotel is very close to the Palace gardens which is a great view. Highly recommended hotel.

We booked at last minute, so we paid waaaaaaaaay too much. When we got there they tried to give us a different style room to the one we booked, so after much hassle they upgraded us to a bigger japanese style room (we had booked a double japanese style room, but they tried to give us a western one) which was great, but we had booked a non-smoking room and the room we had was a smoking room, which was unpleasant for us every time we walked into the room, although we got used to the smell.We were here in later November, so going into the colder months, but our room overheated EVERY DAY. So much so that we just physically could not stay in the room during the day, we asked them about it and they said there was nothing wrong with the air-conditioning, but even when we put the gauge on 15c in the morning, the temp would rise to 30c by afternoon, and this was with the japanese style blinds and the curtains shut!! The sun obviously faced our room the entire day, we had a room where the imperial garden was to the left of our window (but still in view) - sorry for the unhelpful description, but we recommend not getting a room facing this way, ESPECIALLY in summer!Also the breakfast was really bad for the price, would not recommend getting that included.

Very nice hotel, very well located, close to Hanzomon Station, various bus Stops, restaurants, markets, etc.Beautiful view of the Imperial Palace park and the city, and beautiful skyline of the city. Great room. Internet included.

I don't have time to make reviews. After all I feel that all my vacations are working vactions trying to take care of my 4 kids. And we are very busy trying to get into many places around the city in all the places we go to. But I must give this hotel a very good one. This is the very first one that I am writing. I am impressed the very first day. The hotel front desk staff Mr. Nakafuji was so efficient, he was ready as soon as I stepped I front of him. Our papers are there and our keys are ready, our rooms are ready and he speaks very good English. I just filled up some papers quickly a d gave my card and immediately we are booked. We went to check our rooms. I was expecting very tiny ones but our rooms are really big according to Japanese standards. And so we cancelled the 3rd room. I expected a penalty of at least a day since that is in my contract with Booking.com- canvel 3 days before and yhe first day will be charged. I told Mr Nakafuji I will just pay for extra person in the room because we can definitely fit one more person in the suite. He was okay with it and I think that he did not charge me for any of both. I was correct because later Booking.com emailed me to say that the hotel waived the penalty.The next night we had dinner in their restaurant and I told the wait staff that I had a headache. Maybe they called him because after 5 minutes, Mr. Nakafuji was there to rescue me saying maybe it was the sake. The view from expectedly the best because it was the Grand Arc Suite. But my boys room was not and they also have the same view.The hotel amenities were overflowing. I liked that they gave us fresh night clothes to wear. Everything was clean and new. The toilet was scary because we are not used to using smart toilets that have lids that open and close by themselves whenever we enter and leave. After a while, I began to appreciate it especially because the toilet seat was heated! The vendo and ice machines were located near our room, plus I appreciate the fact that the ref didnt have anything in it because we like to fill up our ref with various food and fruits we find whenever we go around. Tomorrow we are moving to the Capitol Hotel. We booked 2 different hotels because one of the hotels can't take us in for 2 weeks (fully booked). I am definitely going to miss the view! Thanks, GAH!

This hotel is just a great place to stay in Tokyo. The position is central (close to the Imperial Palace) and close to a metro station, in a quiet and pleasant area. The rooms are quite big, with a comfortable bed and very good toilet and shower. Anyway, the best thing about the rooms is the astonishing view of the Tokyo's skyline and the Tokyo Tower. It's an extremely comfortable hotel, and the price is vey convenient! Just a perfect place to stay in Tokyo.

I don't think I can say anything bad about the Grand Arc Hanzomon.The service from the staff was incredible. Everyone was always very kind and professional. The hotel and our room were absolutely spotless and up-kept (God Bless the Japanese and they're cleanliness). The location was amazing. Right next to the Imperial Palace and Hazomon station. We ate at the little restaurants nearby as well as the 7/11 at times. The view from our hotel room was incredible with both the gardens and downtown Tokyo.I would definitely go back to this hotel if I were to go to back Tokyo.

We stayed here in a semi-double room for five nights and the Grand Arc Hanzomon met our expectaions. As written by many reviewers the hotel is off the major shopping and nightlife districts in the heart of Japan's administrative centre with streets getting really quiet at night. But it was this tranquility we somehow liked for a first time visit to Tokyo. That said, there are plenty of food options in the area. Access to all major transport hubs is easy due to its proximity to the Hanzomon metro station. For directions to the hotel, simply refer to the hotel's website. However, note that if you travel with a lot of luggage a taxi might be a good option; otherwise be prepared to carry all your belongings up some flight of stairs as the Hanzomon station doesn't have any elevators.Unfortunately we weren't given a room with a good view (be it that all rooms facing the Imperial Garden were taken or we booked a semi-double). However, our room was clean, well-appointed and comfortable. Yes, it was small (with the bed 120cm) but no complaint since we were aware of it's size at the time of booking.Breakfast in the Patio restaurant was good as well (starting from 740 Yen for a Western breakfast with free refill for coffee and tea). Overall, service was as good as expected, with all the staff being able to communicate in English.The Grand Arc Hinzomon seems to cater more to business but tunred out to be a very good place to stay while in Tokyo.

This hotel seems very popular with businessmen and is also located in a discreet neighbourhood with 2 convenience stores nearby. Though it it is centrally located, the Hanzomon line does not have any stations of mai tourist attractions so you always have to change trains.The service is not overly friendly, but rather discreet and professional which I liked. Room was smaller than 18m square as advertised, but certainly significantly bigger than all the other hotel rooms i stayed in Tokyo. We had a smoking room though we requested for non-smoking, but they cleaned it well so there was no smell. Our room also had a great view of the imperial palace garden and Tokyo Tower.

We stayed 4 nights in the Grand Arc Hanzomon and I'm glad we did.Although there's not a lot in the area, the hotel makes up for it by offering you either and birds eye view of Tokyo Tower or the Imperial Palace.The hotel lobby is nice, with a bar offering well priced drinks on the 4th floor. I had a great stay! The only problem was they are very short on non-smoking rooms, I was worried when we first received the room, but to my delight, there was no smoke smell in the room. Now for all the visitors, take exit 1 from Hanzomon Station and be prepared to lug your bags up about 3 flights of stairs, the the hotel is a few minutes walk away.

The hotel is pleasant but a little dated, the staff very polite but a touch inflexible. By Western standards the rooms and beds are small (with nowhere to put suitcases except the floor). The Japanese hi~tech toilet is a revelation. You can stay in a Japanese room, sleeping on mats on the floor - I loved it, my wife hated it, particularly the strong sun pouring through the traditional sliding screens in the morning. We changed rooms. Breakfast offers either Japanese or Western options, though the latter is essentially three set meals which get boring over an extended stay. Quiet area, very quiet in fact for Tokyo, but excellent views over the city. Very clean.

The hotel was great apart from the small bed. It's look more like a large single bed but still it's acceptable to us. The hotel provide a lot of amenities and i like their bathroom! The mirror was equipped with anti fog and also come with a high-tech toilet! They even got an adult channel although you need to buy a tv card in order to access it (not suitable for a family with children).Our room got an excellent view and we can viewed the Imperial Garden and even the Tokyo Tower!!This hotel is located near the Hanzomon line and you can easily transfer to other Tokyo Metro line. Just buy the Pasmo or Suica and you don't have to worry about the fees.Please try their restaurant (Mon and Hangoromo)Highly recommended especially Hangoromo for the tempura!! The best ever tempura i ever tasted!Highly recommended!!!!!!

Good clean hotel with spectacular views of Tokyo. The immediate area is a little quite, although access to the rest of Tokyo by the metro is easy. The staff are very helpful and friendly and the hotel really is a good base for both business and site seeing in Tokyo. For the price this hotel is extremely good value, the breakfast was also good, but a little disappointed in the bar.

We stayed in a small double room for 5 nights. Everything was ok, except for a rather small bed (120cm), but we were informed before booking, so no huge complaint. (Therefore, if you are particular about having a comfortable, normal double bed, do not go for this.) Otherwise, the room and service was fine, and its location is also good, walkable from Hanzomon subway station, near to Imperial Garden, and if you can walk further, you can reach Tokyo station and Ginza! Just print a map and you are ready to go! Oh ya, we are surprised that we were given a room facing imperial garden and the view is superb!

This hotel is located near the Hanzomon station of the Hanzomon line, so it´s easy to move with the subway. The neighbourhood is very quiet, right in front of the Imperial Palace gardens. The room had an incredible view of the city and was also very comfortable, not as small as we thought it would be. The staff was ok. We loved this place and would stay there again.

I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights for my business trip, since my branch office just across the street from this hotel. This hotel has a typical Japanese hotel room, with small room and small bathroom, but with a quite full equipped amenities. Every floor have vending machines and water dispenser. This Hotel located near Imperial Palace and in opposite from Tokyo Station. There was a near subway station from this Hotel. There are also some convinience store near this hotel.

After staying in a tiny box in another Japanese hotel, I was expecting more of the same, but the Grand Arc Hanzomon was a pleasant surprise.Although the hotel room was built on the same pattern as most Japanese business hotels - bed on the left, small gap, desk on the right, bathroom in front before bed - there was just a tiny bit more space everywhere. There was space between the bed and the window, giving us a place to put our giant American luggage. I could actually sit at the desk. And the bathroom was larger-than-average, and looked more like a "real bathroom" than a plastic phone booth.The view from the window was incredible; a chunk of the Imperial Palace garden and part of the south of Tokyo. It was really nice and made the room much more pleasant.I see other reviewers have had problems with getting a non-smoking room, but that was not my experience. This may depend on when you're going.Breakfast was not included in our stay, but the breakfast options, while not "bargain," are not extravagantly priced and are a fair value for the money, especially the Japanese-style breakfast, which has unlimited refills on miso soup and rice (the Western breakfasts have unlimited toast). I also see from other reviews, and this does bear mentioning, that while the Grand Arc Hanzomon is very close to the Imperial Palace, it is on the opposite side of the Imperial Palace from Tokyo Station, which makes it not ideally suited for public transportation as no train lines go directly under the palace - they either detour north or south.The Hanzomon station of the Tokyo Metro's Hanzomon line is a block away, but the Hanzomon line doesn't really connect to anything a tourist would want to see, so one takes it a stop South to Akasaka-Mitsuke for a connection, which involves a lot of walking as the "connection" is really walking 100-300m underground to a nearby metro station. One can also walk a little more or less than a kilometer to get to the stations to the west or south of the hotel which are on much more useful lines. We took a taxi to/from the hotel when traveling with bags, and I love walking, so this was not a problem for us, but it could be for other people.

I like this hotel. Clean, quiet enough, rooms ok (but the semi double is a single) but there is a real problem with two things:1. Almost all the rooms seem to be smoking rooms. It is vital to specify a non-smoking room. This hotel also has what it calls "no smoking treatment rooms". This means smoking room with air freshener.They really need to increase the number of non-smoking rooms. According to statistics, only 20% of Japanese smoke today. So why are most rooms smoking?2. Staff need to get a bit more flexible. Some of them are very nice and helpful but others treat customers like dubious forms of alien life whose (perfectly reasonable and politely asked) requests are outrageous.I suspect the managers in this hotel all smoke and are in deep denial about the health impact of smoking including second hand smoke.Still prices are quite reasonable and if you get a non-smoking room its good.

i am so taken back by this hotel's service that they rather send their guest away because they have made a mistake by assigning the guest the wrong room but did not offer any assistance to the guest to look for alternative non-smoking rooms in other hotels. I booked a non-smoking room for this hotel but upon my arrival, they assigned to me a smoking room. I explained to the front desk that due to health reasons, i am not able to accept the smoking room, and that i will get asthma attacks after prolonged exposure. They kept insisting that I accept other smoking rooms instead, but I rather not take the risk at all. I am sure that when i made my booking through a third party website, i stated that i wanted a non-smoking room. but the receptionist kept insisting that it was my fault. Instead of helping me to find alternative lodging, the receptionist simply cancelled my reservation and sent me away. My request to see the front desk manager was ignored and no attempt was made to help improve the situation. I had no choice but to seek other hotels at this very last minute. I sat on a chair 5 meters in front of the front desk trying to booking alternative hotels for 45 minutes but no front desk personnel offered any help in locating alternative hotels. At the end of 45 minutes, i went back to the front desk requesting to talk to the manager, and it was only after much insistence that they called for the manager. Even the manager was unapologetic and unhelpful and told us that such service is normal. i have nothing else much to say after hearing the manager's comment but to simply just walk right out of the door.

We stayed here in October, and found this hotel a bit hard to get to. We transferred to the Hanzomon subway line from the Yamanote Line, and with our two large luggages, we found the transfer between the stations not accessible at all. We had to carry our luggages up and down many flights of stairs with no available escalators or elevators. The hotel is not too far from the Hanzomon station but getting up to the ground floor from the subway was about four flights of stairs. The room had a view of the imperial palace, which was nice. However the room was a bit dated and the semi-double bed quite small in comparison to other semi-double rooms that I have stayed at. The washroom was relatively clean. The hotel itself isn't too bad but taking public transit to get there really wasn't the best idea.

Very big and clean room compared to other 3 star hotels in Tokyo I stayed in for the same price. And the view outside the windows is astonishing. I was in the 14th floor and could see the Tokyo Tower, the parliament and the imperial garden.

This hotel is cheaper than most in Tokyo and it's pretty well located for the Metro. I expected the room to be small and to be fair the width of the bed (120cm) was advertised when booking so I shouldn't be too critical, but it's the smallest double I've had in a hotel. As the two days there were spent exploring Tokyo the room was all about getting a good sleep, but I just thought the bed was too small. Otherwise everything was fine.

We stayed here for six nights in September. The hotel is conveniently located near Hanzomon station. The rooms are spotless. The economy double room is very small though, but for the price it was a great deal.

is a nice hotel, my room was very small, but it has all you need. I loved the toiletries!! (they were very good quality and a lot of things. and well just a silly thing, i was very impressed with the bathroom mirror, because it doesn't fog!the only thing i didn't like was that if you have breakfast included, is not that great, they give you only two options, so if you stay more than 4 days, you want a little more variety. the people is very nice and helpful. hotel is clean. and the view from our room was very nice, facing the imperial palace gardens. It was lovely going on a walk or a run around the palace. it was amazing how quiet it is, even if you have hundreds of cars passing next to you! all you hear are the crickets!!the location is very good. is only like 3 min walk to the metro, and you have little restaurants around that are very cheap, and there is a shop one block away just in case you want food in the middle of the night. i would stay here again!

"Space" is the commodity of brokerage in Japan: The bigger your space, the more you pay - which makes this hotel a particularly good option. The rooms are well above average size for their price, extremely well maintained with lot's of light from wall to ceiling windows throughout - some offering splendid views of the Emperor's residence amongst beautiful gardens & a narrow, winding lake beyond. As others have stated, the Hanzomon metro line is just 2 minutes away, making life a lot easier in what is essentially a very over populated city. We experienced excellent, professional service in all departments; enjoyed first class cocktails in their lounge & an appetizing breakfast from their restaurant. The surrounding streets are home to several fine eateries, 3 all night convenience stores & the occasional bar. The hotel location might be a tad outside most tourist spots, but Japanese transport systems are SO gloriously clean & efficient, the whole experience can be really quite captivating. I believe you will enjoy this hotel.

This hotel is easily accessible from the Hanzomom line, just being a few minutes walk from the station. However, do not that this line is not covered by the JR pass so you'll probably have to fork out about 230 Yen just to get on the Yamanote line that is covered by the JR pass.Check in was a breeze and staff spoke good English. There's a Chikara Meishi down the road that serves hot gyudon. Also, the area has several 24-hour stores (7-11, Lawson) to cater to midnight cravings.Rooms are small, but we didn't mind. They provide a small jug for heating water and there's an ice machine on every floor.Pretty good views.

The Grand Arc Hanzomon was one of the hotels that I stayed in during my trip to Tokyo. The service from the concierge was very good. They checked us in quite quickly and were very helpful with all the questions we had about the rooms and all other things. The rooms were very nice and well maintained. Some of the other reviewers mentioned that the rooms were a bit small, but I thought they were pretty good, compared to the other hotel rooms I stayed in. Our room had an excellent view of the palace and of Tokyo Tower, and it was an excellent sight at night. The hotel is not that close to a lot of the attractions that Tokyo has to offer but the Imperial Palace is right by the hotel. It is also an excellent area to walk around and just enjoy the atmosphere of the district. Only thing is that if you take the subway to get to the hotel, the easiest route would be through Hanzomon station, which doesn't have any elevators so you have to carry the suitcases up several flights of stairs (at least we did!). Overall, it was a good hotel and a great place to stay while in Tokyo.

We stayed here for 6 nights. The hotel is short walk from the metro station which is called hanzomon. Also hotel is very close to imperial palace just 5min to metro station and you can find also open supermarket and kiosk till midnight. The room is clean and very nice view. Hovewer the rooms are very small but if you think about japanese standart it is normal. You have also free wi-fi and interconnection is very good. The bathroom is clean ok but tiny. The bed is okey not much compertable but okey. Price is very good for Tokyo.

We stayed here for four nights.The Hotel was very clean and the bed was firm, which I like. The restaurant was good and the bar was comfortable. Bathroom was nice. Free wifi, fridge in room. Room was a little small but big enough. Very quiet in the room, no noise from the hall. The hotel isn't near a lot of tourist attractions or other restaurants. It is about three blocks from a subway station. I would not hesitate to stay here again.

The hotel is a short walk from the metro station, making it really convenient to get around. There are no lack of restaurants in the area and there is a convenience store just down the road too.The rooms are small (as expected of Japanese rooms) and the double bed looked more like a super super single. It was very comfortable however, and the staff had a good command of English. The rooms are all facing the same direction (west) and have a view of the gardens and the Tokyo tower.

This hotel is only a 5 minute walk from Hanzomon Station. From there it's only a few minutes to Shibuya. But for arriving and leaving with all the luggage it was exhausting, since the metro station has only stairs, no lifts. The rooms are small, and clean with a great view. Bath tub and japanese toilet. Very quiet and with very friendly staff. Wifi included. Highly recommended.

I stayed in a single room, which was small but fine for a few nights. Tokyo is expensive and I think this hotel is decent value for what you get. Very friendly as usual in Japan. Breakfast was Western or Japanese, which is good. I liked the location because it is a little quieter but still has many options for food and groceries.

This is a very good hotel to stay if visiting tokyo. Although it is not in a "centric" location, Metro station is only 20m away so you can go everywhere.Hotel views are also very good (imperial palace gardens), and rooms space is ok (good for japanese standards).Cost per room is also ok, so it is a very recommendable hotel.

We stayed twice in this hotel, with our 2kids of 9 & 11 years old, first in a std room with beds, and in a Deluxe twin room still western style, at the end of our long travelling in Japan in July 2013. The difference in confort and size of room is really worth the difference in price we got on the deals via booking.com. the std room (110 € per night) was actually very tiny for us 4 and all suitcases. The Deluxe room at 160€per night had a nice sitting room space in addition to the 2 beds and splendid bathroom and separate toilet. 2 large windows with a view on the green imperial gardens... Waouw ! Nearly a studio. For Tokyo, this hotel is really a nice quiet and 4 stars confort and services place, at very decent price. Indeed night life is at a few stops of metro from there, but not a big deal compared to the advantages detailed above.Good tip for travellers : most twin room in Japan (sold on internet for 2 adults & 2 children) have quite narrow beds. Usually between 110 and 120cm : to know before booking for a family with children or tall teenagers... This hotel has beds of 120cm wide, which was OK for our family.

Excellent value for the location and amenities. Service is exceptional. Though it is not in one of the larger centers of Tokyo, there are many choices of excellent restaurants in the neighborhood. Must change lines once to go to the Tokyo station, but taxi (1400-1700 yen) is a comfortable option.

Located right next to the Imperial Palace (which was unfortunately under construction during our stay in March), this hotel served as a great base for our time in Tokyo. The Hanzoman subway entrance is at the end of the block so that was super convenient to explore the rest of the city. It's a hotel more for business people. We stayed in a traditional room with futami beds. While comfortable, the room had barely any room for the 3 of us. I understand that rooms are a lot smaller in Japan but we were not used to it being "this" tiny. Nevertheless, we enjoyed our stay at this hotel which had a pretty helpful staff. The rooms were clean and modern. The wifi was also strong in the common areas.

This is a very nice hotel in a very quiet area of Tokyo, one block from Hanzomon subway station. The price is good, the rooms are a little small but very clean. The food at the restaurant is very good and the view from the rooms is amazing!!!

My boyfriend and I stayed here for the last leg of our Japan tour. The hotel is located in the buisiness district and is a close to the Hanzamon line subway. It's ok for getting about, however getting in and out of the station with luggage is difficult as there are only stairs ( and many of them). The rooms were small and so were the beds & bathrooms, but it was fine if you just want to use it as a base. The views were lovely - we had overlooking the park and the theatre. My biggest issue was the very unhelpful and rather insolent staff in form of a male recepsionist. Firstly when i called down to inquire about options of getting to the airport he respnded "train". I asked if the limobus which i had read about was in service and he replied "no. Train" and hung up. I thought maybe he just couldn't understand or didn't speak english very well. He proved me wrong when I later that day went to reception to inform them that my partner had lost both his phone and camera earlier on the trip and that the police might contact the hotel with information. Before I was even able to explain or say what I had come to say the male receptionist interrupted and said it was a matter for the police. After 15 minutes of me trying to get through that I wanted to know was whether the police had been in contact or if there was anything more we could do, I had to give up out of sheer frustration and annoyance at the receptionist. He even went as far as to scournfully laugh at me for not getting the name of the police officer ( I had the policeform with reffrence number etc). I am appalled at how we got treated by the receptionist - he at no point seemed vaguely interested in helping or empathising with our situation.

We found an outstanding deal online for this hotel and was very pleasantly surprised at the quality of the hotel for what we paid. It was fancy for under $100/night!! We loved the view of the Imperial Palace and the Tokyo skyline especially at night. The Tokyo Tower lit up at night and was just BEAUTIFUL from our room. Other reviewers are right in that itʻs not in a busy part of Tokyo, but we liked that it wasnʻt. There was a convenience store just up the road and we found some rather fabulous places to eat just around the area. We loved the close proximity of the Honzōmon station (of the Tokyo Metro) to the hotel. The hotel staff was very helpful, most especially with helping us get to Narita Airport after check out. They called the cab for us, which made life easier for us as we donʻt speak the language, so the driver knew exactly where to take us and we didnʻt need to say too much! lol I wouldnʻt mind staying here again if we go back to Tokyo. Oh, yes, it is primarily a business hotel - lots of men in suits and ties. We felt out of place in our tourist get up - jeans, t-shirt, hat, etc. LOL Yeah, one more thing. It was smokey in our room. We werenʻt able to get a non-smoking room (they were sold out), so we had to endure the smokey room smell for the duration of our stay. BOOOO

This is a very nice hotel located aross from the Chiyoda district, the location of the Imperial Palace. Alas you can't go in to the palace itself and the surrounding neighborhood is not terribly exciting; government buildings and embassies mostly. Still plenty of food options and the hotel restaurant itself is quite good. The Hanzoman line is about 2 blocks away so you can get on there and subway to most areas of Tokyo. In essence it's a nice central location but not the most happening neighborhood; in retrospect I would have liked to stay in Asakusa or Shinjuku.The hotel itself is well maintained and the staff are helpful. Great value for the money. Tatami mat sleeping takes some getting used to for those of us used to Western style beds so be forewarned.

Good location with the Tokyo Metro station Hanzomon very close. The hotel is more of a business hotel with small rooms, but ideal if you only goong to sleep. Great view towarda the Imperial palace and the skyline in Maronouchi district. Clean rooms and great staff. The resataurant offers breakfast of different kinds.

We had a lot of "needs" for our stay in Tokyo and the Grand Arc fulfilled every one. We wanted a room that could sleep 3, we wanted to be close to the Imperial Palace and we wanted a nice hotel.The Grand Arc was a nice surprise, considering it cost less than many others. Service was excellent. From check-in to check-out we were well taken care of by the staff. The room was large enough that even with the additional twin bed there was room to walk around. The bathroom was two rooms separated by a vanity. Nice touch with so many of us in the room.The rooms were clean, the lobby was spotless. They even had a designated smoking area outside that had an air purifier so that the smoke wasn't wafted over every guest walking in or out of the lobby. Nice touch!The view from the room was spectacular! The little gift shop in the lobby was quite nice and had many unique items as well.I would stay here again if I were ever to come back to Tokyo.

I arrived here after a very long flight for a 3 night stay on business. From the outside it looked impressive enough, and the location close to the Imperial Palace gardens was very attractive. However, I was told that check in was not for another 3 hours and my room was not available. My complaints, saying I was exhausted and needed to rest were met with polite inscrutability, but no real attempt to help. I could not believe there were NO rooms that had been made up and that was confirmed when a colleague who also arrived early was able to go straight to his room. I asked if there was a lounge where I could sit in a comfortable chair with a soft drink, but there was none, only restaurants. The lobby only had a few uncomfortable chairs and a leather bench, which is where I ended up crashing out until my room was ready.Once I got to my 10th floor room, the only impressive part was the view. The room itself was small and the furnishings were basic; the bathroom was more of a cupboard, measuring approximately 5ft by 6ft. The bed was hard and uncomfortable. There was no mini bar and no soft drinks were available in the room, nor could I find any room service menu. The TV was exclusively Japanese- no CNN or Sky News. WiFi was free, but slow, so I resorted to the high speed ethernet connection which was good, offering a robust connectivity. Food in the restaurants was unremarkable. No gym or pool.Whilst the overall entrance to the hotel gave an impression of a mid-range standard hotel that would boast most of the expected amenities, but the accommodation and services were more like those of a low budget motel. Judging from the guests when I was there, the hotel is clearly geared to Japanese business travellers and, in my opinion, little concession is made to western travellers, although the service was always exceedingly polite and attentive, as one would expect in Japan. This is very different from my previous experiences with other hotels in Tokyo and I was therefore very surprised and disappointed.I will not use this hotel again.

We spent three nights in Tokyo and we found a good deal with grand arc hanzomon. The hotel is close to the train station, very quiet and has a great view of Tokyo. Given that we originally wanted to stay at a ryokan, we decided to go with the Japanese room option instead of the normal bedding, which was proven to be a bad choice! Two of us couldn't even get any sleep on night one so we decided to get an extra mattress for one of us, only to be told that they ran out of mattresses for the night ... Hard to believe. They can do with more breakfast options too .. But overall, we were pretty pleased with the hotel ..

Just few steps from Hanzomon Tokyo Metro station (Z05). Nice hotel. Our room n. 1311 was a little bit small but with a great view on Tokyo Tower. First three nights we've slept very well only on fourth night there was people making noise and speaking loud in the aisle in the morning.A large variety of complementary items included slippers to take at home, combs, hair brushes, nail set, cotton and body and facial cream

Close to subway station. Paid $180/night 3 people, last minute booking in June 2013. Free slippers, assortment of cutesie toiletries and amenities, fancy toto Japanese toilet, large bathroom/shower in the Japanese style room. Nice view of the palace and river. Clean rooms, nice staff. Be warned that Japanese room comes with futons on the ground, not conventional beds that you might be used to. When in Rome....

We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights and we had a room with an amazing view of the Imperial Park. The room was rather spacious considering Japanese standards. It was close to Hanzomon station but there was not much happening at a walking distance from the hotel.

I and my husband traveled to Tokyo for a business trip. We are also partners in our family law firm with 50% international clients which make travel us travel internationally a few times a year to meet existing and potential clients. So we stayed there for 7 nights. Five nights for work and 2 nights for pleasure :) The hotel is a marvelous value of money. We stayed on 16th floor. The view was magnificent especially at night. The room was big enough for two for us and was super-clean with neat sheets,pillow covers. The breakfast was not included in our room, but there are rooms with included breakfast. The location is perfect, just 3-4 minuted from Honzomon station and walking distance from imperial palace and restaurents nearby.Overall, it was a great experience, except that only one lady from the entire staff at the reception could speak and understand English.

We had 5 nights in the Grand Arc Hanzomon and for this unbelievable price it was just awesome. We stayed at the 14th floor with a nice view to the governments building over Tokyo. Rooms were a bit small but it was ok. It was very clean and the room service very friendly. Would come back every day.

This hotel, located on the West side of the Imperial Park, is spotless, comfortable, and has an excellent restaurant used by locals. It was delightful to see tables of kimono-clad ladies sharing dinner on a Sunday night. My single room was compact, but well-appointed, and had a huge floor to ceiling window facing south with park, river, and Tokyo Tower in full view. The only negative is that if you try to arrive by subway with luggage, there is no escalator or elevator to the street level. So, better to arrive and leave by taxi, but the subway close by is convenient for going anywhere in Tokyo.

Stayed 2 nights. Room is small, as expected from a Japanese hotel, but complete with amenities. We got a room with a view of Tokyo Tower, which was nice. Wifi is available in room and lobby. Room was super clean. All floors has vending machines. Located walking distance to the Hanzomon Station. Local marts and restaurants also available in the area. Staff was friendly and helpful.

We Stayed here for five nights. We arrive early in tokyo, From Tokyo Train Station its about 5 minutes by taxi cost about 1200 Yen or about AUD$12. Its convenient to catch a taxi if you carry suitcases and big back pack, Because the you have to take and change two subway train. We cannot check-in early, the room was full for Golden weekend holiday. A lot of visitor Domestic and International stay here. Nice and Friendly Staff very helpful with guide of Tokyo and around. The room was nice, clean and big enough for both of us. Maybe compare to any other cheap hotel in Tokyo, this was spacious with only double bed available. Breakfast was included, we can choose between western or Japan style breakfast, in two different restaurant. Japanese style breakfast food was good, a bit cold, but healthy, mostly pickles, and the main always fish. But its enough to make us full. The Western style choice is kind of bacon and egg muffin kind of style with coffee. All is in set menu, so its not buffet breakie. Hanzomon subway is just two minutes walk, and unlike any other station, this hanzomon subway line never busy any time of the day, so no need of pushing inside the train. A lot of restaurant and convenience store around this area. Walk distance to Imperial Palace around 15 minutes. Overall for the price i paid this was worth stay.

The hotel has a great view over Tokyo Tower,especially looks great at night.İf you are planning to use subway,it is only 5 minutes walk.İt cost 15 usd to tokyo station with taxi.The hotel standarts are really good,compare to prices.The room was extra clean.They have changed our sheets every day and brought every day extra slippers,shaving knits,tooth brushes and etc.The staff was helpfull and kind.I enjoyed staying at that hotel.

Honestly i was glad that i booked this hotel after reading the positive tripadvisorreviews. I stayed for six nights and i was absolutelly satisfied. The hotel is next to the imperial palace, 200 metres to the next undergroundstation and 24 hour convenient store. And by the way, this should be the safest hotel in japan, because they have a policestation as their neighbour.My room was spacious enough, equiped with a fridge, a flatscreen-tv, a good quality bed and a perfect view of the citylights at night. The staff was friendly and helpfull and my room was clean. And i mean clean, no insects, no stains, no hair or other things from former guests.One other positive thing i'd like to mention ist, that my room was nearly noisesealed, i didn't hear any noisy neighbours or streetsounds. Therefore i needed no earplugs and that's why i give full five stars.

Perfect hotel to stay in Tokyo, no need to go anywhere else. Very good location (by Narita express to Tokyo station, then 10 min by taxi to hotel, 1560 yen) and absolutely fantastic view. Room was very clean and fresh and most of all, silent. Air condition worked well. Nearest underground station (Hanzomon) just few steps away. Staff helpful. We highly recommend Grand Arc Hanzomon an will absolutely stay there again when visiting Tokyo.

My wife and I are spending the first leg of our round the world honeymoon in Tokyo for 4 nights after arriving from Australia. I am currently writing this review while waiting to head down and check out from this fantastic hotel. We booked this hotel on the basis of the great reviews on trip advisor and the rate on Expedia of around $100 US a night. When we arrived we noticed the Trip advisor Awards taking pride of place on the check in desk. We were welcomed by a young man who spoke very good english and explained all the necessities for our stay. The rooms are not luxury but have all the comforts you will need including desk, safe, hanging cupboard, flatscreen, vast array of complimentary toiletries and in our case a fantastic view of the tokyo skyline and the emperors palace. The staff are only too eager to help when you ask and are very polite and unintrusive. The floors all have vending machines with Asahi beers for $2.50. Bargain.The hotel is located in a quiet area near some great hole in the wall restaurants, however a 10 minute walk will find you Mcdonalds, Starbucks and Hooters. Hanzoman Metro station is at the end of the street and will connect you to any train in Tokyo. We loved the 4 km walk around the palace and gardens each morning. The only criticism if any was the firmness of the "Semi-double" bed. Then again it is asia, so when in Rome. I highly recommend this hotel for business or pleasure.

We spend 4 nights in this hotel in May, and it was really nice. The room was very clean (a semi-double bed), a bit small, but this is common in Japan, the bathroom was excellent as well, and the view from our room was magnificent (of the Imperial gardens and Tokyo city). Plus, it was relatively cheap in comparison to hotels in this standards. The only disadvantage of the hotel is that there is nothing next to it, no main attractions, and not many restaurants as well. However, it is close to the Hanzomon line so it is not a problem to go anywhere.

I stayed here last year and wrote a review. I liked it so much that I wanted my husband to experience the stay at Grand Arc Hanzomon this spring. Although the timing was right for the cherry blossom season but because of the unusually early bloom this year we missed the peak. I was really looking forward to the beautiful blossoms in the next door National Theater's front area and Chidorigafuchi around the Imperial Moat. Nevertheless we enjoyed our seven- day stay at this hotel. We had a standard twin room on the thirteenth floor with the Imperial Moat, the Diet Building and Tokyo Tower view. The view was as refreshing as the first time. As mentioned in many reviews the metro line Hanzomon station is only a couple of minutes away although the elevator for the station is eight minutes or so away. There are many convenience stores and restaurants nearby. The hotel has wedding ceremony and reception halls, banquet rooms up to the sixth floor. There are four restaurants on the premise, La Mer French restaurant on the forth floor, Hagoromo Tempura on the second floor, Mon Japanese in the basement and Patio Western café on the ground floor. I did not visit La Mer but had breakfast and lunch at Mon and Patio. We had dinner at Hagoromo. Mon and Patio were quite busy during lunch time. Hagoromo's tempura was quite good and the price was not bad at all for a restaurant in a hotel managed by the Imperial Hotel.Our room was spacious with a large window. It had a closet with a space to hung clothes and drawers, an extra sink, a writing table with a TV and a set for tea with a small fridge, drawers and a safe underneath, a chair and a coffee table and a trouser presser. There is a coin laundry in the neighborhood.We were very happy and understood why Grand Arc Hanzomon was selected at the top on the best budget hotels in Japan by TA.

We stayed in the Grand Arc for 7 nights in April and really enjoyed it. We stayed in a semi double room and a twin room. Both rooms had really large windows with a great view towards the river and the imperial palace, also one of the rooms had an excellent view of the Tokyo Tower. Our rooms were very clean (spotless), comfortable and had everything we needed including a full complement of toiletries.The room had a small fridge and to be honest the room was a much better size than we expected. The twin room was larger but you do pay a higher price for that space, the semi double was adequate. We are travelling for a while so have 2 large suitcases, these were stored against the wall and didn't get in our way. We did keep most things in the suitcases though rather than scatter everything around the room.The aircon was very good and the in room internet access was fast and reliable.The hotel is really accessible via the metro, on the Hanzomon line you go to the Hanzomon station - the closest exit to the hotel is exit number 1 - bear in mind this exit has stairs only, exit 5 has a lift - using exit 5 is a longer walk to the hotel but only about 5 minutes in total. Using exit number 1 you literally cross the road, take the first left and walk for about 2 minutes - the Grand Arc will be on the right hand side.The reception staff are very helpful and spoke enough English to understand our questions. The hotel will also store luggage, which is secure and they give you a tag so you can make sure you get the right luggage back. They stored our bags for us overnight.The location of the hotel was excellent, it was very quiet and only about a 15 minute walk to the entrance for the Imperial Palace gardens. The Hanzomon line is one of the main tokyo metro lines so it makes all the tourist attractions really easily accessible such as Akihibara (electric technology town), Asakusa for the Sensoji Temple and Skytree, Shibuya for the pedestrian crossing as well as Tokyo station for the JR train lines and Shinkansen.There is also a Lawsons, Family Mart and Sun Rus convenience stores close to the metro station about a 3/4 minute walk from the hotel.All in all we really did enjoy our stay - for the location, comfort and cleanliness. We would stay here again and definitely recommend it.

Great view over Tokyo Tower and the Imperial Palace Gardens. Looks great at night. Close to subway, quiet area with not many restaurants near by but good value western breakfast. Imperial Palace Gardens a popular place for jogging any time of the day or night. Staff helpful and spoke great English.

This place is great! I will definitely be staying here again when I visit Tokyo again. I did an internship in Tokyo 2 years ago so I lived in an apartment for that, so this was my first time staying in a hotel in Tokyo. And you really can't beat this. $90/night for a single room that is by Japanese standards quite spacious with all the amenities you could want (wifi, refrigerator, tv [if you buy the card] a pants press [in case you are here on business like many of the guests] is a good deal! Really don't even bother bringing toiletries either the soap/shampoo/conditioners they have are great, my hair feels better than at home! And it's in one of the quietest spots I've ever been in Tokyo because it's so close to the Imperial Palace. It's got such a nice view of Tokyo Tower at night, and it's close to several stations.  The Hanzomon Line is very convenient because it takes you right to Sky Tree and also right to Shibuya which gets you just about anyplace else in Tokyo. Hotel staff speaks English though most of my interactions with them were limited and I usually just used Japanese. Don't forget to visit the Imperial Palace while you're here! You're so close! It's also a really nice place to run in the morning. If you want to go inside the Imperial Palace grounds you have to apply about a month before you visit, but really the East Gardens are great and those don't require any sort of reservation.
