Fulton, New York, United States

review_body: Very grand, indeed! It was next door neighbor to the Tokyo Opera House and Imperial Palace. My room had a great view of the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Tower. It was a short distance from the Hanzomon station which was great. The staff were very courteous and helpful. Plus factor is that it is few minutes away from Chikara Meishi, serving very delicious Jap food with affordable price.

We stayed here for our first trip to Japan. The location of this hotel is very convenient since it is a short walk to the subway station. The staff was very helpful and attentive. The rooms are of course on the smaller size but we knew to expect this when coming to Japan. When travelling to Osaka/Kyoto they happily held our luggage til we returned. Vending machines are located on every floor and the rooms have a small refrigerator. You also have a nice view from your window that includes the Imperial Gardens and Tokyo Tower.We also booked this hotel through hotel.com atleast 5 months in advance and received a really good deal that averaged out to 89 dollars a night. I highly recommend this hotel.

The hotel is not a very tall building but the views to Tokyo are incredible! Our room was in the 13 floor and we could see quite a lot. The room was not big, as normal japanese room, but the layout was great and there was enough space. The hotel is more a business hotel so it was very quite at night which was great. Only negative was the quality and quantity of restaurants around, it is a very quite area, however, by underground or even walking Ginza have everything that you need

The hotel is very close to Imperial Palace and Chidorigafuchi Park, close to Subway station and many restaurants (mostly need reservation for dinner), very helpful staff, and nice view from room on Tokyo and the canal around Imperial Palace

We are so pleased to have stayed here and not in closer to the 'action' like Shibuya etc. you really are only about 15 mins from there anyway. A quick 5 min walk then 10 mins on the subway all for y160., although if you plan on using the subway a lot by a multi day pass.  The room was incredibly spacious, so if you plan on spending time in it then you will have space and comfort. We had a deluxe twin room on the 17th floor. A great view of the city and Imperial palace park. The room was very clean and all furniture and appliances in great working order.  While we could hear the traffic outside it made more of a quiet hum than anything that woke us or disturbed our sleep. Now the beds are firm ... Not rock hard but certainly firmer than most beds. We actually used the padded bed spread as a soft layer under the sheet and that worked well. Just folded it in half and it was a lot more comfortable.  The shower pressure was great. You get an empty fridge to stock from the 24 hour mart near the subway and a small kettle to use. Staff spoke reasonable English .. I was able to communicate easily. Free wifi is an added bonus.

Room was larger than others we had stayed at, clean and well appointed. Beds abit hard, lower quality mattress. Quiet. Easy to find map right outside the subway station (hanzomon z05 exit 1). Across from the palace but you are on the back side, so walk around for the main gate. Mostly embassies in the area. Close to the subway and the hanzomon line is not too busy there. Some restaurants in the area and many more about a km away in asakasa. Beautiful view and helpful staff. Good quiet ac. Only question would be location, if you need to be closer to something. In Tokyo though the subway is cheap and fast and nothing is far away.

This hotel has a central location. I had ordered a nonsmoking room, but was given a room which was stinking from smoke. I returned to the reception and asked for another room. They claimed that this was the only room they had. I left the luggage at the reception and returned some hours later. They had managed to arrange a nonsmoking room. The hotel is quite ok but it is the location which is its asset. Nice breakfast in the morning. Their laundry service is excellent.

Can't think of my self staying at American brand hotel and pay $300-500/night like some business travelers. This hotel has everything I need -- small rooms but that's what you get in Tokyo business hotels.Room - Great view! Small but comfortable. Has everything you need. A/C works fine.Service - LOL! you are in Japan so there's nothing wrong with it. You can get really good service from subway station staff in Tokyo so.....Location - AWESOME! especially if you are into running and exercising. One of the most popular place to run. Very close to Hanzomon line.Restaurants near by - Yes, plenty of them -- all kinds of Japanese, Chinese, Italian, Thai food.Overall great business hotel with sensible room rates -- somethings AWESOME rates!

we stayed here for 9 days in march. perfect hotel, much more impressive and up market than what we were expecting! we booked an economy double room which was a good, easy size. definitely not too small. and the view was amazing. only problem we had was trying to find it since google gave us a pretty weird direction! the easiest way is to just take the hanzomon subway line to hanzomon station and make sure you take exit 1 (it stairs up, not escalators, but you will survive). right in front of you will be a big sign showing you to the grand arc. all you need to do is walk directly forward from the exist until you get there. staff were friendly and spoke perfect english and also gave us a map to the nearest coin laundry since they only have a dry cleaning service. a handful of general stores and a wide range of restaurants within a 5 minute walk around the area. would definitely return.

Booked a room on special and was surprised how upmarket the hotel is when I arrived. Despite this the staff were extremely friendly and there was no snootiness that one usually associates with a hotel of this level. The rooms were small but very clean and well appointed and the room had a beautiful view of the Imperial palace. Close to Hanzomon metro and the palace but there is not much else to see or do in the area.

We stayed at the Grand Arc Hanzomon last November for a week. The location is unmatchable, especially if you like to enjoy Tokyo on foot: most of the places are within 30 minutes to 1 hour (e.g. 40 minutes to Shinjuku, 30 minutes to Ginza and Roppongi). The hotel has the best quality-price ratio among those hotels in Tokyo. We´re sure to repeat the stay at the hotel on our next trip to Japan's capital.

If i was traveling on business, this would be the hotel to stay in. Simple, clean, well located, and plenty of restaurants and good staffs who speak acceptable english. However as I came in with kids, we found the room a bit too small and traces of cigarette smokes can be smelled although our room was on non-smoking floor. Everything else was very good as expected in a Japanese hotel. Fast trips up to our room, quick check in and out, nearby mini markets and take out foods, Hanzomon station entrance only 200 meters away, plenty of taxis available if you need one, and easy access to the airport without changing metro lines to get to the Airport Limousine Bus Service. The hotel is not perfect but you also don't have to pay triple the price to be in a perfect one.

I was a little disappointed in this hotel.Nothing fundamentally wrong, but little things like only one reading light and the double bed pushed up against the wall was frustrating.The view from the window was great and the loaction worked well, but later we stayed at the bay and that was far better from a location and hotel point of view (But more money!!)So generally OK, but not amazing IMHO!

The hotel is in a great location for visiting the city just a few steps from the subway.I stayed over from December 27 to January 1 in a "half double" (which would be a single 120cm bed) and it seemed quite spacious.Wi-fi free in the room, electric kettle with tea, bath set complete: toothbrush, nail file, brush, comb and razor.There was also excellent value for money.A great experience: if I ever go back to Tokyo, it will be my accommodation.

Ive stayed here twice now and everything about this place is class. The rooms are clean, comfortable and have stunning views of the Imperial Palace gardens. The location is fantastic, with Akasaka a 10 minute walk away, and Roppongi, Shibuya and Shinjuku all easily accessible via Tokyo Metro.The Japanese restaurant in the basement is great and offers very good value for money, and the western restaurant on ground level also offers good food at not unreasonable prices. The staff on the front desk are polite, helpful and have a reasonably good grasp of English.Whenever I visit Tokyo (2013 will be my 6th visit), this is always the first place I check availability for. Ticks every box!

Perfect hôtel , great location very good services ! The room was very nice with a beautiful view on the imperial garden ,and tokyo tower ! the metro station is at 5 minutes walking distanceWe Will Come back !

Having just arrived from an excellent hotel in Shanghai, we found the room to be claustrophobic.We had small twin beds with a choice of banging your head against the wall or the window.My great gran would have refused to wear what they offered as a dressing gown. Only has BBC World in english. Be warned if you are a family and want to watch additional english channels using pay per view, there a pronographic channels also. It is near to the subway (use 1a or 1b), not many good restaurants nearby.They do not cash TC`s. Check out is 10am, which is most unusual. Didn`t eat at the hotel.

We spent 2 nights in a Japanese style room at the Grand Arc. The room was quite comfortable, the hotel decently located, although a little north from the center of town, but right in front of the Imperial Palace. Very clean and professionally run. Highly recommended for a Tokyo stay.

We stayed here for a few days after skiing in Niseko. When searching for hotels in Tokyo we found lots of them VERY expensive for what we needed, as we had two children with us (3 & 5 years). The rooms here were a really good size, with great views. It is also in an excellent location - very close to the station. We had breakfast downstairs, which I couldn't really complain about and the restaurant downstairs in the basement was fantastic! Full of locals, which is always a good sign.Service in the hotel was excellent, although we did have a few issues trying to get wifi/computer access. The hotel seems to cater more for Japanese travellers, rather than international ones, so there weren't many tourist maps/attraction brochures in the foyer, like you'd find at most hotels. This wasn't really an issue, as we were happy to look online. Overall a great hotel and a real find in Tokyo!

We were in Tokyo for about 2 weeks and stayed in the Grand Arc Hanzomon twice in that time. First for 5 days, then left for Osaka and came back to stay an additional 3 nights. All the reviews are pretty spot on about this place. It's centrally located and just a short walk from the Hanzomon station which makes getting to anywhere in the city relatively painless. The rooms are not as tiny as some have complained about. They are small compared to western standards but at the end of the day it's a nice room, well kept and a place to crash after long days of exploring Tokyo with great views of the imperial gardens and the city. I feel that I should mention that the hotel is in the middle of a business district so you might feel a little out of place when you're dressed in sneakers and jeans (to walk around the city all day) and almost everyone else around you is wearing suits but this really didn't bother me too much. Just something I thought about while I was there but this did not affect our experience in a negative way at all.  The service was also very good, as others have mentioned the staff does speak a good amount of English so it was easy to communicate when we needed something. The cleaning services were also very good. The staff always seemed eager to help with anything that we needed. If you'll be visiting with a lot of luggage, do as others have noted and take a cab from Tokyo station to the hotel (shouldn't cost you more than 1,800 yen (~$20)) as you will have to climb about 4 flights of stairs out of Hanzomon station. This would not be fun after a day of long flights/layovers. We wouldn't hesitate to stay at the Grand Arc Hanzomon on our next trip to Tokyo (which hopefully isn't too long from now).

I spend 2 nights in this hotel. The staff was helpful, knowledgable, friendly and most importantly their english is good. The location is great as it was near to the Hanzomon station. The room is clean and tidy. The view from my room was great and i was able to look at the Tokyo tower. I will gladly & definitely comeback to this hotel for my next trip to Tokyo.

The folks at Grand Arc Hanzomon were friendly, quick, and eager to please. Their english is fantastic, and they showed a great knowledge of the local area. The rooms were clean and comfortable, and the cleaning service every day was thorough. I would be very glad to stay here again if I were to stay in Tokyo.

We wanted to experience the Japanese style room and this hotel was perfect. We stayed here on the first day of our arrival as we wanted to get to the palace first. However, you have to take two trains to get here but we took a cab from Tokyo station. Very nice place and room. There is a seven eleven very close by where we got some pastry in case we got hungry. We did not find that many restaurants but there was a chinese restaurant down the road which was very good. It was very convenient to visit the palace gardens.

I spent some time dithering over choices for a 5-night stay in Tokyo prior to embarking a cruise there, and considered several other hotels before deciding on the Grand Arc Hanzomon, largely on the basis of the TripAdvisor reviews. What a good choice it turned out to be. First, by Tokyo standards the price is very reasonable, and the rooms are both spacious and stylish: great care seems to have been taken in furnishings. Beds are firm and comfortable, with linen changed every day by the most courteous housekeepers. Almost all rooms overlook the Imperial Palace Gardens; rooms have huge windows to allow you to enjoy the views. Bathrooms are not large but are adequate, and come equipped with an all-singing, all-dancing Japanese toilet: if you don't know what this is, you're in for a surprise.The Grand Arc Hanzomon is not right in the centre of frenetic Tokyo, but to me that was an advantage: it is two minutes' walk from Hanzomon Metro stop on the Hanzomon Line, so Ginza or the other major centres are no more than 15 or 20 minutes away.Staff are uniformly extremely courteous and helpful, as only the Japanese can be, although in some instances I encountered a language barrier with restaurant staff, whose command of English was rudimentary.I felt that breakfast was the weak link in an otherwise perfect stay: it is rather unimaginative and limited, but I have to admit that there are plenty of places nearby where one can get breakfast.The Grand Arc Hanzomon is not a "grand" hotel in the style of the Imperial, the Okura or the New Otani, but those hotels have the disadvantage that they are swarming with people and are often confusing in layout (the New Otani especially). I like the restrained atmosphere at the Hanzomon, although it can be busy at weekends when it becomes a popular venue for weddings.All in all, I am delighted to have found this hotel, and will be very happy to return there on my next visit to Tokyo.

We have stayed for 5 nights and were very happy for our decision to choose this one instead of stay in Shinjuku.The location is super, 2 minutes walk from Hanzomon subway stn., and this subway line (also called Hanzomon) is not that busy as others, and literally in the middle of the system, so it is very convenient to switch lines.The staff is very friendly. We checked in Saturday night and was given a city view room, i was a bit disappointed and asked the front desk to switch to a palace view room. They said it was booked full that day, but they can move us to same size room on Sunday for free, and if we keep luggage packed, they will move the luggage too. So we left to the city early Sunday morning and came back late night to a palace view room with all our stuff already there.The room is small if measured in American way, but was good enough for us even with two big cases and two carry-ons in the room. The palace view is super in the morning with beautiful sunrise to wake up with and splendid view at night. (we stay at room 1503)Only one drawback is that not many restaurants around, but there is a family mart and a Lawson very close-by for breakfast, drinks and snacks.Definitely will book it again next time in Tokyo.

First time for me to write such a review right after the visit today as I really feel that this hotel should be shared to all. Best view I have ever had in Tokyo. A room with a view of the palace, river, and even the Tokyo Tower (my room is on 16th floor). Reasonably priced through Hotels.com. Excellent location, only 2 minutes walk from Hanzoman Metro Station. Some convience stores, cafe, Chinese and Japanese restaurants right above the station. Only a few stations away to nearly everywhere in Tokyo. Perfect jogging / walking /cycling path right opposite the street to circle around the Palace of 5-6 km. Very clean and tidy, both inside the room, at the lobby or from the outside. Free wifi and wired Internet connection, pretty fast speed.Only minor problem of carrying the luggage up and down 2-3 stairs from the Metro station.

We booked 5 nights in this hotel and stayed in a twin-room. By japanese standards it was a big room with a fantastic view of the Imperial Palace grounds and the skyscrapers of the financial district surrounding Tokyo Station. The price was most reasonable. The area is a little quiet during the evening hours, but there are a couple of places where you can find something to eat (24h restaurant, chinese place, soba place, izakaya, coffee shop).The subway (Hanzomon line) is within reach (5 min by foot). All in all we really liked the place. Staff was helpful and friendly and most of them spoke English. There was free WiFi in our room. The room was clean and nicely furnished. If you expect buzzing nightlife around you, you might not enjoy it as much as we did, but if you like to unwind from the city and enjoy the view at night, it´s the place to be for you.

The location is central and that is what the premium rates are for, but in reality there is little life in the area on evenings, weekends and holidays. IF you are lucky you MIGHT get a view of the Imperial Palace but most rooms would not have that, in which case it is not any better than a business class hotel. Free WIFI in the rooms.I had a small double which had too much furniture that it was not possible to walk around the bed. Drinks were in a vending machine down the hall as were cards for premium channels. Checkin was only at 2pm and checkout at 10am - pretty stingy hours in my view. Found hte staff to be efficient but not particularly nice.For the money, next time I would book a business class hotel in another area such as Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ikebukuro or Roppongi.

I agree with other positive reviews. One important addition is that it does now have free wifi for guests. They give you a code valid for one month when you check in. Good signal in my room on 13th floor. Also, i think breakfast is fine, especially the japanese one in "mon" in the basement. Sure there'sno buffet but of you can afford to stay here you are unlikely to be malnourished.

I recently stayed at the GAH for 3 nights. Check-in was quick and painless, just the way it should be after a 10 hour flight and 1.5 hour train/subway ride. About the hotel:- Staff were very friendly and helpful- Great location- Super clean ( like most things in Japan)- Nice rooms and washrooms- Free Internet access but bring a long cable if you want to lie in bed. No wireless.- As others have said, walk to one of teh bakeries nearby and enjoy a nice cup of tea/coffee and a freshly baked pastry instead of eating at the hotel.- The price is right for downtown Tokyo ( I paid $114/night on Bookit)The hotel is located a few steps from the Honzomon subway station. As others have mentioned, this particular subway station does not have escalators at the exits and you will have to carry your bags up three flights of stairs. Make sure you take exit #1 or you will have a longer walk.I toured the city on foot/subway/train/monorial for three days. Buy a full day unlimited subway pass (~$10) and you will be all set. There are two subway companies in Tokyo, but the "Tokyo Subway" has the most lines. In some cases you will have to pay a few extra dollars to transfer from one line to another. The machines to buy tickets all have an "english" button and subway staff all speak some english. Take advantage of the central location of the hotel to come back in the afternoon for a quick nap!There is a great Indian restaurant near the hotel called Dimpmahal. Try their Thali which was delicious and only 1500 yen.I had many great inexpensive meals all over the city.If you are there on a Sunday, make sure you check out the "temple sales" which are basically the Japanese version of our garage sales. there is a complete listing on Google.

Stayed at the Grand Arc for 4 nights, good location, very close to the Imperial Palace grounds where we did a walk around one morning. Quiet location, rooms are small (but standard for Japanese hotels) and we made it work with two suitcases and a little furniture re-arrangement. Very close to the Hanzomon subway line, where you can get direct access to Shibuya and Shinjuku. Views from the hotel room was fabulous! Very safe feeling walking around late at nightStaff there spoke fairly good english and we were treated well (no concierge in the hotel but that was not a problem) A few things to note:- i) Japanese subways at different stations sometimes do not have elevators or lifts that take you to street level so pack prudently or carry a backpack instead of a suitcase-makes it easier to move around. ii) If you are carrying luggage, book the rearmost seat on the Shinkansen as you can put your baggage behind you, against the rear bulkhead wall. Luggage storage space is at a premium on those trains so reserve your seat early on. iii) To get to Grand Arc from Narita, I'd suggest catching the Narita Express to Tokyo and then the subway-we took another (at the time seemed a more direct route) which I believe took us longer to get there. iv) Have your breakfast outside, there are quite a few French inspired patisseries around with fantastic breads and pastries for your morning breakfast (and cheaper too)Overall, very good value for money!

Very big building offering you big rooms. Price quite high..Located right next to imperial city, it is easy to reach (Hanzomon station on Hanzomon line)Breakfast quite poor - don't get attracted by low price, dish are very small and you need to stop by first Starbucks on your way..They do not change money at the front desk as you would expect. But most disappointing thing is that you have no wi-fi rather than 30 min per day at ground floor...Moreover, all the 3 restaurants inside the hotel as well as the bar stop serving at 10PM with last order at 9ish.. Just get into the tube and go to Ginza or Roppongi!I wouldn't probably stay again if I were to visit Tokyo again in the future..

We stayed in this comfortable hotel from 23.07. to 31.07. and it was one of the warmest periods in Tokyo. We took a taxi from the Tokyo Central station and it costed JPY 1'300.--The value for price is very good e.g. our room, which was modern and very clean, was with a wonderful view overlooking the green Palace garden and other typical buildings in Tokyo such as the parliament building. The location is excellent particularly for me, who needs good food. There are a few good places for breakfast near by and for dinner there are various good quality restaurants around the hotel and near the nearest underground station "Hanzomon". For jogging, there is an ideal way around the Palace (you can start right in front of the hotel), which is green, safe even at night (there are lots of police, who are guarding the Imperial Palace). You would jogg along the way passing by the National Museum of Modern Art, the British Embassy, the National Theatre, which is right next to the hotel. The way is nicely lined with bushes and the moat. By the way, there are a few more easily reachable underground stations e.g. "Kojimachi", "Nagatacho" , "Yotsuya" and "Akasaka-Mitsuke". The hotel is located in a friendly village like area although it is geographically quite in the middle of Tokyo.

This was the best hotel we stayed in Japan, The value for price is very good: we paid 80 euros for a double bedroom with a fantastic view over Tokyo: from the very big window you can see the park of the Royal Palace, the Tower of Tokyo and the skyscreapers of Tokyo. Both the room and the batrhoom were modern and perfectly clean. There is a free internet connection (cable), a big TV and everything you need for the bathroom is provided (shower gel, shampoo, conditioner, tooth brush, razor blade, hair dryer,...). The hotel is 2 minutes walk from the Hanzomon subway station, but the area is quite, so if you like to go out at night, you'll find it a boring area (keep in mind that the metro closes around midnight). For us it was not a problem at all, because after a long day visiting the city, we were so tired we went back to the hotel before midnight, We absolutely recommend it!

I stayed in the Grand Arc for 6 nights at the end of July which was a fabulous introduction to Tokyo. Wonderful hotel, highly recommended and for under £80-90 a night this a great value hotel. Hotel is well air conditioned which is essential when it's 35 degrees outside! Really well located as well as its a minute walk from the Hanzomen subway line (which is only 4 or 5 stops from Shibuya).The room - we had a front facing room so like many of the pictures had an amazing view every morning over to the park and the city skyline. I think rooms begin on the 8th floor so most should have a good view. The lobby was amazing and all facilities are first class.The staff - very helpful. Could translate instructions for me ( I bought Baseball tickets and couldn't work out when the game started) and the staff also really help us by booking a cabin on the 7th station of mount fuji (which took about ten mins of their time). The hotel also went out there way and stored our luggage safely for one night once our booking was completed as we climbed mount fuji and collected the next day. Top class.Highly recommended for short or long stays. I didn't use the restaurants but there are some really nice places 5 mins away for lunch and there is a small bakery round the corner for bakery. I really enjoyed my stay here, it really made the holiday!5 stars all the way for me, if I was being picky it would be cool to have free wifi as I couldn't use the wired internet with my iPad buts that my only fault!

Just came back from Tokyo (oh, I miss it already!!!) where we stayed in this fancy-shmancy hotel. Clean, shine, very polite staff, cleaning every day. Several channels on TV with funny Japanese shows, air-conditioning, view on Imperial Garden (closed Monday and Friday) and fantastic panorama of Tokyo, especially at night. You can use Internet via cable or at the reception or borrow a laptop. Metro is only 5-minutes walk away, but mind the stairs on the station if you have huge luggage or better hire a taxi. Lots of small shops and places to eat around. When we come back again we will stay there!!!

My husband and I stayed in this comfortable business hotel for 7 nights this past July. We were very pleased we did so. Like most of Japan, it‘s super clean although the room was small by Western standards. As we had requested, we were provided with a non-smoking room on a high floor over-looking the Imperial Garden. What a fabulous night time view that included Tokyo Tower all lit up. We found the staff to be friendly and helpful at all times including our late evening check-in. With a side trip to Kyoto in the middle of our stay, the staff was happy to store our suitcases so we could just travel with our small bags. Their consideration extended to booking us in the same room both times which made it easier to acclimatize. The soaps, shampoo and conditioner were all very nice. You get two bags of green tea and two of black tea every day. The small water heating pot was the only thing I would change. A kettle would have been nicer. The hotel Business Center has a good map of Tokyo that’s different from the airport one. While there is no wi-fi in the rooms, the hotel provides a LAN cable. This gave us excellent, reliable internet access. Try walking across the street along the Imperial Palace moat. You will see a small play ground, and lots of people jogging, etc. It’s lovely and hooks you up to Kitanomaru Park in about 20 minutes. We walked back from Ginza one day which took us about 45 minutes. Make sure you book your free tour of the Imperial Gardens on-line. It was so easy to get around the city on the metro from Hanzomon.Getting there from the Airport: First pick up a Tokyo Map and a Subway Map at the Airport Information desk in the arrival lobby. I think the easiest way to get to the hotel is to purchase SUICA cards at the JR rail office downstairs from the arrival lobby at the airport. Use these for both the train and the subways. They are super convenient and easy to re-charge. You must pay for these using yen, no credit cards accepted, so make an initial stop at the ATM. We took the Keisei Sky Access Line [1130 Yen each way] to the Oshiage subway station. This is the end of the Hanzomon subway line. Stay on this line until you reach Hanzomon station [230 yen]. There is an elevator, but it gets you out at the back of the station at the opposite end you need to be. Take EXIT #1. There are two escalators which cut down on the stairs. When you exit the station, turn right and you will be at a curb almost right away. Cross the street and immediately turn left to cross the street again. You will be at the hotel in two very short blocks.Food near the Hotel:There are two excellent bakeries very close to the hotel. If you walk back towards Hanzomon station but go one more block, you will see a Lawson’s store [like a 7-11]. When you see the Lawson’s , turn left and you are at Don Meister [open 8:00 a, to 8:00 pm]. The second bakery - a French Patisserie– get on the street that has the entrances to the subway and keep walking. You will cross a big street and pass a Thai restraint, Sawadee. Keep walking. Across the street you will pass a gas station, a little 24 hour lunch place [it was OK],and the post office [has a 24 hr ATM that accepts US cards]. I think it was also open until 8:00pm. Right next to this bakery, there was a tiny Chinese restaurant – 4 tables and a small bench. We loved the food there and ate there two times. We had sea food with noodles and vegetables for 800 Yen with a plate of 5 or 6 pot stickers for 400 Yen. We did not care for the Chinese restaurant on the same street as the hotel.

A great hotel that offers some amazing views of the Imperial Palace and the moat that surrounds it in addition to views of Tokyo's impressive skyline. The hotel is super clean, it has a bunch of restaurants in its premises and it's only a short walk from the Hanzomon purple line Metro stop. The only downside is the size of the rooms which are kinda small. You gotta love the robes and slippers that they have for you in the room!

Amazing views, good location 5 minutes to subway station and 10 minutos walking to the imperial palace.The room is comfortable and it has room enough for the logagge.Very good price. The least... Staff it is sometimes not bilingual and their attitude it is not service oriented.

The location of this hotel is its highlight, along with the great view afforded from the Imperial Grounds facing rooms. Location-wise, the hotel is convenient to two Tokyo Metropolitan subway lines (Hanzomon station on the Hanzomon line is one block away, while Kojimachi station on the Yurakucho line is about 4 blocks away). Iidabashi is a great area to explore that is easily accessible on the Yurakucho line (great restaurants, bars, shops and a Shinto shrine). Yasukuni Shrine near Kudanshita is also very near. This hotel would be a GREAT location during cherry blossom season. Immediately around the hotel, it seems to be mostly office and government buildings, with the notable exceptions of the National Theater and the Imperial Grounds (literally next door to the hotel on both accounts). There are a few restaurants that we would have tried had we not already had plans for dinner elsewhere. For us, who have been to Tokyo multiple times and live only a few hours away, this hotel was a launching point for us that is centrally located in the city (literally, I don't know if you can be in a more central location in Tokyo than here). Our biggest regret was not bringing running gear with us. From our room on the 15th floor, overlooking the Imperial Grounds, we were teased by views of dozens of runners making their way around the perimeter of the grounds along a wide, paved jogging path that appeared to have ample shade.The room was standard Japanese fare: small by American standards (but cozy for those used to Japanese business hotel accommodations), free in-room Internet access via a hard-wire hook-up only, clean and relatively quiet. We got a good price through Expedia (about $130/night for two nights), and would stay here again for that price.

We stayed here our second night in Tokyo after getting horribly lost trying to find our hotel the night before. This hotel was super easy to find, as it is right down the street from a subway exit. It is nestled in a cute little neighborhood that is very quiet, and has amazing views on all sides. It is literally across the street from the Imperial Palace, so if you are like us, and just don’t have time to squeeze it in, you can at least see the grounds from right outside the hotel. We went in the peak of cherry blossom season, so it was lovely to be able to see cherry blossoms in full bloom right next door to our hotel at the theater. The rooms were not any smaller than anywhere else in Tokyo, and in fact feel bigger due to the huge window the bed is facing. Our room had a view of Tokyo Tower and the cute little nearby streets. The American breakfast is NOT really American as we know it… I would have preferred the Japanese one. But a block away is THE BEST coffee shop/book store called ChocoCro, which has amazing croissants and coffee, though the menu is in Japanese for the coffee, just a heads up. The hotel was clean, smelled fresh and had beautiful décor.

excellent location, 3 mins walk to metro and 5 min walk to another subway line. Lovely views of Palace and city area. Freindly and efficient staff in hotel and in restaurant ( had a beautiful Japanese style lunch there.Stayed in a Japanese style room .....ok for the experience .

Next to the Imperial Palace and to a subway station. Typical tidiness and spotless room and lobby. Always the problem with language in Japan where even at front desk English is little known. Everything was smooth and pleasant. Restaurant not so special but good. Service impeccable.

We were afraid of size of hotel rooms in Tokio. So in last minute we change from hotel with 15 sqm room to this 24 sqm rooms. It was good decision. We stay at 16th floor: It was amazing view like in movies :) Tokyo Tower lighting at night, skyscrapers around ... Hotel is located near Hanzomon metro station. From railway station you will need a taxi for reasonable 15 euro. Imperial palace is near the hotel. You can walk to Giza by foot (around 25 minutes). We have very nice room, equiped with all you need, included internet. Be aware: at Tokio hotels internet is mainly wired. So you will need notebook or wifi router for using your talbets and smart fones.This is 4 star hotel with 4 star services. At the city center and witch great view from your room.

We really enjoyed our stay at the Grand Arc Hanzomon. Our room had a fantastic view of the Imperial Gardens and Tokyo. Although the room was fairly small it was equipped with everything we needed and we found it to be comfortable. The location was good - a peaceful neighbourhood, only a short walk to a metro station and the National Theatre was right next door.

Stayed at this wonderful hotel during December to January 2012 to celebrate the New Year. The rooms were extremely comfortable and well appointed and the breakfasts were great. As with many Tokyo hotels it is extremely well located close to subway stations, shops, restaurants and bus was nearby for a short ride to a JR station with an elevator for disabled people. The staff were most helpful to locate us up high with a palace garden and Tokyo Tower view to watch the lights show 2011 then twinkle up the New Year 2012 spectacular change. Hotel is in a quiet location yet close to all one would want to visit in Tokyo. Thanks to Grand Arc Hanzomon staff for looking after us..

we stayed here at the beginning of May. The room was a little small for two people as it was a semi double but the position in Tokyo was good, near the palace gardens- if you like to jog or walk- and fairly quiet. I thought it good value for money. Try booking a japanese room as they look out over the park and looked nice- I peeked in!! Overall, nice place with some nice touches.

This hotel has easy access to the metro, and is located overlooking the imperial gardens. The view is nice from the arc, either day or night. The room had every essential (plus the yukata robes) and was quite comfortable. There are places to eat on the premises, but not all open every day; there are other dining options in walking distance. The staff were friendly and very helpful.

This is a nice pleasant mid range hotel. The room was slightly smaller than a similar hotel I stayed at whilst in Kyoto. Here the double bed is against two walls. This was not a problem for me as a single traveller but I could see that it would create some interesting manoeuvring if used as a double as one of the occupants would have to climb over the other to get out during the night (however this may well be the same in many hotels in Tokyo.) The room was exceptionally quiet and I did not hear anything from either of the neighbouring rooms. The bathroom was well appointed though the bath was not full size. Breakfast, Japanese, American or Continental, is served at a cost of circa Yen 1000 and was a pleasant start to the day. The hotel is located very conveniently to Hanzomon subway station with exit 1 of the station being a 3 minute walk from the hotel reception. The imperial palace gardens could be seen from the bedroom windows as could the Tokyo tower in the distance.My reason for giving this four rather than five stars is that the bed was a little lumpy. Nothing that stopped you sleeping after a full day visiting Tokyo but enough for me to notice.

The views from the higher floors over the suburb and the palace gardens, is captivating especially during cherry blossom time. The ground floor cafe/restaurant provides prompt, quality meals from a restricted menu, at very reasonable prices (by Tokyo standards). Our room was a good size, with high quality fittings. The adjacent park land is perfect for an afternoon walk along the palace moat.The short walk to the Hanzomon underground provides convenient links to Tokyo's extensive rail network, however I'd recommend a taxi if coming from the central station. There is limited shopping and restaurants in the immediate area, but there are a number of convenience stores.

I would recomend this hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo. The rooms the were clean and tidy (only as small as the average hotel rooms are in Japan but me and my partner found that we had enough space) and the view was great (Tokyo Tower and the Imperial Palace Park). The staff were friendly and approachable - there is also a good level of English if your Japanese is not up to scratch. And the breakfasts were tasty - we ate there three of the five mornings we were there. It is primarily a business hotel and the location reflects this. The hotel is slap bang in the middle of the business distict which meant it was quite quiet at night and during the weekends. We found this suited us but this maybe a drawback for others. The transport link was excellent. A very short walk from Hanzomon station (Hanzomon line line) and this took you directly to Shibuya (in 10mins) as well linking up well with the other subway lines.Over a giant thumbs up!

our honeymoon to Tokyo and first trip to this wonderful city, we decided to stay here after all the great reviews. pros- very clean - free wired internet access- plug converter for 3 plug laptop power adapter - great value hotel- quiet area- close to hanzomon line - easy access to shibuya and omotesando stations, north track ends at the new tokyo sky tree in oshiage station- many places to eat nearby and in hotel- friendly staff, some spoke good english, others not so much - still very helpful- short walk to tokyo station east of the imperial palacecons- room was a bit small for a "double" room but we quickly got used to it- requested and paid for a non-smoking room, could still smell smoke - no currency exchange, banks nearby provide service- free internet lost connection intermittentlywould definitely stay here again!

During cherry blossom time, this hotel is the place to stay. The Chidori-gafuchi street is only 10 minutes walk away. Our room overlooked the palace moat with a city view and a view over the cherry tree lined street in front of the national theatre and was super!Breakfast was a choice of Japanese or Western and both were more than sufficient with endless toast or rice/miso.The twin room had a large bathroom and an extra sink outside which worked well if one of us was taking a shower.Hotel is 2 blocks from exit #1 of Hanzomon line and about 4 blocks from lots of choices of restaurants.
This hotel is clean and very convenient to the subway which is what makes Tokyo so accessible to tourists. Clean, nice room, good value - I would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Jeanne M
Sausalito, California, United States

review_body: Lovely views from the rooms, which were spacious and well kitted out. Staff were very friendly and went out of their way to help when i had to make an unplanned visit to the hospital! Level of English shown by the night staff was far from perfect but the effort they put into trying to understand my request negated this. Restaurants were relatively expensive but to be expected to a certain extentRooms very good value when compairng the price to the location and quality of the hotel - highly recommended!

Nice hotel with views of the Imperial Palace grounds. Subway is only two short blocks away and plenty of places to eat and explore. The staff is very friendly. If you are use to American hotel rooms the rooms will seem very small. On site restaurants are good. This offers a great location at a reasonable price so you can enjoy all Tokyo has to offer.

Here's another review on this popular hotel. I chose this hotel as a part of my home coming trip in the latter part of March and stayed ten nights. I was curious why it is so popular and also it attracted me for its location so close to my middle school and overlooks the area my father and I have worked. Yes, the location is in an exclusive area in Tokyo, close to the brain of Japan(the National Diet Building and the surrounding government buildings), the National Theater, the Supreme Court, the British Embassey and the Imperial Palace. I was also aware that the hotel is operated by the same company as the Imperial Hotel. It is very close to the Metro Hanzomon Line (Purple line). The Exit 1 is only a couple of minutes away but since Hanzomon Line is deep we have to walk up and down two flights of stairs. Exit 4 has an elevator and it is a little farther from the hotel but it isn't actually that far. it is possible to get to many major areas in Tokyo by using transfers on the metro from this hotel. The surrounding area is all business so it is quiet. There are several convenience stores and restaurants nearby but no supermarket. There is a small supermarket a little walk away though. The Imperial moat that surrounds the garden is just across the street so it is nice to have a stroll or jog (be ware of joggers in the evening and weekends so they won't bump into you).The hotel's lobby is nice and spacius. The hotel has a large wedding hall, several reception rooms and four restaurants and they occupy the lower six floors. The breakfast is served at a cafe on the ground floor for a Western ones and at a Japanese restaurant in the basement floor for Japanese ones. I tried both and they were good. I did not try other French and Tempura restaurants but they have very good reputation. The hotel front desk staff was polite and helpful but seemed unapproachable which was rather unusual in Japan.My room was on the 12th floor. It has everything we need, a clean bed, a night shirt, a TV, tea pot with tea bags, a trouser press and a connection to PC. The bathroom is not large but efficient and clean with plenty of ammenities. The room itself is not large but not very small for Japanese standard of a "business hotel". By the way I think this is a higher grade business hotel. There are public computer for English and Japanese use in a small corner of the lobby.There are vending machines, a card for Pay TV vending machine and an ice machine on evert floor.The best thing about staying at this hotel is its view. It overlooks the Impereial moat to the government area and the Tokyo Tower. It is very beautiful at night although Tokyo is exercizing energy conservation and it is a little darker than I remember. The Diet Building does not light up any more. Tokyo Tower usually lights up in red and white but it lights up in different colors occasionally. It was especially nice to see the full blossomed cherry trees in the front garden of the National Theater right below my eyes.I have enjoyed the stay. The price was good for the location and the quality. To me the view itself was worth the stay.I'd like to thank all the staff for making my stay comfortable. I appreciated the room attendant lady's kindness to check if I needed extra ammenitie or tea bags on days I indicated I need no cleaning service.I have one request to the hotel. That is to consider a microwave oven on every floor. It should come in handy. I am going to stay here again next spring when I take my son and his family for a visit to Tokyo.

We stayed on the top floor with amazing views of Tokyo and the imperial palace. It is a 3 minute walk to the imperial palace, so worth doing the 5.5km loop around it. Kojimachi and Hanzomon subway stations are both within easy walking distances - a previous reviewer complained about the stairs at the Hanzomon station, but if you're travelling in Tokyo, lift access is not always accessible in a lot of stations (and anyone who decides to get on a subway in Tokyo with "a lot of luggage", then moans about the lack of lift access, obviously doesn't plan their journey very well). Neither station is a JR line so if you're a tourist with a JR pass you'd have to pay a little more for public transport (we paid about 160 yen each time per person). There were many small restaurants around the area but nothing fantastic (we spent an hour looking for somewhere baby friendly), the closest department store was in Ginza, several stations away including a transfer. It is a business district so if you're a tourist you'd have to get on the subway for any tourist activities. The hotel itself was good - nice Japanese breakfast, a comfortably sized room, nice big bath and clean facilities. The staff spoke reasonable English for assistance with directions. No wifi in the rooms apparently - but there are coin operated (100 yen for 10 minutes) computers at the lobby. You get one 30 minute wifi access at the lobby or restaurant but it's quite slow. Overall a good hotel and I'd stay here again.

Our double room was really a semi double. That means that it was pretty small for a double room, and that the double bed was relatively small (120 cm). That did not bother us at all though, and everything else was very good. The rooms were very clean, the staff were helpfull and the view was very good. We asked to get a room high up and got one on the 14th floor. We initially booked a room for 3 days, but was so satisfied that prolonged our stay with 3 more days afterwards, and when we came back to Tokyo one week later we stayed there for one more night. Don't bother with the breakfast though, unfortunately it wasn't very good.The hotel is located a few minutes walk from Hanzomon subway station.

Maybe we were expecting a lot more, from the excellent ratings on tripadvisor. We were quite disappointed with what we got in the end. Perhaps the high ratings were from the hotel's many business travellers, for whom it seems well suited. Indeed, during our 3 night stay at the Grand Arc, the bulk of the hotel's guests were businessmen.To be frank, the hotel wasn't that bad. The room was small, as is typical in Tokyo, but we've had smaller. The bathroom was well stocked up with amenities and the shower was pretty decent.The view from our 15th storey room was quite nice - partial view of the Imperial Palace and right across was a clear view of the Tokyo Tower, a pretty sight at night.Staff here spoke good English, which was a hug plus for non-Japanese speaking tourists like my wife and me.Most importantly, price was reasonable.What we didn't like:1) Although the hotel was near (less than 5 minutes' walk) from Hanzomon Station if you took Exit 1, you'd have to climb 2 flights (floors) of stairs to reach the ground level. Not a big problem if you were a business traveller or if you travel light. If you had huge and heavy luggage, you'd seriously struggle. The exit with the elevator is on the other end of the station, so you'd end up walking a good 15 minutes to the hotel from that exit. Print a good detailed map to avoid getting lost.2) Wi-fi in the hotel lobby was horrible. It was difficult to connect and when we were connected, we would get cut off every 20 seconds or so. My wife is on the iPhone 4S and I'm on the Samsung Galaxy S. 3) My wife didn't have a problem with her wired internet in the room but I did. My connection was slow and hung frequently. Perhaps it was the Windows 7/IE9 my laptop runs on... but I had no such problems at the other hotels in Tokyo.4) Again, yes, the hotel is near to the station; however Hanzomon Station is connected only to the Hanzomon line i.e. it is not a junction. To get most places such as Shinjuku or Roppongi would require at least one transfer. Not a big deal, unless you have lots of luggage with you. 5) Compared with other hotels where the staff appear eager to please and are super helpful and warm, over at the Grand Arc, staff seemed cold and aloof. When we asked for directions, two of the staff looked disinterested and we detected a hint of sarcasm and impatience in her reply. Maybe they aren't used to guests asking for directions? My wife and I were unimpressed.Overall this hotel is ok. In summary, it is probably great for business travellers. For familie or couples travelling with lots of luggage, you might want to look elsewhere.

We stayed at this hotel for 2 nights in April. The hotel is very closely located from Honzomon subway, which on the same line as Shinjuku and a few other interesting places. Its also very close to the Imperial Palace and National Theater (to catch a Kabuki play). There are only a couple of restaurants around and a convenience store around the corner.The hotel is well presented, clean as a whistle and the staff are friendly. The room is small but average sized in Japan. Very clean. Comfy bed. Toilet is a decent size. Overall, I would strongly recommend it.

My wife and I stayed in this hotel for a week whilst touring around the area. The previous reviews are fairly accurate. We got a very good rate on booking.com, that certainly was well below the prive being quoted by the hotel. The rooms are small but clean and functional with all the mod cons that you would need. The bathroom again small but with lots of amenities etc. the room we were put in first was at teh back and had no view, but we were moved upon request after teh first night, this was good as at the end of our trip the Cherry blossoms started blooming and we had a nice view of them.the location of teh hotel is excellent, only 2 minute walk to coffee shop and metro line. there is also a 7/11 style store at the end of the road for snacks etc. we saw lots of people bringing drinks and food back. There was also a Chinese, Korean and vegetarian restaurant in tteh same area, all of which were very reasonable and delicious!I would only have two small criticisms of the Hotel.1) we ate in the ground floor restaurant one evening as we were tired and just wanted something easy, it was 25 Euro for a pizza, even though it was delicious, this is too much money!2) we stayed in the hotel for a week and while the hotel staff were very helpful when we asked for something, we did not feel that they were very friendly. (Maybe a cultural thing) Usually after a weeks stay in a hotel I am best friends with the staff! Overall an excellent stay in a good location would recommend unless you are a large couple!

Great hotel location for cherry blossom viewing on Chidorigafuchi and in front of British Embassy.Only 1block from Hanzomon metro (exit #1). Excellent breakfasts either Japanese or western ...we tried both, included in our room rate throbooking.com. Our room 1101 had great views over moat and castle gardens as well as blossoms in front of national theatre. Room was comfortable, large by Jap. standards, great washroom + extra sink. WiFi did not work in the room even though we had a router and in lobby only 30 mins free per day always at the exact same time! Our router worked elsewhere. Would stay here again for its convenience...3 blocks...to a wide array of restaurants and the price was good for Tokyo!

The hotel was as we expected from reading the reviews. Spotless rooms, free wifi, excellent bathroom amenities (heated toilet seats and bidet), great location, close to public transport and restaurants. The staff were excellent and, as everyone seems to be in Japan, very helpful. We booked early and had a fantastic view of the city and the Imperial gardens. The night views were especially spectacular! The price by Japanese standards was very reasonable considering the quality of the hotel and its location.On this trip to Tokyo, we actually stayed here on two separate occasions. The first time we had a western style room which was excellent; the second time we opted for a Japanese style room just for the experience. This was also good but for a gaijin a bit difficult to manage. In addition, the Japanese style beds are laid out by the staff at 5pm and this takes up most of the floor space. The room was actually meant for three persons but it would have been uncomfortable if this had been the case in our visit. This was the only reason I did not give it an overall excellent rating.I would strongly recommend the hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo but I will stick with the western style rooms in future.

everything we read so far in those Tripadvisor review was correct; well-located close to the subway, beautiful view from the (rather small, but very reasonabaly priced) rooms. One information thiough was missing: the windows in the rooms cannot be opened, so no way to get any fresh air and one is rtherefore stuck with aircon... Matrasses are not very comfy. Friendly staff.

This hotel is just right for business travel. Upscale "business hotel" with very clean rooms bigger than the usual for this type of hotel in Japan (of course still small by European or US standards) but everything you need, great views of the Imperial Palace and for the price is a bargain in this city. Plenty of good places to eat nearby and the station is just 3 minutes walk (Hanzomon and Yurakucho lines).

I stay in the Grand Arc Hanzomon for 7 nights.The next time when I stay in Tokyo I would come back to this hotel.It is just 2 minute's walk from Hanzomon metro station and close to the impera palce garden.The housekeeping is excellent. Extreme clean and thorough. The reception is good but I miss the special touch for be excellent exellent.Also the restaurants a very good.It is a very good price/ performance proportion.

The best part of the hotel for me was the location. Easy access to the metro, places to eat nearby, and right across the street from the Imperial Palace grounds. The view of the skyline and Tokyo tower from my small, but perfectly acceptable room was spectacular. The staff at the hotel were friendly and helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

This hotel has much of the characteristics of a business hotel including smallish rooms, no bell captain, etc. but also has some characteristics of a more full-service hotel. The front desk staff will forward your bags to the airport, for instance, which is normally not done at business hotels. The 2nd-5th floors are dedicated to wedding services which most business hotels do not cater to. The restaurants are upscale compared to a business hotel but not on par with 4-star and 5-star full service hotels.The rooms are larger than the average business hotel and the bath and toilet are noticeably larger than the pre-fab bath boxes in most business hotels.The location is not convenient to JR but is convenient to the Hanzomon and Yurakucho subway lines.
