Route246
Aoyama Dori and San Jose

review_body: The biggest advantage of the hotel is the great location. Very close to the metro station and to the Imperial Palace gardens. Rooms are rather small, but fair price.

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights in early March and were very impressed. I had requested a view over the Imperial Palace Gardens and received this, as well as non-smoking accommodation on the twelth floor. The view was wonderful by day but even more stunning at night as the many high buildings lit up the cityscape.The room was not large but this is usually the case in Japan. However, it was comfortable and had free broadband connection via a lead. We ate at the Patio Restaurant on the first night which had a good mix of food. The continental breakfast represented the best value at 740 yen and was very promptly delivered.The accessibilty of this hotel from Narita Airport was one of the main reasons for choosing it. Take the Keisei Sky Access train and then join the Hanzomon line to Hanzomon. Exit for Hanzomon Gate and then walk 150 metres to the hotel. Easy and the cheapest route!!

Pros:Very professional classy hotel. Staff speak English.Cons:Internet is limited to 10mb / file. There is no WIFI internet - just a LAN cableNot much to do in Hanzomon - will need to catch and change trains on a daily basis to get into central Tokyo station.Overall:Would stay again. 4/5.

The hotel as a whole was really nice: clean, friendly, helpful, and a great location (right next to the palace gardens in which we had a great view from our room). With an underground 2 mins away it's very easy to find (no need for a taxi). The only thing i ca fault is that the room was a tad small, but don't let that put you off. For the price bearing in mind it is Tokyo the hotel was fantastic, and personally I loved the heated toilet seat as we were there in January 2011. Highly recommended, happy holidays!

Rated this hotel as "excellent" simply because ratio of (experience there / fee) was quite high.Metro Station Hanzomon on "Hanzomon line" (purple line)" is very close, within a 2-min walk. This is one of the nicest feature of this hotel. "Hanzomon line" has an access to major stations such as Otemachi and Shibuya. Oshiage is also a stop at the end, where a new landmark of Tokyo, "Tokyo Sky Tree", is there. Even if you are not very familiar to using Metro, having a cab is also an option and is likely to be affordable, as it costs no more than or around 1000JPY for Tokyo station, Akasaka, and Ginza.I paid 10500JPY for a single room for one night, through a well-known hotel reservation website. It turned out to be more expensive than reserving a room directly through the hotel website. Worth trying. At first I didn't expect much for my room considering the price, but soon I recognised that the view from the window was much much more than expected. You could see the Diet, the Supreme Court, the National Theatre, the Daiichi Seimei Building (used to be a General Head Quarter of US), and the Imperial Palace. Indeed, a top-down view of the Imperial Palace may not be easily expected in Tokyo expect for suite rooms up in the upper-end hotels. If you are interested in ensuring such a view, I do recommend what can be seen from the room you will reserve, since the building is round-shaped and what you can see varies. The hotel is situated neighbouring to two monumental sites; the Supreme court and the National Theatre. The former was selected as one of "50 heritages of monumental architecture in Tokyo". I recommend this hotel especially to tourists relatively new to Tokyo, who may have had a nightmare of being charged of exorbitant price at any hotel in Tokyo, who may be unfamiliar to using Metro, or who has never been in the Imperial Palace or been to see the Diet etc.

Checked in late at night, staff were friendly though check in took a bit more time then I'd come to expect from Japanese hotels.Room was clean and tidy and well sized for Tokyo - but hot. We were visiting in midwinter, so the aircon seemed to be disabled (or else just broken) but the room was stifling and I was unable to sleep well.The location of the hotel is fantastic, about 2 blocks from the metro and one train stop from the lively Shibuya. The view from the hotel room was something else as well, overlooking Tokyo Tower and the city and river.Overall for what we paid it was a good little bargain.

We didn't expect too much before we booked the hotel. However, when we stepped into our room, the view of Tokyo Tower was in front of us! The night view was stunning!! We chose to have the japanese style room which was very authentic and clean. Nice experience!Staff was very nice and helpful. Highly recommended this hotel!

I read someting like .....good price "but"... a few reviews below and I directly stoped reading further.The facts:- I am paying 125 USD a night for a REALLY pleasant hotel in Tokyo (which is cheap even in poor dustly Sofia, Bulgaria!)- right now I am sitting next to my window at the 9th floor, looking directly on to the Emperor's garden! How much better can be any location?!- the room is small for Western Standards, but HELLOOOO, TOKYO?!- everything is spotlessly clean, the service is immaculate, just as everywhere in JapanAnything else BUT a 5* review of this hotel is a shame on the objectivity of the reviewer!I love Tokyo exactly for the many places like this one! In New York you'd be spending 300 USD for a room like that, and you might even get bad service :-)Price/Quality ratio: BEST IN THE WORLD!

I stayed at the Grand Arc from Jan 19 - Jan 24. I absolutely loved the hotel! My room on the 12th floor had a lovely view of the city and nearby gardens.I checked in very late and they were expecting me, which was nice. The room - small, but had everything you would need. Bed was extremely hard but AMAZINGLY comfy. At least to me! There was a decent tea service in the room as well as a fridge. The bathroom was small, but perfectly set up. The bathtub was very deep and welcome after a long day of walking.The hotel provides all needed toiletries, including full size bottles of shampoo, conditioner and body wash. They also provide razors, brushes, combs, etc. There was a good vending machine on my floor for quick access to drinks.I thought the room was very quiet and never heard my neighbors.Tips - Hanzomon station is one short block away. Take exit 1 or 2, cross the street and the hotel is just on the next block. There are a lot of stairs and it was a bit hard dealing with luggage, but worth the savings on a cab.Buy a Suica or Passmo pass for the subway as soon as you get there and then reload as you go! The Hanzomon line connects with many other lines in the city and takes you right to busy Shibuya - just five stops away.I didn't find many restaurants near the hotel and didn't try the restaurants at the hotel, but there are two little quick markets that will do in a pinch.

My husband and I stayed at the Grand Arc for four nights in December 2011. We were extremely pleased in all regards.First Impressions: Extremely clean, not-quite-luxury but close lobby and finishes, quick check-in (did not experience any communication issues though the helpful staff do not know much English beyond what is required for checking in and out)The Room: We stayed on the 10th floor in room 1009. We loved our room and had a great view of the Imperial Palace and could see Tokyo Tower! Again, the room was spotless. The bathroom was fully stocked with toiletries (razor, toothbrush, shampoo, soap, etc.) and the toilet was of the fancy sort. Our room was made up each day and we had no issues. The bed (we did the room with the bed slightly larger than a twin/slightly smaller than a full American size) and slept comfortably. The bed was a little firm, but the space was not an issue (I am 5'8" and my husband has very broad shoulders and is 6'2"). There is a TV (virtually no English channels except for a watered-down BBC World News, but this was not a concern of ours) and a mini-fridge you can actually use to store your own food and drinks. It was a lovely home away from home!The Location: We were so very pleased with the Hanzomon neighborhood. It was very high-end (not sure I have seen so many $100,000 cars in so few days in my life) and felt very clean and safe, though I would compare it to the Wall Street area of NYC: it pretty much empties out after work hours. I would also liken it to staying on Pennsylvania Ave. in DC, being just down the street from the National Diet Building. We were a 5 minute walk from the Hanzomon station, and 1-15 minute walk from a second station (forgetting the name). We had easy access to almost everywhere we wanted to go from those two lines. The Food Situation: We had one of the continental breakfast options one morning and it was very good and was served on what seemed to be china (possibly a porcelain). We each had an English muffin with ham, a small fruit salad, a glass of fruit juice, a tea or coffee, and toasted raisin bread. It seemed small but filled us until lunch. It was a little pricey (I believe about $20) and so for the remaining three mornings we ventured a few blocks away to a Don Meister (I think that is right?) bakery and enjoyed delightful pastries for half the money. There was plenty of selection for us in the neighborhood, though everything was a 5-10 minute walk. Our favorite was a little place called Lush Kitchen, and is located on the same block and street as Don Meister (running perpendicular to the street the drive-in entrance to the hotel lobby). You can't go wrong here--the menu features pictures of pork potstickers and fried chicken. These were delicious, but everything coming out of the kitchen looked delicious. We also ate off the lunch menu, which was noodle bowls and was also quite good. It was also very affordable.The Bottom Line: We are thrilled to have found such a quality hotel (I would say it is a very good business travel hotel, not quite luxury but close) at an exceptionally great price in a very nice neighborhood; we paid about $120 a night. I would not hesitate to stay here again or recommend it to virtually anyone.

Like all Tokyo hotels the rooms are smaller than in most other places but we loved it. Our 10th floor room had views over the Imperial Palace Gardens and the Tokyo skyline including a perfect view of the Tokyo Tower. Free tours of the Palace and Gardens are available by pre-registering with the Palace and start a short distance from the hotel. Also in walking distance are the Modern Art Museum, the Arts and Craft Museum and Science and Technology Museum. There are several restaurants in the hotel and we enjoyed the food and service we received. Our room was very quiet and clean and had tea and coffee facilities with a small hot plate to heat the water. This was a little slower than a kettle but fine. The bed was against a wall which was a little inconvenient but it was one of the smallest and cheapest rooms. There was a fridge. Free internet access was wired and free enabling an excellent Skype connection. There was an excellent range of toiletries provided in the bathroom which had a power shower and bottom washing toilet. The staff were very helpful and even sent a book back to us which we had left in the room. We travelled from the airport on the Airport Limosine (coach) but the nearest drop off was at the Hotel Excelsior which is about 1 km away. We could have got a taxi but mistakenly attempted the metro assuming that, like London there would be escalators. As there were not this was a struggle with our cases. On our return to the pick up hotel we found it a straightforward walk along the street which took us 20 minutes with our wheeled cases. Briefly, a good value place to stay in a lovely location.

I just had to write this review half way through my 8 night stay here.Good:- It's just 5 mins walk from the Metro. It's a direct line straight to Shibuya on the Hanzomon line. (I love Shibuya)- It's quite a decent price for Japan- It's a clean area- Rooms are small but quite a good size for one person if you take a double bed.- Full size amenities- I had a do not disturb sign and the reception called to ask if I was feeling well and if everything was alright (I got up late). That was very nice of them!- Great view of Tokyo Tower!Bad:- The mattress is hard and uncomfortable- You can't open the windows so the rooms get stuffy- This isn't the hotels fault but I've had three people come to my room incorrectly and call me by mistake- The internet is ethernet only (no wifi) and it's not stable. Goes down randomly and I cannot even access YouTube (I think it's blocked)- It's really cold right now (around 2c outside) and the blanket is... well I have a thin sheet and a bed cover (which isn't really a blanket). I'm serious! I had to ask for a blanket from reception, which they gave me. (it was like a cotton blanket)- The walls are thin and I can hear my the room next to me quite clearly. (Granted my neighbours were quite loud).- Not really many places nearby. There's like a couple of noodle places and a convenience store.- No proper kettle! There was like a hot plate that took 15 mins to boil a cup of water at a time. I was really like 'wth..."I'd say that the thing that dropped the rating down the most was the uncomfortable bed and pillow. It would have been great if I could open a window to get some fresh air in the room too.

I spent a week in this hotel over New Year. I suggest you request a room on the 12th floor or above, facing the Palace gardens & Tokoyo Tower. Rooms are small but well appointed, very clean & efficient housekeeping, all staff are helpful & most speak adequate English. There is Internet access but no Wi Fi. The hotel is close to Hanzomon subway station & buses. All in all a very reasonably priced, quiet & convenient Tokoyo hotel.

A good hotel with a great view, close to 7elevens/lawson and metro.The hotel shop is open 10:00 - 19:00 which was no good for me as i was out before 9:00 and back after 20:00.There is a good view of the Imperial Park and city, including Tokyo Tower but not a view of the imperial palace.If you don't have access to the metro, just a JR Rail Pass, then it's a trek to the nearest station but an enjoyable walk going around/thru the Imperial Palace Park.There is a busy main road but it has a good crossing system.This room had internet (wired) access and while there was wireless access in the hotel it wasn't avalable in my room, 18th floor.There was a laptop hire service available.There are ice machines and vending machines on each floor but for the if you don't mind a little walk then the 7 Eleven/Lawson may be worth a visit, with a larger choice.

Don't miss out that there is public hot spring 'sentou' just 1 min away from this hotel, you should give a try.Room is very clean, everything is perfect. Location, bathroom, serveice are all fantastic. No noise at all so confortable sleep is promised.This hotel is very useful for anyone visiting Tokyo for business or private reason, Even you pay a bit more, I highly recommend you to choose the room with a view.If you're luckey they might upgrade when a room with a view of the garden is available.

This really is a "grand" hotel, huge lobby, a few restaurants, big building facing the imperial garden and skyscrapers - the view from our room was just lovely, especially at nighttime. As so often in Japan, excellent, courteous staff.We've been to Tokyo a few times, it's a big city to say the least and we found that this hotel is in a perfect location for exploring - anywhere you want to go it's maximum 6-7 stops on the subway, and max one change. Very handy and a big plus. Immediate vicinity is not very lively at nighttime though so if you want to stay in the middle of the hustle and bustle you should look elsewhere.We booked a japanese style room to get some "Japanese feel" to this leg of our journey, but realised that we made a mistake. Sleeping on the futon mattresses on the floor is not very comfortable (and we couldn't switch since the hotel was fully booked). Also, the tatami mats has, as they always do, a special smell to them. If you're in doubt, we suggest you go with the safe option and choose a western style room.Appreciated the free wifi Internet accessBreakfast was good, but got a bit boring; the same thing every day.Considering the rate we got, the ratio price/quality was extremely good and we'll definitely look into staying here next time in this fabulous city.

Great value for your money.Check-in was fast.Room service was great.Very quiet at night.Rooms are kept tidy.Also, near from two train lines, very convenient to move around the city if you will stay here.

I checked into the Grand Arc Hanzomon earlier than the permissible time, yet they gladly provided my room key and whisked me through the check-in process. My room was small, modern and suitably equipped. Internet access was by wire, but immediate and without id protocols. There was a flat panel tv with pay channels, a comfortable bed, nice bedding and a clean bathroom with free personal amenities. The room appeared new and absolutely spotless. The view of Tokyo from the 11th floor [as the others] is stupendous. I found the value for this first class accommodation to be excellent. Slept like a rock in this quiet room.

I stayed in this hotel for 5 nights on business in a standard single room. The hotel is opposite the Imperial Palace so the location feels quite open for Tokyo. It's about 5 minutes walk from Hanzomon station on the Tokyo metro. My single room was small but had all I needed, including a LAN connection for high speed broadband. The bathroom was compact and could have done with a better extraction system as it got quite steamy using the shower. There was a choice of two separate restaurants for breakfast, one serving Western and the other Japanese food. I went for the Western option which was very good, with speedy, friendly table service (no buffet).All in all, very good value, and I would definitely consider staying at this hotel on another trip albeit for business or pleasure.

We wanted to stay in a hotel near the Imperial Palace as it is one of the few places in Tokyo to have an traffic free jog, and also just a 20 minute walk to Tokyo Station. The room was good, view from a double superior room on the 17th floor outstanding, and service pleasant (though limited spoken English). The breakfast that came with the hotel room package was also excellent value for Tokyo. We used the Narita Express to get from the airport to Tokyo Station, then a taxi to the hotel (about 1300 yen).

Very comfortable, stylish and clean hotel. Fantastic service. Delicious food. Staff very helpful. Excellent view. Nicely located, right in the centre of Tokyo, next to Imperial Palace. Will stay again for sure.

My boyfriend and I visited Tokyo for 4 nights at the end of Sept '11. We were overjoyed when we arrived at this hotel, everything exceeded our expectations. The staff were very friendly from check-in to check-out, even holding onto our luggage until late in the evening on our last day after we'd checked out. Upon booking, we had requested a view over the Imperial Palace Gardens, which we got and it was definitely worth requesting. The views were simply stunning, day and night!The hotel was incredibly easy to find, catch the metro Hanzomon Line (green) and get off at Hanzomon, exit at exit no.1 (be warned, there are 4 flights of stairs, no lift - but not too bad, as long as your case isnt too heavy! Mine was 22kg and i managed fine), cross the road immediately infront of you then follow the road to the end (about a 2min walk) and the hotel is on the left.Our room was on the small side, but I'm sure all hotel rooms in Tokyo are the same, but I must say it was delightfully compact and for the amount of time you actually spend in the room, you have to ask yourself, do you really need a big room? The bed was a semi-double but incredibly comfy and we slept soundly every night. The black-out curtains were a god-send too.The shower was so powerful, just what you need to wake you up in a morning, there were plenty of toiletries and anything else you may need - toothbrush, toothpaste, shower cap etc.Clean towels and bed sheets every day.We loved Tokyo and will be back, without a doubt, and we shall be paying Grand Arc Hanzomon another visit!

We were very impressed with the hotel in every respect, top marks. A one minute walk from the Hanzomon metro exit 1 brings you the hotel which overlooks the Imperial Palace park and for us it provided a view over the park, $1M view and no doubt. The room size for the price is probably unbeatable, staff were very helpful and the proximity of the park gives great options to exercise. Highly recommended.

We stayed on the 11th floor and you can't beat the view from here over the imperial palace gardens and the sky line of Tokyo. We had a semi-double and I was actually quite surprised with the amount of space we had compared with other Japanese hotels I have stayed in. There was a choice between Japanese and Western breakfast we had the western on one day and have to say it wasn't the best but the Japanese restaurant was really nice with friendly staff and reasonable prices.

There are very few hotels in Tokyo with great views of the Imperial Gardens from the bedrooms-especially at cherry blossom time and in the Fall.Well appointed bedrooms (Western style or Japanese) with FREE internet and breakfast included for around $120 per night makes this a great choice.

My wife and I found a good deal online for a room at the Grand Arc Hanzomon. It is a classy establishment right in the middle of Tokyo that served our needs exceedingly well.Our room was clean and well-appointed and while no one would describe it as roomy, there was certainly enough space to move around and to store our belongings. The views of the Imperial Palace were beautiful and quite memorable. Beds are comfortable and the fridge was a welcome touch. A flat screen TV in the room offered several local channels as well as CNN. Air conditioning works well and kept the room livable even on the hottest, most humid days.The hotel itself is quite elegant and has a remarkably beautiful lobby atrium. Service was always warm and helpful. The hotel restaurant offers a very good breakfast special with western selections (including coffee). Considering that other hotels during our trip were charging twice the price for similar meals, I'd say the Grand Arc is an excellent deal.The location of the hotel is both good and bad. It is very central meaning that other parts of Tokyo are very easy to access (the purple line is a less than 5 minute walk away). The Imperial Palace grounds are across the street. However, there is very little in the immediate vicinity of the hotel in terms of shopping, entertainment and restaurants that would be of interest to visitors. You will normally have to take a taxi or metro to find something interesting. It wasn't a big problem for us but some might prefer to be in a livelier neighbourhood.

In February/March this year, I visited Japan for the 1st time in order to take part in a run event. After a few searches on the net, my friends & I decided to stay at this Hotel which offers good discount.The hotel is located in a quiet neighbourhood, away from the bustling shopping district. It takes only 3-5 minutes by foot to reach the Hanzomon station on the Tokyo Metro Hanzomon Line (purple colour subway line). It is easy to move around using the Tokyo Metro subway network.My room is on a high floor with a fantastic view of Tokyo city at night. The room looks new and has a neutral colour scheme that makes the room bright. Furniture & fixtures are arranged in a manner usage of space is maximised. The bed is long enough for a 1.7m person to sleep comfortably. One can find an electronic alarm clock by the bedside for alarm setting. The room is not lacking in facilities that meet the needs of a traveller. In the toilet, a hi-tech toilet bowl washes one's butt by the press of a button. Try it!Despite the compact room size, I did not feel hem in. In fact, I like the cleanliness in the room and the magnificient room view. I was pleased with my stay in this Hotel. It is good value for money!

We found this hotel through expedia since it was having pretty discounted rooms, everyone mentioned how small the rooms were, however we found them to be just right. We are still here (check out on Monday) and we are having a blast. The hotel is centrally located, but in a quiet neighborhood right next to the Imperial Palace. Great small restaurants all around offering nice affordable meals. The Hanzomon Line connects directly to Shibuya which is a huge area full of restaurants only 10 minutes away by train. The room was extremely clean and was serviced daily. The hotel has a couple of restaurants. The staff at the front desk was incredible and spoke great english. They helped us with directions and calling different locations for us.
This was our last destination in Japan and perhaps we have been spoilt elsewhere. Not value for money. Reception service and degree of helpfulness was definitely below par.

The Grand Arc Hanzomon Hotel in Tokyo was very pleasant. We paid a little more to have a larger room and it was well worth the extra money. The maid did a great job cleaning the room each morning. I recommend having breakfast at the hotel as it was tasty and inexpensive for Tokyo. Other than breakfast, the hotel restaurant was Ok, but there are too many other good restaurants to dine at while in Tokyo. The location of the hotel is in a scenic area near the Imperial Palace, but it is not within walking distance of shops and only a few restaurants. There was a great French patisserie within walking distance that we stumbled upon. Otherwise, we had to take the subway for pretty much everything. If you don't mind being off the beaten path, it's a good place stay. But for your first visit to Tokyo, you may want to stay in an area where more things are happening.

Here are my pros and cons of staying at the Grand Arc Hanzomon.Pros - Very close to a subway station. - Courteous and professional hotel staff. - Quiet hotel with great city views. - In the business district. (can be a pro or con) - Free high-speed wired Internet. - Laptop rentals from the front desk. - 110v electrical outlets so no adapters are needed for travelers from the U.S. - Radio stations BGM1 and BGM2 are broadcast directly from the t.v., and play soothing music. - Air-condition unit in my hotel room was great. It was hot and humid during my stay and a working a-c unit was appreciated. - Strong water pressure from the hotel bathroom's faucets.Cons - No on-site currency exchange. - Must request extra towels (only one bath towel/per bathroom). - No travel-size bottles of shampoo and conditioner (both items were in big pumps)- No wireless Internet access anywhere in the hotel.- Floors are not designated as smoking or no-smoking, only select hotel rooms have those designations.
user_name:
AznNomad
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We loved this hotel. The service was very courteous and everyone spoke English. We were upgraded to the suite and enjoyed a gorgeous view onto the Tokyo Tower for 2 weeks. We travel quite a bit to Japan and this was the best hotel. It was possible as Westerners with no Japanese language skills to experience a Japanese hotel and ambiance. Everyone was very welcoming and attentive. The restaurants were very good as well. The first floor restaurant even has outdoor seating, the lounge on the fourth floor had a nice bar and also served food with a beautiful view and very good dishes. It was the perfect place to sit and relax with a drink after walking around the city all day. The suite was amazing and it was hard to leave this wonderful place. The most spacious suite and hotel room we ever had in Tokyo on our many trips. 5 stars from us. It was a joy to come back to the quiet and elegant hotel every night. The walk to the subway station was short on a quiet street. The jogging trail around the Imperial Garden was just across the street and used by many runners!

At first I had trouble finding this hotel, but after a bit of walking around, I managed to find it. Directions are not that easy.Check in was simple and easy and the reception area of this hotel is quiet impressive.That soon changes once you get to your room.The rooms feel quiet dated, and more of a 1990's feel to them.They are however clean, and in good order.Bathroom was ok, but once again for Japan's service and quality levels' I did expect a bit better.Breakfast was not included but I did go downstairs to try. I must say that the American breakfast is very basic, and quiet expensive for what you actually get. Next time I would prefer to try a restaurant close by.Staff were ok, but often didn't seem very welcoming and friendly.I wouldn't stay here again, it suited my needs at the time for a basic hotel near the city centre, with good views, but I will be staying somewhere else next time I'm in Japan.

I booked a double non smoking room, upon check in I was told there were no non smoking rooms left. So I agreed to stay in a smoking room for one night with the promise of being moved the next night. That evening I became extremely ill from the disgusting smoke fumes in the room so I was moved to a single room but was again told I would be moved a to a double room the next day. In the morning I was informed that there was no double room available after all so I was stuck with the single. So basically I paid for a double non smoking room for four nights but got something completely different. I wish I had stayed at a different hotel altogether as the location was inconvenient when trying to get to and from the airport. Transfers were required to get anywhere so unless you want to haul your luggage around Tokyo subway stations, stay somewhere else. Overall i was disappointed with the service and location of this hotel
nice experience nice experience nice experience nice experience

My boyfriend in I spent 5 nights here in May/June 2011. We couldn't have chosen a better place - the size of the room was amazing for Tokyo (to be honest, many hotels I stayed at in the UK where smaller!) and everything was clean and tidy. The location - a 2 minute walk from the Hanzomon station - meant we were able to get around on the metro really easily. We had requested a room with 2 single beds as they are bigger and the view from the window (on one of the upper floors) was brilliant. The area itself is not particularly touristy but there are plenty of eateries and supermarkets around. Staff at the hotel where always helpful. I've noticed the odd review commenting on staff''s poor English skills - first of all, remember that in Japan the huge majority of people do not speak English, even in Tokyo. Staff at the Grand Arc Hanzomon do speak some English, and they helped me with any query I had. If you want a hotel where staff speak fluent English, then this one may not be for you. We would definitely stay again.

My wife and I visited at the start of May as part of a Japan tour and we stayed at the Grand Arc Hanzomon for 4 nights. The room was very clean and tidy, the view was fantastic, the service was great & it was also in a great location (3 minute walk from the subway). The breakfast wasn't the nicest I've ever had but it was certainly edible. Overall I am very impressed with the hotel and would definitely go back if I was in Tokyo again.

Good location, next to the Palace. Staff are friendly and helpful, speak relative good English. No money exchange service at hotel, so make sure you have some cash before arrive at hotel. Room is very clean and in good condition. subway is only a block away from the hotel. couple of 24 hours stores next to the station.

The hotel is about a minute away from the nearest subway station (on the Hanzomon line) and about 10 minutes walk from the nearest JR station (Yotsuya). In the Chiyoda business district, the area is quiet after-hours and isn't the best way to experience Tokyo as a tourist. However, the quality and value of the hotel, and the ability to hop on a train after a short walk are beneficial. Because the area is a business district, there aren't many bars and restaurants locally. For food, I would recommend Vege-Table, which is just around the corner. The restaurant, which I visited twice, had very friendly, english-speaking staff (with english menu), and focussed their menu around vegetables (not vegetarian, although there were options), which made for a nice healthy meal amongst the many unhealthy restaurants. It was also well-priced. The hotel room was excellent - large windows letting in lots of light and providing a great view of the Imperial Palace grounds and city skyline. Our twin room had two semi-double beds, and a spacious bathroom with a basin and mirror external to the bathroom. Free internet was provided through a wired connection. The beds were comfortable (well, by Japanese standards) and the room was quiet. There are three restaurants, but we deemed them too pricey, so found others locally or elsewhere. This was definitely the best presented/equipped of our 4 hotels in Japan, and was a bargain at £50 per night for a twin room.

Friendly staff who spoke excellent English welcomed me to this hotel - which doubles as a wedding location for many Japanese. The hotel has it's own chapel, several ball rooms and restaurants - all of which were good additions to the hotel - and not disturbing for me who did not want to get married.The room was small, but really comfortable - the best about it was the excellent view. The first day I stayed there, it was really difficult to leave my room, as the view was simply breathtaking.The rooms was extremely comfortable, extremely clean - the only negative thing I found, was that there was no English language channel on TV - which would have been nice for the occasional news update.The location is perfect if you are willing to travel with the public transport system - otherwise, Hanzomon is a bit of a Business district, with only a few restaurants and bars around. The station for the Metro, is only 200m away, which makes it really easy.

very nice, sturdy looking hotel. staff spoke limited english but were very nice. our room was very clean, had a great view, and everything we needed. they have free internet but it's not wireless. it's located in a quiet area that's removed from the hustle and bustle, but i actually found that to be a pro not a con. overall, great experience.

Going to Japan with my boyfriend was a holiday of a life time but before you go, you get nervous about certain things. One thing we were worried about was "what was the hotel going to be like?" You never know what your going to turn up to. We were greeted by English speaking, really friendly, polite staff. The girl who checked us in was so lovely. We checked in to a fairly small-ish room but it was a decent size for what we needed as we spent very little time in the room anyway. The room had a huge window from celing to floor over looking the moat around the palace. I had to pinch myself a few times to check it was all real. The bathroom attached was lovely and clean and had a bath with shower attached and a super ace toilet with electrical settings :D The staff laid out new little house slippers for us everday and a clean bath robe. The towels were washed everyday and the room kept spotless. I can not fault anything about this hotel. The hotel was right next to a tube station which made it easy to get around Tokyo with very little problems. There is a lovely place to eat inside and with the staff speaking English, you can get help if you need it. I would recomend this hotel to anyone and would definatly stay there again myself. Awesome place and kicked the holiday off to a great start!

This is a centrally located hotel with great views of the Imperial Palace. Located conveniently on the Hanzomon (purple) Line, you can enter and exit the subway station via Exit 3, which leads directly to the hotel. The room and hotel service were perfectly fine. The bed had a very firm mattress and pillows, so the sleep quality was actually very high for me! Everything was clean and tidy. I especially loved the free pink scrunchie, which helped me control my long and frizzy hair in the hotel room!The atmosphere is "Westernised Business" but with strong hints of Japanese style. The ground level restaurant downstairs serves a satisfactory set lunch.

We had a reservation for the end of May, but given the natural disaster we decided to cancel out trip. This hotel offered NO REFUND. $600 down the drain. Not even half refund. I will never stay here even when I will go to Japan next time. I asked them to re-evaluate their policy given what has happened, but they do not bend the rules. Very, very. very disappointed with this type of customer service.

Do not go to this hotel if you are expecting any form of customer service. I booked this hotel weeks ago. After the Japan earthquake struck, I had to cancel but they refused to give me a refund on the grounds that it was a "non-refundable" booking. While I am sympathetic to the plight of Japan, I think it is basic customer courtesy to waive all cancellation charges when such events occur. Even my "non-refundable" air ticket to Tokyo was cancelled by my airline with no penalties whatsoever, and my cancellations of all other hotels for my stay in Japan was similarly smooth.In short, do not stay in this hotel.

Cannot recommend this enough, fantastic clean rooms with views over the Imperial Palace and the city. Great value if booked via online sites (£110 ish for a double). It's very close to the subway and just 4 stops from Shibuya which is a good nightspot. Also easily walkable to the famous fish market and the trendy Ginza district. The neighbourhood is swanky with some good restaurants and beautiful parks away from the crowds but close enough to be convenient.It also felt like it would survive a bigger earthquake than the one we experienced last week so safe as well!If you're coming to Tokyo, stay here.It doesn't have a gym or a pool but we weren't looking for those features.

I had booked to come to Tokyo in May and given all of the recent disasters decided that it would be safer to leave it for another year.I have contacted all the hotels I had reservations with and they have all refunded my money with one exception, this one !!!! Even after speaking to the reservations manager Tanakya the hotel is willing to do nothingHow disappointing is that regardless of what the rules or regulations may be they couldn't accept why I didn't want to travel and offer a refund. Its not even about the money as I booked this hotel early enough to get it at a cheap price but really would it have hurt them to refund under these conditions.I will visit Tokyo when things have settled down again and despite what look like great reviews this hotel is one that I shall never use again because of this incident.if you are thinking of using this hotel make sure you don't have to cancel or you will be out of pocket like me

I stayed here during the March 11 earthquake. Although it was terrifying, the hotel staff restored calm to the guests and offered special rooms on the second floor for days for those who were stranded or too nervous to return to higher up rooms. Food and drink was offered the entire time, and staff was available to help. The actual rooms were rather small, but okay for one or two people, and the location was great. Ask for a view of Tokyo tower. Great view. 2 minute walk from the Hanzomon metro station makes it very convenient for getting around Tokyo (three or four stops from Shibuya station, and two or three stops from the Tokyo Odeo line).

I honestly cannot fault this hotel, you are 2 minutes walk from the underground and there are restaurants of all levels within 5 minutes or less. There are 2 convenience stores on the next corner.The hotel has great views over the Imperial Palace and Tokyo and is next door to the National Theatre of Japan.

Was here for 3 nights in late Feb. Was allocated a room almost similar to one shown in hotel website. Great view of part of the city (incl Tokyo Tower) and part of the Imperial Museum. Staff were generally warm and helpful. Rooms were well equipped with internet cable, pants press machine, safe and toilet was roomier than those in other hotels i stayed on other days. On the whole, a great stay!

This hotel isn't luxurious but if you are just looking for a clean, safe and central place to stay while exploring Tokyo this is a great option. The Hanzomon metro station is about a 2 minute walk away, there are a few shops where you can buy sweets and drinks close by and the staff were helpful (although there is still a bit of a language barrier). Overall it was a really great choice.

It sets right across the Imperial Palace garden, jogger's favorite. Offers less than 5 mins walk to Metro station on a quiet street, far from the happenings and nightlife, stayed for 4 nights as it is central enough to Tokyo, Shinjuku, Ginza. But latest check-out time is 11am, and will start charging at 12noon.Room is typical Japanese room, petite, enough, not excessive. Free high speed internet. Great view which I enjoyed very much at night, dawn, and sunset. Tips: if many luggage, metro may not be the best option as the station's lift to the ground is quite far from/to hotel & metro gate. Metro a lot of stairs, manageable if no heavy bags

We booked months in advance and got a great deal for our semi double room - if you can get a good price for this place like we did go for it! Our room was on the 15th floor with an incredible view of the imperial palace gardens and the city including tokyo tower. It's a quiet area but of course like everywhere in tokyo there are plenty of convenience stores nearby and a few nice places to eat. Room was immaculate and very quiet at night. I was a bit worried about what the size of a semidouble bed would be like but it was fine - my partner is about 6ft and we had no problems both fitting comfortably into bed at night. Hanzomon station is only a few minutes walk away and if you understand how to use the metro/jr trains you'll have no problems getting around. The staff spoke adquate english and very polite and friendly. 24hr internet cafe in the lobby and a vending machine outside our room were a huge plus.

The Arc is right next to the royal residence so you get to enjoy peace and quiet away from other hotel choices in Tokyo. The national performance theater is right next door, and the DIET and other government buildings are a step away. Saw one patrol car and two bike policemen between 9 and 10PM during my stay. If you know Tokyo subway/JR rail system, location should not be a factor when choosing ANY hotel in the center ring.Pros: peace, quiet, safe, relaxed atmosphere, easy transportationCons: not a whole lot of eatery choices in the neighborhood but enough for 3 nights. Hop over to Shinagawa anyway for eateries. Free internet is a tad bit slowNonfactor: between my rudimentary Japanese (tourists, lean the local language before you head to any country!) and their ok English, communications is not a problem!

Pretty good location near Hanzomon station less than a minute walk. District is quiet and peaceful even walking at night feels secured. Perfect view of the imperial palace on left and Tokyo tower on right. Nearby, a few convenient shops which you can get snacks and food easily.Only point is that the staff are not well train in english thus if you need to ask them something, they may not be able to answer you.
I was impressed by the cleanliness and the efficient English speaking staffs they have! For a mere S$100 a night, I couldn't ask for more.... Truly a 5 * rating among all the budget hotels...

We stayed for one week at the Grand Arc Hanzomon and while the hotel is perfectly clean and the room-service superb, the hotel incomprehensibly doesn't seem to be much interested in international guests.This starts with "Japanese-only" user manuals in the rooms and ends with staff, that is capable of only rudimentary interactions in English which lead to more than one inconvenient situation.Even basic questions how to reach the airport or if a receipt can be made out are overstraining the helpful but in terms of language incapable employees.The rooms aren't too big but spotless and with a superb view over Tokyo. The in-room service is average with a noisy AC and a nice panorama-window overlooking the city.The neighbourhood is a business-district at the west side of the palace grounds. For those not wishing to take expensive taxis the metro is just a view meters away, while the JR-lines aren't not so easily reached.All in all a middle-class hotel with a very good value-for-money ratio but unfortunately a poor trained staff.

It is a business hotel clearly above average in terms of room comfort and quietness, cleanliness and service, and it is not really much more expensive than the average business hotel (at least it wasn't for us). The views from the hotel are just fantastic, and you have many different restaurants to choose from in the surrounding areas and the hotel itself. As a downside the rooms are a bit small and they lack storage space, but this is no different from any other Tokyo hotel within that price range.

Got a rate of 5000yen per night at hotels.com for a semi double room (stayed as a single but rate was the same for 2 people). Was very surprised that grand arc turns out to be such a classy hotel. Of course, it's no mandarin oriental, but if you are able to book the discount rate, this is definitely the best value for money. Pros:1. 4 star - grand arc is just totally in a different league from other budget chains like toyoko inn and villa fontaine. If toyoko inn is 1 star, villa fontaine 2-3 star, grand arc would be at least 4 star. BUT the price for grand arc is actually cheaper!!!!! When I stayed there, some very important person (politician possibly?) must have stayed or dined at the hotel. There were like 30 bodyguards on the streets and at the lobby to escort him. imagine the chances of that happening at toyoko inn ;-)2. Room size - the semi double room is 18m2+ in grand arc vs toyoko inn12-3m2 and villa fontaine's 14-16m2. Room is small for 2 people but very sufficient for single. One thing to remember is that a "semi double" room means that you are renting a single room for double use legitimately. So, it's unreasonable to compare the semi double room size to the normal double rooms by american standards. Years ago when hotels in japan were much more expensive than everywhere else, the semi double rooms became a good alternative for travellers who wanted to save money. Now that the hotel prices for every other countries have been increasing yearly, prices are quite comparable for normal twin/double rooms in japan and other countries. You can get a double room 33-40m2 in tokyo for usd 150-200, about the same as in bangkok. So if a couple decides to stay in a semi double room, they should realize that they are offered an alternative unique in japan so that they can pay a lower price for a smaller room.3. View from room - rarely in tokyo, especially budget hotels, does the room have such an open view. The hotel is located next to the imperial garden, so there is no building blocking the view at all. To the right side of the window, i could even see the tokyo tower light up every night. One more good thing about the open view is that it makes the room feels bigger.4. location is a plus and a minus. first there were some misunderstanding from previous reviewers that needed to be clarified. There IS an elevator to the ground at hanzomon station, just not at the closest exit to the hotel. For anyone who plans to stay there, there is elevator from platform to the gate and then another elevator at exit 5 to the ground level. The only problem is that exit 5 is at the other end of the station and hanzomon is a pretty long station, so it's quite a few blocks further from the hotel and there is a little upward slope outside of exit 5. But it's still better than haulting heavy luggage up flights of stairs.hanzomon line is actually much more convenient than i previous thought. can get to most anywhere in tokyo with max 1 transfer. for example,narita airport - 1 easy transfer at oshiage station (w/ escalators and a short walk). don't really need to pay higher nex fare to get to tokyo station and then get a taxi. dragging luggage around tokyo station to get to the taxi stand would probably be a longer walk than the transfer at oshiage station. if worst comes to worst, can always get a taxi from exit 5 hanzomon to hotel (about 8min walk to hotel with luggage)shibuya - direct trainomotesando - direct train mitsukoshimae - direct train (huge mitsukoshi department store)kinshicho - direct train (1 of the biggest 100yen store in tokyo and a famous yakitori restaurant)tsukiji market - 1 easy transfer at kiyosumishirakawaikebukuro - 1 transfer ginza - 1 transfer with a long walk or there is a bus next to the hotel which runs twice every hour. takes 20minshinjuku - 1 easy transfer at aoyamaicchomeshinbashi - 1 transfer with a long walkasakusa - 1 transfer at oshiageebisu - 1 transfernihonbashi - 1 transferakasaka - 1 easy transferryokoku - 1 easy transfer akihabara - 1 transfer at kinshichoas hanzomon is pretty at the center of tokyo, it's actually closer to travel to the rest of the city than shinjuku and shibuya. 5. service - pretty much impeccable as most other hotels in japan. service standards were 5 star. e.g. i bought some fruit and asked for a knife to peel them. within min, they sent the full set of knife, fork, plate, wet naps, and paper napkin so thick that it can pass for real napkin.6. accessories - full set of accessories including toner, lotion, after shave etc. normal for standard hotels but rare for hotels at the budget range. even the slippers were not the paper type that are used in all budget hotels.7. free internet in room. notebook available for rent for 1000yen per night.8. not the normal yukata provided. It's a button bathrobe which is great coz with normal yukata, the belt is always in the way when sleeping. but then it's not too sexy looking...cons:1. neighborhood is commercial and there are not a lot of restaurants or supermarket around. but there is 1 convenient store 1 min from hotel, 1 small supermarket 5 min away. Many of the famous restaurants in the city is just a short train ride away though.2. service was great but it was a bit strange that they were not too familiar with sending luggage to narita... don't know if it's coz mostly japanese businessmen stay there and there is no need for sending luggage to narita...? the girl needed to look up the procedure but they had it done though.3. there was no voicemail. needed to leave message with the staff.all in all very very satisfied with grand arc and would recommend to anyone who gets a good deal.

Just ended my stay in Tokyo with this hotel! We had an awesome stay with the hotel, with clean rooms and friendly hotel staff. The hotel is located pleasantly on the Hanzomon line on the tokyo metro station, so getting everywhere was no hassle for us. The view the hotel staff gave us was also what we wanted! We had a fantastic view overlooking Tokyo on the 7th floor. It was also extremely value for money as the rooms were quite spacious as compared to other hotels in Japan so it worked out fine for our family of 3.There was also small mini marts and shops located near the hotel so getting food was not a problem.

Very comfortable hotel, clean, classy, couldn't recommend it more for its price. Were it not for the small Tokyo-sized room I would say it actually deserves a 4-star rating. As it was, the room size was still much larger than all the other hotels I looked at in the same price range; it was perfectly roomy for one person. My room was billed as 'semi-double', whatever that is, fine for one person but would be bit of a squeeze for two. You can see for yourself if you go the hotel homepage - the room looks exactly like it does in the photo. Bathroom was fine, very clean, water was hot and shower was high pressure. Provided big bottles of shampoo/conditioner/shower gel. I rate hotels by their bathrooms and on the basis of this one, it's a big thumbs up. The hotel itself, though not a luxury hotel, was obviously a class establishment. A fairly busy venue for functions and weddings; many smartly dressed Japanese milling about the lobby/elevators. The function rooms are all on the lower floors though so my room was very quiet. Didn't have much occasion to speak to hotel staff but they were perfectly helpful when I did; provided a helpful little map of the local area with restaurants and convenience stores marked out. And that's actually all there is in the vicinity: small restaurants and convenience stores. Definitely not the hotel for people who want to be in the thick of it all. I think the area was more of a business/commercial district. The metro station is a minute walk away though so it's fine if you plan to travel daily anyway. The nearest metro is Hanzomon station on the Hanzomon line. I found I changed lines daily at the next station along, Nagatacho (also connected to Akasaka-mitsuke), so it would have been perfect if the hotel had been nearer that station but the Tokyo metro system is very convenient so it wasn't really a problem. (Tip: Tokyo stations are big so get the right exit!) So the location is probably the thing I liked least as it wasn't very interesting but in return you get a quiet and very safe neighbourhood right in the middle of the city next to the Imperial Palace. Best thing about my room was the glorious view. The hotel rooms have huge picture windows and the view is great day and night with Tokyo Tower twinkling in the distance. One suggestion mentioned in other reviews that I'll repeat is to get a taxi to the hotel instead of braving the metro - like I said before, Tokyo stations are big with many flights of stairs and long passageways; if you don't like lugging luggage around I wouldn't recommend it. I came from Haneda and got the airport bus (900 Yen) to Tokyo station, then a taxi from there (around 1500 yen). Tokyo taxis are expensive so this was the only time I took them. Airport bus drops off and leaves from the Yaesu exit side of Tokyo station (Tokyo station is huge and has 2 main exits).

We got a great offer from Hotels.com for seven nights and because the reviews were so favourable, decided to choose this hotel in Tokyo. The hotel is a very large building with many floors and it is situated in Chyoda less than a five minute walk from Hanzomon metro station. If you arrive from Narita, you will get to this hotel quickly from Tokyo station by taxi. The room itself was extremely clean with great views to the royal palace park. The bed was a bit small (120 cm wide) but otherwise the room had all the necessities, trouser iron to a blowdrier. There was even a bathtub in the bathroom (and of course a heated toiled seat ring). You can buy water and drinks from an automatic dispenser in every floor. The staff was very friendly (as expected in Japan).Great hotel in every aspect and highly recommended !!

The only real critic of this hotel is the room size (quite small), as most of japanese hotels. The rest is perfect:nice room furniture (the hotel looks very new), perfect service, good breckfast (just american, not buffet, but perfectly done!). The hotel has 3 restaurants, very good ones; the rooms have nice views, an is placed in a nice place, close to the Imperial Palace; there is a subway entrance at just 100 mts.Very good option in Tokio

Stayed in the hotel for 4 nights. I was surpise with the fact that the hotel room was massive, 4 times bigger than our previous hotel room in Shinjuku. I got a 50% discount because I booked the hotel almost 6 months in advance. for 75 Euros a night this hotel was an amazing deal, It is extremly clean and everything in the room was new. Free internet in the room. We had a room in the 12th floor , the views of Tokyo were amazing. Didnt try the restaurants in the hotel so I cant comment. The are is dead in the night, you have to take underground to go to Shibuya for dinner/drinks out. The Hanzomon train station is very close to the hotel but is not linked to the main JR circular line. Transport wasnt really a big problem but I personally prefer to stayin Shinjuku and Shibuya to avoid taking taxis at night. Overall very good hotel.

Stayed for 8 nights at The Grand Arc, fantastic hotel with great room, very helpful staff most spoke English. They even checked me in early, just what i need after a long flight! I was given a room on the 10th floor, amazing views across Tokyo. The hotel has about 3 restaurants and a great bar, which had great views across Tokyo, great place to grab a quiet drink before bed!Rooms are clean and well looked after, great facilities and cosy after a day walking round Tokyo. The hotel really is only about 5 minutes walk from the metro, the surrounding area isn't great, there isn't many bars or restaurants in the area, but with the metro so near and cheap you can soon get to the main sights very quickly. The Hanzomon stop is usually only one change from from some of the main sights and like everything in Tokyo the metro is super quick and always on time and really easy to understand.Highly recommend the hotel, which I would class as a 4 star hotel. great rooms, fantastic views and really helpful staff.

Its a very nice hotel, with a great view over the city and Imperial palace gardens. The rooms are bigger than other Japanese hotels, but still small by some standards. They were clean, the service was excellent there. There are a number of resturaunts and bars there, however Hanzomon itself has a limited number of places to eat. We usually used the subway to get to somewhere more interesting, but the Subway entrance is about 400m away. (Use the yellow signs to find your exit - the hotel is listed). While we were there the Tokyo high and mighty seemed to be meeting there and there were numerous TV cameras outside. For the price we paid for it, we were very happy.
This place is right by the subway and the Imperial Palace. I had a great view of Tokyo and Tokyo Tower from my room. Good deal for the location and lots to do in and around this area.

Firstly I went with my 11 year old daughter, so although the room was small, not such an issue, but we did have our 2 suitcases taking up most of floor space! But certainly adequate if intending to be out most of day. View was great & panoramic - and made the room feel much more open & bigger. Spotless, good size bathroom with nice big bath and shower, toilet with all functions you could ever want and more! Friendly staff - all those we spoke to could speak English. Restaurant good and reasonably priced. Location great - very close to subway. Took taxi to and from Tokyo Station (one hour from Narita Airport on Narita Express) and it cost about £10 for the 10 minute journey. Subway not worth it because of stairs. Free internet connection very fast - LAN cable in drawer in room - connected my laptop within a minute of arriving. Through Hotels.com we paid less that £60 per night for both of us which was very reasonable - I would have paid more. If we go back to Tokyo I would not hesitate in booking the same hotel.

This was the first hotel I ever stayed at in Japan and so I was shocked by how small the room was. However having been many times again and stayed at different places I know that this is quite a standard size of room. Although it was small it had everything I needed and there are lots of gadgets in the bathroom, from the toilet seat to the clever mirror that does not steam up after you shower!The location of the hotel is the main attraction though. With the train station nearby it is just so accessable. I just wish I had been there in Blossom season.

All of the reviews I have seen online have been from people who speak Japanese and mention that not many foreigners stay in this hotel. This is true, when we stayed there, as far as I could see, we were the only English guests in the hotel. None of us spoke Japanese and the staff were very helpful and most of them could speak English quite well. Just to add on to what others have said, really nice view, good location (couple of minutes walk from Hanzomon station). The rooms are quite small, but it wasn't much of a problem as we didn't spend much time in the hotel anyway.

Very convenient hotel located only 2min away from the Hanzomon station. Hotel was clean and the room is pretty decent size. Our room had 2 double bed and 1 single bed. One of the room was where the bath and shower was located and the other room was where the high tech toilet was located.Pros: The district seem to be business people oriented. There are restaurants and convenient stores close by and a McDonald just outside of the Hanzomon station. Very friendly staffs and although most of them don't speak fluent english, they would attempt to communicate with you by hand signals. Though my 2 night stay, I've encountered 2 staffs who were able to speak fluent english. (both during night time)Cons: I would not recommend this hotel to people who are not used to carrying heavy luggages and will be planning to take the train. Reason is the Hanzomon line does not have any elevator or escalator. To get in and out of the station you would have to walk up and down the many flight of stairs. (however if you are willing to pay for taxi service, its around 1400yen from Tokyo station to the hotel)

This hotel is conveniently located a block away from the Hanzomon station and right outside the west side of the Imperial palace. What is so great about that is that it's easy to find and every taxi cab driver knows where the imperial palace is. The rooms and beds are small compared to Western hotels, however it's typical for japanese hotels. The hotel was very clean, smelled good (because of the open floral shop), great food and the staff was very helpful. Our view was part of the imperial palace grounds and some of the hotels near tokyo station. It's way better than having a view of just buildings.

This is a business hotel (SMALL rooms) run by the same group as the imperial hotel (so I was told). It is very close to Hanzomon station and so really easy to go to omotesando, shibuya and it is also right near the imperial palace, very nice during cherry blossom season. Very few foreigners stay there but they seem to be able to cope (I speak Japanese but I think they usually had someone who could function in english). If yo want hustle and bustle I would not stay here.It is a good value and safe
